Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than5 years

Con:
1. Bureaucracy still reigns. Common Sense doesn't always prevail. The simplest things are made complicated... Every time a new senior leader arrives, there is a re-org or re-alignment... They say associates have a voice and they do survey associates, but if you speak up otherwise, do so at your own risk...

2. The company is making great strides towards improving career mobility but many legacy barriers remain in place, including attitudes of hiring managers and their superiors.

3. Very conservative company when it comes to risk...decisions are made by "committee" after exhaustive discussions, even over the most smallest and trivial things. Many times your work gets trapped by becoming all about the process and not the outcome.

4. Top Heavy. Appears to be a large population in the lower pay grades, but very few in the middle (managers, sr. managers), and an enormous Director, VP, and above segment. The top segment is all about taking care of each other when not competing or fighting one another.

5. Unless you sexually harass someone or get caught stealing something, no one gets fired unless it's an overall reduction in force. Lazy or inept associates are coddled or passed along.
Pro:
1. Above Average Pay Mostly. Great Benefits! Great Retirement. Match 100% of your contributions up to 7% after a year and3-year vesting program. Plus a 10% profit sharing contribution each January! Tuition Reimbursement and more.

1. Numerous different business units and sub-groups, many different career paths, multiple locations. Working remote up to 100% a possibility for many positions (off-phone), depending on business group.

3. Mostly good opportunities to improve your skills and knowledge.

4. Massive population to network.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than3 years

Con: Management is only interested in one thing,  and no one knows what it is.
Summary: "Graveyard of ambition with better than average benefits"
Pro: Parking,  Coffee, HSA, nearby trails.
Recommendation: Doesn't Recommend,Negative Outlook,No opinion of CEO
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than5 years
Author Title: Former Employee - High Net Worth Representative

Con:
Software engineers at fidelity are very low on the totem pole, probably a step lower than call center employees if I had to guess. 



The compensation is insulting. I went to a competitor in asset management for the same role level and tripled my compensation. You could probably quadruple your compensation by going to amazon, google, etc. A senior software engineer with 10yrs of experience at fidelity makes less than an entry-level software engineer at JP morgan/bank of america/goldman sachs with no years of experience. Don't work here unless you are in asset management. Those are the only people who make any real money.



The tech is severely outdated. Some engineers were working in COBOL while I was there. Once again, this is insulting and shows that no effort is made by management to invest in good tech. 



Management makes it very clear that technologists provide negative value, we were even told this during out first week. "You are a cost center" -- I can't tell you how many times I've heard this. It's so obvious. Why do you think there are barely any technologists in the Boston HQ? Instead they're pushed to the basements of New Hampshire and Rhode Island.



Bonus is insulting too. Don't count on that. 



People brag about the generous 401k match but it doesn't kick in for 5 years. That is 5 years you could be working as a technologist at a competing asset manager making triple your compensation. 



My first week at Anonymous a manager told me that technologists are expendable because their job can just be outsourced. Ouch.



This company has no path forward. Mutual funds are a thing of the past now that low-fee ETFs have become so popular. And their brokerage is so outdated.
Pro:
- I worked with some very smart people. It's a shame they worked here where they aren't at all valued.



- Work isn't challenging at all. You can coast and do nothing all day and slip through the cracks.

Con: Like many large companies, it can be bureaucratic and slower moving than I'd like (although better than most of the large companies I've worked at). Some individuals are motivated by self-interest and politics and kissing up can trump business results.
Summary: "Wonderful place to live a well-rounded life"
Pro:
The work-life balance, benefits, and compensation package are the best I've ever had at any companies. The culture is collaborative and not stressful. There are many senior leaders that are women, including many that have young children at home, which I believe helps set a great tone for work-life balance.



Given the business is privately held and family run, I've found leadership to demonstrate more long-term and strategic thinking compared to large publicly traded companies. There is a desire to deliver today and plan for tomorrow.



Over the last few years, there has also been an earnest push to keep pace on rapid innovation with the rise of fintech and operate under agile principles. People do value pace over perfection and speed to market, but there is still a ways to go to truly be agile.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than a year

Con: The environment can occasionally be very cliquey. Your ability to move or grow is extremely dependent on your relationship with your manager.
Pro: Anonymous is a great company that truly cares about its employees. They are very competitive on benefits and encourage movement between departments.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than a year
Author Title: Current Employee - High Net Worth Service Associate

Con:
This job will literally drain your life, you're answering 30-40 phone calls per day. You're graded on your CEI (customer survey) and your CPH (call per hour), which sometimes you get surveys for calls that is not your department (wtf 401k calls).



Promotion is not based on your CEI and CPH alone, they will promote you if they like you enough. Good luck on getting a manager that you'll get along with, some of them don't care (looking at you Lauren, coming in at 11am and leaving at 3pm), and some are so obsessed with stats that they'll work your until you die. 



Oh you're putting in overtime? That's great, we're expecting you to, who cares if you don't have work/life balance. 



Stay away from this job if you can get anything else. Don't believe it when they tell you 'oh here is a Ping Pong table you get to use', or 'you can sit anywhere you'd like', because they're too cheap to build their own place, and they're overcrowding this office. 



P.S. you better drink that koolaide.
Pro: The people you work with, and that they pay you to study.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time

Con: In the financial center I worked, the monthly review was a verbally abusive situation.  It would involve personal insults  and create a "damned if you do, damned if you don't" atmosphere. When achieving stated goals, you would be berated in the "way" you achieved the goals. The corporate culture at Anonymous claims an "open door" policy for its employee's. In reality, an employee is committing career suicide by complaining about an abusive situation. In my 25yrs as a financial professional, I have never worked in a more toxic unprofessional environment. Perhaps brought on by age discrimination.
Summary: "Good Pay / Head Games / Verbally Abusive Reviews"
Pro: Anonymous offers a competitive compensation package
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than3 years

Con:
The environment in the regional centers is not very modern. Males dominate the industry and it's very clear when looking around. If you aren't one of the "it" people or popular, you're out, or they will not be on your side like others. 
The benefits are somewhat skewed to a specific group of employees, so not everyone gets to benefit from them. 
They aren't very competitive with base pay and put a lot of money you could be making in your pocket into your 401k.
Summary: "The base salary is not competitive but the overall "benefit package" is good I guess"
Pro: Not super expensive health insurance. Good101k match and profit sharing (yearly into your101k - avg. 10%)
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than5 years

Con: You take about 80 calls a day, Managers are not helpful and make the job even more stressful. They care more about customer satisfaction than they do employee satisfaction. Under payed and over worked. Expected to work overtime hours and shamed if you opt out. Don't work here. my mental health is still recovering from this sweat shop of a call center. They rant about how great their benefits are (7% comp match) which would be good if you made more than what they pay. The calls suck, customers are incredibly rude. No flexibility on hours and not very understanding on leaving early. I would not recommend this role to my worst enemy. I left on my own terms and met some really good people their but everyone is miserable because the job is ..... also don't expect to use this as a 'foot in the door type' because once you're in the call center there's no movement out. I was their for 2 years and got promoted within the call center but never once met or saw anyone get an opportunity that didn't involve answering the phones. Look elsewhere
Pro: solid benefits and bonus, was able to get Series 7 +63 after a year
Recommendation: Doesn't Recommend,Neutral Outlook,No opinion of CEO

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 10 years

Con: I honestly never had any issues here that weren't my own fault (and I had a few for sure).
Pro:
I worked here for over decade, and I really enjoyed my time here. I remember the day I got hired as a temp. My world changed, and I was so excited to start my new hire training class. The people at Anonymous are top notch from the security guards, to the cleaning crew, to the executives. This company is ridiculously good at finding the right people who fit the culture and help others grow.



My manager had flexibility where required, and demanded excellence where necessary. I was never unsure of expectations because of the constant feedback loop, and I always strived to do the best work possible because of it. In my group, we had executive leadership involved as well, and even though I was a lower level employee, they were fun, respectful, and always treated me like part of a very important team. I couldn't have asked for more from Anonymous, and I was sad to leave.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for less than a year

Con: There aren't really any cons. You are getting paid to learn(say what?). It is what you make of the program.
Pro:
Within the LEAP Program as an Associate Software Engineer, you get trained for roughly 11 weeks. After this, you'll have dedicated project time where you work on a real project within Anonymous Investments. A great plus is, you get paid during training. You'll learn things such as front end, middle tier, and back end technologies. You are basically getting equipped for your future role within the company. You work closely with your manager and they'll try to find the best role for you. Ie, if you want to work more on front end(html/css/angular), they'll try to find the best role for you. 



Trust me, as a recent college graduate, this program is unreal. It truly is a gateway to success for your Software Engineering career. It helps you get your feet wet, and feel the least bit comfortable to get off to a good start. 



Here is a list of Pros:

-101k match (7% at 100%) + ~10% profit sharing (Ie: its ultimately 17%101k match)

- Student Loan Assistance (Up to $10,000) 

- Great networking along the way (You are in classrooms with recent graduates just like you. Great life long friendships and connections were made!)

- Learning Front End, Middle Tier, Back End Technologies (The general ones Anonymous uses.... and no, these aren't legacy software technologies)

- Learning coding concepts/design patterns

Con: Not much job security and very restricted schedule.
Pro: It has been a good experience.
Recommendation: Doesn't Recommend,Neutral Outlook,No opinion of CEO

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 8 years

Con:
The managers are high strung and a bit too interested in your personal life, almost seemingly desperate to make friends with you.  If you don't want to join your team members or whoever works their for lunch, every working shift, they look at you funny. No, joke the culture is overwhelmingly in your personal business. Not recommended for the reserved type or the "I need a break from you all" type. There's also a company ball (no joke) that they request all of their staff to attend. It's like a company prom, because yes you need to wear a gown or suit. WTF. And if you don't attend, then they look at you funny.



The series 7 training is a joke. The trainers that we had were aweful. One used weird metaphors constantly to teach, and when he was told that his metaphors were confusing he would smile and use additional metaphors to explain the other ones. WTF. The other trainer was on some sort of stimulant, and would constantly speed walk from one side of the room to the other waving his arms around like a monkey swinging on a branch, but missing the branch.
Pro: The benefits are decent. They offered an HSA account with company contributions (not sure if they still do this), health care and dental at a decent monthly cost, vacation, sick time, and PTO.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for less than a year

Con: Difficult to get Vice President based on hard work and ability.  You have to be exceptional at managing up, and skilled at waxing eloquently while really saying nothing of value.  Sounding good and being liked by your manager is more important than being effective, liked by your colleagues and trusted by your direct reports.
Pro: Tremendous resources and good pay
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 10 years

Con:
The pay is not comparable to other major investment firms, and it doesn't keep up with cost-of-living increases we've seen in the Denver area. 

There is also a big difference in what some managers bring to the table versus others. There seems to be a 50/50 spilt between managers who show up, coach their team, and support their associates and those who, frankly, don't. If you get one of the managers who doesn't, there is no opportunity to switch.
Pro: The company has a great work-from-home opportunity for a lot of roles, the health care plan choices are pretty good and are affordable, and there are a lot of options for schedules, making it easier to balance work/home life.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than5 years

Con: The salary is the worst part. You get quarterly compensation which is nice and can be a lot depending on your function but they rarely budge on raising your base pay. This is used as an excuse to not raise your base pay when you move around. Also, this is a call center job so not specifically a con to fidelity but these type of jobs have their ups and downs.
Pro: I think Anonymous is a great place to start your career. Their benefits are really good and affordable, and they have very generous PTO and 6 weeks paid paternity leave for men. I have read a lot of reviews about there being a lack of movement. I can honestly say that I could see that being an issue for some people. In my own experience Anonymous rewards being ambitious. A lot of people here have been in their role for a very long time and become jaded. Be ambitious,  take initiative, and it's not that hard to move up here. Comparitively there is a lot of opportunity here, if you miss out on that you have nobody to blame but yourself. Not to mention every manager I have met at fidelity seems to genuinely care about advancing your career. Quarterly comp is nice. Working from home is a other nice part if fidelity, but this also varies depending on your function.

Author Title: Former Employee - Senior Phone Site Manager

Con:
Though the Emerging Leader Program was designed to allow liberal arts graduates to learn about financial services in an "elite" program, it has its severe downfalls and ultimately I do not recommend this program to anyone considering starting their career with ELP. My cons are as follows: 



- Commuting: for New England based associates, you are expected to travel to your assigned rotations in either RI, NH, or Boston. These assignments are chosen subjectively by your manager, and you do not know up until 3 or so weeks before your rotation begins. Though you can express interest in rotations that are based in Boston, NOTHING is ever certain or clear, you may be left surprised at your unsatisfying assignment. Not everyone in the program will get assigned a rotation that requires 2+ hours of driving so you may be a part of the unlucky few that is left to drive into the woods for a dark 4 months. You cannot log your miles driven so you do not get reimbursement for gas, the low compensation does not help  cushion the cost either.



- Rotation assignments:  The program  gives associates three 4-month long rotations in different business units within fidelity. If you have an interest in a certain group - finance, strategy, personal investing, etc. there is no certainty that you will be able to work with them as the rotations are assigned by topics - operations, product, and data analytics (which they don't even stick to half the time so it's unorganized). The way these are assigned are subjectively your manager who you share your interests with but they ultimately decide where you will go. You may be left unhappy and confused at what you are assigned and the lack of skills developed in 4 months. Management hammers into you to "trust the process" but I caution you not to. The lack of structure to how placements are assigned is the single biggest downfall of the program since final placement is correlated to the work experience you have or haven't been able to build in the past 18 months. 



- Compensation: the comp is way too low for an "elite" program and compared to similar programs at other firms!!



-  Diversity and Inclusion: though efforts are being made to advanced inclusion in the firm and program at wide, don't expect Anonymous to be as socially aware as your liberal arts college. You'll find people with similar social consciousness but as a firm they still have a ways to go - though sincere efforts are being made, culture changing is slow at a large firm. This lack of D&I inevitably trickles down to ELP management and the decisions made so enjoy :). 



I see the program thriving in 5-10 years when large structural changes have been made (which are being considered to be transparent). 



TO BE CLEAR - most of my feedback is for ELP and not Anonymous at large, there are great parts of the firm that are healthy and great career drivers that I would highly recommend.
Pro:
Anonymous at large is a good company to start your career in, there are great people at the firm always willing to lend a hand and offer career help and connections. Different from other financial services companies, Anonymous doesn't work its employees all day and night so you'll have a social life and get sleep.



I joined Anonymous after college as a part of the Emerging Leader Program - a new 18-month rotational program for college graduates based in New England.  The program pros are: 

- Exposure to senior leadership: many 1:1's with VP's, SVP's and executives once in a while

- Opportunity to travel: ad hoc and there is a trip ELP plans to tour the different Anonymous sites

 - Working new jobs/roles: you won't get bored for too long since you are rotating every few months 

- Comradery:  You do the program with other new college grads and you build a great comradery and makes the experience fun as well as gives you great new friends. 

- Connections: different from networking, you will meet great individuals along the path that will be sincerely great mentors, rotational managers, and friends at the firm.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 8 years

Con:
Compensation: Compensation is extremely low for the caliber of people they expect to hire for ELP. They told us they did 'comp' research and that we're in line with other liberal arts grads in the business sector, but for the amount of knowledge and commitment they are asking (jumping around different BUs and delivering business value straight away, commuting over 110 miles a day some months) we are grossly underpaid. Several of us have done research and know we can get at least 25% more at any other comparable role. They tell us that our amazing benefits make up for it, but I don't see many of us, right out of college, using home insurance benefits or "College Success Planning." Those of us holding out are hopeful that our final placement salaries will be a significant increase. 



Management: Management is not as up-to-par as would be expected for a program that recruits from elite liberal arts colleges. One of the managers has an online degree from a for-profit university and it shows- no critical thought, inability to understand and digest feedback without getting defensive, and has worked her way up using relationship skills without actually being qualified for her position in regard to merit. Her manager, an SVP, is too busy with her other initiatives and only seems to present herself at the "fun" opportunities - team-building sessions, orientation, etc. We as a cohort have no insight into what she is doing for the program or if feedback is being relayed up to her at all. Overall, the management team may be well intentioned but lacks clear direction and minimizes transparency in order to hide the fact that they don't really know what they're doing either. 



Rotations: While ELP may present itself as a cool opportunity to explore different functions, expect to be disappointed when finding out where you got placed. Rotations are based on "business need," meaning that while you may express interest in a particular field, you may end up in a completely different field. Management will try to make it seem okay by pointing out the "positives," but it doesn't address the fact that you may potentially waste four months doing something you have no interest in doing and you could've spent doing something that would actually bring some clarity to your career options. 



Final Placement: Placement after the program is supposed to be based the rotation that you matched the most with and enjoyed doing. However, some people get rotations that have no intention of hiring someone from ELP, and get stuck with getting placed in one of their rotations they didn't enjoy or have to scramble to network to see if there are any opportunities available outside of their rotations. Once that process is done and you have your options (assuming you have more than one option), you don't even know salary information until AFTER informally accepting the full-time position- we're supposed to not worry about salary and instead choose the placement option that best "aligns" with our career wants. After this informal acceptance, we then get the "official" offer letter and sign that. I've never heard of an instance where you don't know salary information before accepting a role, but like in many other cases where things in the program don't make sense, there is always a "reason" for the way things are. 



"Trust the Process" : If I had a penny for every time I heard "Trust the Process"...this is the term used by management as a palliative for the program's serious structural issues. Hate the rotation you're in? There's a reason why you got it, you just have to trust the process. Is your rotation not even close to what your career goals are? There's a reason for that, trust the process. If you ever hear this phrase, beware!
Pro:
***This review and ratings are oriented towards the Emerging Leader Program, not Anonymous as a firm.***



Meeting Executives: ELP presents several opportunities to meet executives across the firm, and we even have a team Q&A session with the CEO. At the end of the program, we report out a capstone project to all the executives, which is great visibility. 



Enterprise-Wide View: Since you are rotating in all different areas of Anonymous, you get a great view of how the firm functions as a whole. With the firm's initiative to work better as a collective unit (as opposed to silos), this is an opportunity that allows you to bring a lot of insights to different groups. 



Work-life Balance: I have never had an instance where I've had to work more than10 hours in a week, and management is very flexible if you need to take time off during the day as long as you're getting your work done. Planning vacation is never an issue, management would never say you can't take a vacation or anything like that.

The turnover at the branches brings down client satisfaction. It is definitely a what have you done for me lately type of place. Monthly business reviews can be brutal for people who are not producing. 



You might have managers or trainers that have never been in your seat, or could not cut it so they transitioned. Makes it difficult to have them coach when they have not done it. 



 You make just enough money that its difficult to leave, and they do that on purpose. My advice for people is to get your certifications and a few years experience and then look elsewhere before you start making so much that its hard to leave.
Summary: "Great place to learn the industry and get trained- then you should leave"
Pro: Really good training, their sales process is taught to other firms but they do a great job of driving the process home. Best benefits in the industry and they are now offering flexibility to work from home. They will pay for your licenses and CFP. You can learn as much as you want to learn, plenty of resources available for you.  Great place to gain experience.  You'll never have to cold call for prospects.

Con:
Discriminates against pregnant women and then penalizes you and shames you for having to pee frequently. 
Gives too much VTO and doesn‚Äôt anticipate proper staffing to help cover 2nd shift at night. 
Pressures employees to do the impossible and demands perfection yet pays crap, and doesn‚Äôt even listen to their employees.
PTO can only be planned. They get angry if you have to take sick days. 
They don‚Äôt actually give credit to outstanding employees like they should. I was supposed to get a VOC award but the manager who took it never submitted it even after multiple requests. 
They refuse to change your schedule.
The company says they‚Äôre family friendly but they really aren‚Äôt. 
They force you to sign a sort of gag order which means you‚Äôre not allowed to tell incoming employees or potential employees how bad it is while you work there up to a year after you leave.

They expect you to do all of these ridiculous things during a call, jump through hoops in a quick and timely manner however also need to be able to connect with callers while being verbally abused. 
The work environment is a little toxic. Feels like high school. If you‚Äôre not in someone‚Äôs click then you‚Äôre alone. If you‚Äôre pregnant they do give you a generous maternity leave however they are prejudice against you if you‚Äôre pregnant or become so. I had to constantly get up and go to the bathroom and had severe vertigo, because of that I wasn‚Äôt taking calls which caused my stats to go down. I was constantly pulled aside and ‚Äúcoached‚Äù, a polite way of reprimanding, and told that I, a pregnant woman, needed to hold it till my breaks. When I called HR about it I was told other pregnant women were held to the same standards, yet my own sister in law was almost fired because of the same issues. Every pregnant woman I‚Äôve known who worked this position quit because of the discrimination. Doing a lawsuit against the company would be pointless because they can just say I wasn‚Äôt adhering to my required stats and NH is an at will state.
Word to the wise, don‚Äôt plan on starting a family while working on the floor. They will use every excuse under the sun as to why you can‚Äôt transfer departments or grow in the company and why you can‚Äôt get a different shift. I was 1:30-9:30pm. After I got pregnant I needed to change my schedule because I couldn‚Äôt drive at night. But again I was denied. 
I left the company because my mental health tanked so low from verbally abusive callers and an employer who didn‚Äôt care about what was going on and from being isolated because it‚Äôs like high school, and I was refused a shift change that I desperately needed.
Summary: "Difficult. When you work 401k on the floor, at least when I was there, it‚Äôs back to back."
Pro:
Great benefits and amazing healthcare.
401k has a large portfolio, great matching and profit sharing if you are there for years. 
PTO and VTO,  FMLA
Maternity leave 6-7 months, Paternity leave about a month I think. 
Lots of OT for second shift.
Recommendation: Doesn't Recommend,Neutral Outlook,No opinion of CEO

Con: It all begins with job satisfaction, people in general tend to do jobs they enjoy and are passionate about even if pay is lacking, but fidelity has clearly missed the mark. A volume based discount broker call center where even team leads (managers) are frustrated with leadership. Upper management is not there to help build a profitable successful environment but make sure numbers on spread sheet are met. 95% of the people I worked with actively are unhappy with their current job and only stay so they can get their 5 year vesting. I‚Äôm truthfully dumbfounded at the lack of communication with management down to reps. I‚Äôm disappointed to say I wasted so much time at the company and missed valuable opportunity actually being able to advise build relationships. This company the last two years had tried to put a square peg into a round hole and has lost a lot of talented people. This will continue to be the trend because Anonymous is slow pace when it comes to change. Culture there was absolutely horrible with people just struggling through daily life and I hope those who read this can take this as a warning! Unless you are absolutely desperate or doubt mind being an un valued easy replaceable cog in the Anonymous machine you can do so much better..
Pro: None that would out weigh the cons

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 10 years
Author Title: Former Employee - Vice President and Managing Director

Con:
Pay: You'll get less in salary than at other financial services firms. Anonymous tries to compensate for this with their generous benefits programs. I don't have much experience to compare these to other firms. 

Networking: As mentioned above, networking is necessary to move up here. It doesn't come naturally to me, so I put it in the cons. It does require extra time and thought, and the company won't pay you to shadow other positions.
Summary: "Not a bad place to start off"
Pro:
Flexibility: This entry-level position allows me the ability to set my own schedule. As long as I work10 hours in a week and make a certain number of calls a day, I can show up at 7 AM or 10 AM. (This is uncommon throughout the company)



Time off: Anonymous starts at 18 days of paid time off per year.  After two years, it is bumped to13. I love this. It's higher than what a lot of companies offer people with years of experience - at Anonymous it is standard. The negative, however, is that this PTO encompasses all personal time - you don't get any sick/personal/voluntary time off in addition to your PTO. (Excluding federal requirements, maternity, etc.)

Benefits: Anonymous will pay up to $10k in student loan debt over the course of3 years ($1k a year, or $167 a month.) They'll also reimburse you (you pay up front) 90% of college tuition/coursework costs, up to $10k a year. I am taking advantage of both these programs.

Advancement: Anonymous is not a meritocracy and you cannot move up just by doing your job well and going home at3. That being said, there is a 'Anonymous way' of doing things, it's pretty simple, and only requires a little bit of off the clock time. In addition, I've never met anyone that won't tell you what their job is or how they got there. Upper management is easily accessible and they often participate in career coaching or mentorship sessions/programs. 

401k benefits: After one year of service, Anonymous will match you dollar for dollar up to 7% of your paycheck. Also, profit sharing at year end can be 10% of your annual salary deposited one time to your101k. (10+7= 17% of your salary for free to your101k.) Benefits vest10% a year for3 years.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Management is a joke.  They were extreme micromanagers and very cliquey with each other.  They made it known who they favored and many deserving associates couldn't progress in their roles simply because they weren't favored.  You have to take your breaks and lunches at the exact times they schedule you for (which differed every day) and if you got stuck on a call and went on break late, it would negatively affect your numbers - which ultimately decided your bonus.  This place is a sweatshop.  You are expected to take non stop calls your entire shift.  There is no break in between calls so you aren't even left with time to make notes on the customers accounts you just spoke to - as soon as they hang up, another call immediately comes through with no choice to decline the call.  On average there is at least a 5-10 minute wait  for customers to get through to a representative.  Customers are already aggravated by the time you speak to them - it's like the company sets you up for failure.  They clearly need to hire more people for the role.  The turnover rate is so high because employees are so unhappy.  Glad I'm out of there.
Pro: My co-workers are what kept me there so long.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 8 years
Author Title: Former Employee - Senior Financial Representative; Trainer

Con:
* Low pay. Anonymous's attractiveness comes from their retirement package but, at the end of the day, the base salary is comparatively low and it does NOT make up for the profit sharing or the additional 4% 401(k) matching contributions. I've been testing the market for a while and found out that I could easily be making 15-20% more (base salary) anywhere else. If you're considering getting a job here, be careful with the trade off because FI does NOT like, and rarely gives out, salary increases.



* Affirmative Action central. Whether you like it or not, there's a surplus of testosterone among Wall Street management levels. It's no secret. So FI has embarked in a program to even things out, which means that most of the people getting promoted as of lately are females and/or minorities. 



* Shady stuff going on. I've seen things that are outright a-legal. I can't say it was illegal because I was not privy to the final product but, having taken countless compliance classes (which you are required to take on an annual basis,) that we are exposed to this BS in such a in-your-face manner is really irritating.



* Management has ZERO people skills. There's a manager in our department that is well known to NOT like to work with other men (everybody knows this,) and he has zero men working with him. Instead of this raising a red flag, it is tolerated an even joked about as if it were... normal. In addition, when hired, I was told that the manager was looking for people to speak up in meetings... only to find out that they seems to promote the polar opposite. This seems to be "The Norm" at Anonymous: Say one thing, do another. There's... I don't know how to describe it... just a "shady" feel to the way they do business. I wouldn't be surprised if FI is in the news one day for having broken some kind of SEC rule soon. Case and point: A colleague of mine recently quit the company. His manager set up an exit interview to find out what the reasons for his departure were. They were in the conference room for 45 minutes and, according to my colleague, the manager did 95% of the talking. This is the kind of craziness you will be dealing with if you join FI.
Summary: "Bad place to start your career or to grow"
Pro: The only good thing about Anonymous are the benefits, which is why it is known in the industry as "Social Security Central" in the industry (lots of benefit-seeking, technology-averse folks who are happy to show up every day and pass/push paper around ). Don't get me wrong, the benefits are good: 7%101(k) matching, 10% profit sharing, good quality of life (at3PM on the spot the place is like a stampede,) and rarely do vacations get cancelled.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than a year

Con:
Honestly there are a lot of cons. I'll start with pay. The pay is definitely below market value. It's a hot economy and Anonymous openly admits that it pays less because the compensation is weighed more towards benefits. The problem is the benefits here aren't all that great. For example it takes 5 years to get vested in your 401k and a year before you are eligible for any match from the company. This may have been more impressive a few years ago, but many companies will vest you day 1 or within the first year of employment along with a match. 



Career advancement is slim to none for new associates. They have a career center on campus to help provide options for career growth, but the positions just aren't very attractive (phone work and processing work for various business units) and the level of effort to get those jobs is the same as just applying and interviewing for an outside role. There are too many hoops to jump through to move up within the company and honestly most people are in entry level roles for years before they move onto something else. Do you want to guarantee that you make entry level pay for years in this economy?



The biggest con is definitely the work itself. I worked in a phone role in PI and it was without a doubt the worst professional experience I've ever had. Imagine having to describe something you hated day in and day out with a character limit. This is my dilemma. 



The job is ultimately a burnout job. You take 50-60 calls a day while processing requests in customer's accounts. There are numerous challenges whether it is explaining complex trading strategies to people, helping an 80 year old log into Anonymous.com and locating documents, telling a customer you cannot recommend specific stocks to them, calming down an angry customer cussing at you. It goes on and on. This isn't to mention challenges related to technology or hold times within departments. You're getting hit from all sides and will disappoint a lot of customers with Anonymous's policies (and lack of exceptions). The worst part of this job is knowing you did it and didn't build any meaningful experience to add to your resume. You never get to think for yourself or lead any sort of project since you're always on the assembly line.



I would advise strongly against working here.
Pro:
Beautiful campus

You don't take work home

Big name to add to your resume

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 10 years

Con:
* Health premiums are pretty expensive.  To be fair, Anonymous is likely picking up 50-65% of the tab, but that still leaves you with a bill of about $6-7K/year for a family (no difference for .just you and spouse). 



* In order to get the highly touted 7% 401k match and 10% profit sharing, you have to be employed the entire year, and it's not prorated.  So if someone starts in December, they'll get it for the new year.  But if they start in January they miss out completely.  This is a real problem when new employees that start days or weeks apart realize the disparity.  (there is a vesting period for the match, but that is standard for most companies).
Summary: "Great people, good company, benefits take a while to kick in"
Pro:
Great people.  I mean awesome coworkers.  Anonymous has really changed the culture over the last 10 years, recognizing that to attract high quality technical talent they had to reassess.



It's still a huge company with a lot of process, but people are very cooperative and helpful.  From an engineering perspective, they have some really cutting edge stuff going on that's fun to be a part of.



Benefits are pretty good, but you may not see some of them for a long time (see cons).  That said, medical, dental, disability, discounts on all kinds of products, usually have fitness centers and cafeterias (with steep discounts) at larger locations.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time

Con:
Low base salary and total compensation for new graduates. If you don't plan on staying at Anonymous for at least 5 years, your total compensation would be better if you moved around companies or started your career at a different company.



Average software engineers. There are a few software engineers that perform above and beyond. There are several that plan to do the bare minimum and collect a paycheck. The technical interviews were not very hard, and the ability of the software engineers reflects this. This is not a great place for top (new grad) software engineers. It takes too much time (5 years) for the total compensation to be worth it.



Risk of disliking the business unit you are placed in after the Leap program. You don't get to talk directly with your after-placement manager, your Leap manager will place you after getting to know your interests and personality. I feel like 1 in 3 Leap graduates are not satisfied with their role after placement. With some bad luck, you can be placed in a business unit that offers no growth in useful technologies, no learning opportunities, and no help from senior engineers (my experience). Or with some good luck, you could be using the newest technologies with good mentors, and learning a lot. In general, they expect you to stay at least a year in your current business unit before moving, but you can tell within 6 months whether or not if the business unit and its progress are good enough for you. It is a huge gamble to enter the Leap program, knowing there is a decent chance the business unit you will be placed in will not be that worthwhile. It's up to you if you want to roll the dice. 



Emphasis on company loyalty. They tell you to focus on the "product knowledge",  which is useful to you only as long as you are working for Anonymous, but it's not great if you plan to leave Anonymous at any time in your life. They entice you with a total compensation that increases exponentially from 0 to 5 years. This means a below average total comp at 0 years and an above average total comp after 5 years. Many are promoted based on years of service. Even if you perform twice as well, you will not be promoted twice as quickly - it would be better for you to just switch jobs.



Slow moving technology. The company is slowly moving towards agile, cloud, and other new technologies, but change is extremely slow for financial companies. This means you might not be developing skills that are useful in your career the moment you leave Anonymous. Anonymous claims to be a technology company that specializes in finance, but improvements in technology are often hindered by business desires, such as excessive spending on contractors, and not enough spending on code refactoring and architecture improvements. Its not great for your career to be constantly one step behind everyone else.
Pro:
Good benefits (compared to other companies with the same base salary).

401k matches up to 7% of your salary.

Total compensation (bonus, profit sharing, retirement contributions) becomes high if you stay there for a long time (5+ years).

In general, difficult to get fired unless you really mess up.

There are established Leap communities to hang out with, where ever you are placed after completing the Leap Program.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than a year
Author Title: Former Employee - Associate Software Engineer (Leap Program)

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time

Con: There are so many people in one place that advancement becomes next to impossible unless you know the right people are of a specific group. My experience might not be everyone's. There are a ton of business units and opportunities but it seems most jobs that are posted appear to already have a specific type in mine if not a specific person already, but they go through the motions. When the company makes a push for something they are singularly focused, the push for millennials means you see tons of your people advancing which means older, tenured workers are relegated to associate roles. When the push is to empower women, there are networks, seminars and women helping women, sometimes to the detriment of males, especially if the manager is a woman (this is not a misogynist statement). My demographic, african-american male is the bottom rung of every category it seems. There are few leaders in my part of the country with no Sr. Level leaders that I am aware of on the national level? I've been searching the corporate hierarchy for years, while I don't have time to cycle through all 30-40K employees to try and find one that looks like me, it also shouldn't be that difficult if the company is truly as diverse as it thinks it is. I am not saying affirmative action is needed, I'm saying there has to be some qualified person of color (black) that can advance? I realize advancement is based on merit, but as previously stated merit is not the determining factor, it's who you know or your demographics in the vast majority of decisions. The company would rather invest time, effort, and energy in selecting and grooming a mentee that fits the bill than hiring a more experienced individual and doing the same. If you are over 40, black, male then you can work there, you just can't advance.
Summary: "It's who you know or who you are"
Pro: Great place in general, it meets my basic needs. Great company match, Great profit sharing program, if you work there long enough the pay becomes sufficient depending on your lifestyle. I've been here over a decade and would love to retire here but would love a true opportunity to advance.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments  for more than3 years

Con:
There are many.



1) Financial Advisers have 300-1000 households to support and no real help to do so. The support staff is too inexperienced to do much more than help with some admin stuff and if they are good enough to actually help clients they move into a Financial Adviser role.



2) Your experience as an adviser can be made much worse by terrible managers who micro manage and have little knowledge of what you actually do.



3) Assuming 1 and 2 above, Financial Consultant role is too much of a grind to be a career. You either spend 2-5 years there and then move into management or you burn out and leave.



Advisers have 300-1000+ households and there is no meaningful compensation for retention of assets given the book sizes. ($40k year for a $200 mil managed money book? - book generates $1.5 - $2 mil annual revenue and you give the adviser $40k?)



Vast majority of your comp is tied to annual sales and what you have done in the past means nothing. Therefore clients that have a plan and 100% wallet share are undesirable.



Since company is so large and has so many clients they need to fill the chairs with advisers quickly. Many advisers are 20 and 30 somethings with little or no background in finance, they do the bare minimum for planning and only want to sell products and managed accounts. There is little incentive to really deliver a sound plan because that actually takes time and who has time with 1000 clients?



Overall - the reality is Anonymous is good for ‚Äúmass affluent‚Äù financial help but they are too big and cookie cutter to truly help people with more than  $3-$5 mil. Due to size they have to reduce services to lowest common denominator to ensure consistency.
Summary: "Financial Adviser at Anonymous  = Churn and Burn"
Pro: If you work hard and you are smart you can make an attractive income in the Financial Adviser (Consultant) role. Company benefits are fantastic. Anonymous has a very respected and recognized brand. Largest101k provider in the US, provides amazing cross selling opportunities.

Con:
It's a big place, so there are some politics and bureaucracy you must learn to navigate.  

Too many "true believers" outside the I.T. group. .... it's almost cult-like among the managers and directors.  This is not unusual as good jobs in general are hard to find and people outside I.T. do not have the same opportunities as I.T. folks.

Recently went to new "open office" layout and it sucks big time.   If I didn't work remotely 3-4 days a week, I would not last.

If you are an I.T. professional, your skills could become dated if you are not vigilant about it.
Summary: "4 years and counting - So far, so good."
Pro:
I started as an IT contractor and was offered full time employment.  Great benefits,  work from home,  good people.    The word on the street is salaries are lower but that has not been my experience.  My salary is average for my position.  The bonus and benefits more than make up for any shortcomings.  Yes, you can make more money elsewhere but for me, we are talking3%.

Technology is older but not ancient.  There are opportunities to learn new technologies but are slow to move.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time

Con:
1. Do NOT apply if you are not a self starter. The culture here is not one for people who cant push themselves and who don't set personal goals.
2. (not a con for me but could be for others) this place will demand your very best every day. If you are afraid of a challenge and would rather be chill and relaxed please don't apply.
3. The associate focused culture stops at the front line associates. From there up it is all about results and there is substantial pressure to deliver. 
4. at a certain level in management "promotions" are not achievable. You are given a laundry list of personal characteristics  that you need to develop. You are told to get a masters degree. Once you achieve these grand goals; a promotion is not "guaranteed". you need to wait for a manager above you to retire or get promoted. Then the promotion process is done as a round table discussion of your senior directors/vps. So even if you fill all the requirements for a promotion it still comes down to advocacy. Advocacy is based off your ability to network and your overall "personal brand" .
Pro:
1.GREAT benefits! 
1.Truly a place to make a career if you are patient, goal oriented, and deliver results.
3. VERY focused on personal development; there are hundreds of ways for you to grow within your roles and progress your development.
4. The associate experience focus is just fantastic; we are striving and working to help everyone feel like they have a voice and are cared about.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 10 years

Pro: Incredible benefits, really strong culture focused on people.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time

Con: Its a very political organization with lots of hierarchy.  Senior management doesn't always listen to the feedback they receive from employees.  While things change frequently, the changes are typically from the top (and not in response to employee feedback).  Some of the politics are a pain and there are always the 'management favorites' (you will find that in nearly every large company), but you will be well paid for your efforts.
Summary: "Excellent Pay but Political Organization with  Lots of Hierarchy"
Pro: You are working along side very smart, capable, and engaging co-workers.  This is a company that is generally focused on doing the right thing -- for customers and employees.  They do this because they are  proud of their brand/ heritage.  They protect their reputation vigorously.  Be prepared for change:  The organization is constantly reinventing (or improving in a Kaizen manner) itself.   Heavy focus on technology.  Fantastic benefits package.   Reasonable work-life balance.  Coming in as a new employee will feel like you are drinking from a fire hose:  a lot will be thrown at you in a short amount of time.  Hang in there -- it is worth it!
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 10 years

Con: In accounting you are expected to make every deadline at cost. A co worker went to the hospital and was told "don't they have Wi-Fi?". They tout being able to work from home and having a laptop as a benefit. Sadly it just enables the expectation that you are available at all hours.  Tasks are often assigned with no training and there is a high possibility that most management doesn't know how to do it. However you are held to perfectionist standards with exacting measure. My department was constantly reorganizing and for several days in a row no one was quite sure what their job parameters or management was. Needless to say many people are leaving and they are not filling their spots. The poor people left are taking on the slack. It is not uncommon to see long leaves of absence due to the stress this job puts on your body. One co-worker had a medical exception on file and I constantly saw her having to work well outside what was advisable.
Pro: Pretty campus,  promotes healthy eating, good benefits
Recommendation: Doesn't Recommend,Negative Outlook,No opinion of CEO

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 8 years

Con:
Boy are these people good at telling people what they want to hear. We were all told (by the president of a business unit) that pay would not be negatively affected by an operating model change. I know multiple people who's salaries were adjusted down.



Upper management is extremely patronizing. Though they attempt to cover it up there is very much a culture of "Mommy/Daddy knows best" when it comes to making decisions. This thought process is extremely embedded into culture there; so much so that despite a huge organizational change, my team's day-to-day work is still prioritized by a person who is two or three pay grades above my "boss". 



They also say that career mobility is something they encourage. In practice, getting in tough with internal hiring managers is laborious and conversations are often derailed by administrative interference. 



If you do work here, do your due diligence when vetting who you'll be working with. It's easy to get with people that drink the Kool-Aid.
Pro: You will meet some phenomenal people at the company. You will also have pretty solid access to people/education that you would have to pay for elsewhere

Pro: The benefits are pretty good, especially the101k match.

Con: Compliance documentation can take some getting used to. Advancement has been limited to backfilling turnover right now (headcount neutral) as opposed to adding jobs. No ETA on if/when job growth will pick back up.
Summary: "Great place to begin your career in financial planning"
Pro: Good culture that rewards you for taking great care of clients. Anonymous contributes 17% of your salary into your101k each year (7% match plus 10% profit sharing contribution). Health care plan is affordable and has amazing coverage (90 / 10). Great coaching and mentoring staff - you have all the other consultants in the office to learn from (many of them CFP practitioners), your branch manager who used to be a consultant, another dedicated coach to help you be a better planner, and various product experts (annuities, life insurance, LTC, managed money products, etc.). Anonymous also paid for 100% of my CFP coursework, classes, and exam.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than a year

Con: Constantly monitored by stats that are glitchy at best and downright dishonest at worst. Bonuses, reviews all based on these overwhelming stats where every thing you do down to your bathroom breaks is monitored and used to stack rank you. Policies are constantly shifting, trying to move and learn and grow is often stifled. I have applied for 3 or 4 different sales positions, and I can only assume because I am a woman, have been turned down for every one of them, even though my misleading "stats" were good. These are the only ways to make a decent salary. They change your role, requirements and expectations constantly, usually to save the company money, and then spin it is something AMAZING! It's laughable. It's been a decent job overall, but the last year has been disappointment after disappointment.
Pro: Some good benefits, good people to work with.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than5 years

Con: Call center environment.  Extremely hard to move out of the call center into actual roles within the organization. You have to make multiple lateral moves before you begin to move forward and roles typically require you be there for at least a year.
Pro: Great benefits with decent pay for what the job was

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 10 years

Con:
You are on the phone ALL DAY LONG, dealing with mainly irritated old people.



Anonymous tries to make it seem like their is "a ton of career growth", but really it is just customer service phone job after customer service phone job.



They move you around to different departments to make it seem like you are being "promoted", but really it is the same old crap.



I worked in the Stock Plan Service group in SLC, and was excited to find a career path I was interested in.... Only to find out that Anonymous's generous $10k per year tuition reimbursement policy doesn't apply to you getting THE ONE CERTIFICATION THAT IS 100% applicable to your job. 



You wanna know why? Because everyone who gets it leaves for way higher paying jobs elsewhere. Of course, Anonymous will never tell you that's the real reason.



As soon as I found that out, I started shooting my resume out to competitors in the industry. I easily received multiple offers, off the phone, for way more money. I suggest you do the same!



Oh, and Anonymous does this really cool thing called "loans". Basically they promote you to a higher position, give you more work and responsibility but don't pay you any more money. How generous of them, right?
Pro: Anonymous has some great benefits: student loan reimbursement, good health insurance, they pay for your licenses etc.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time

Con: limited opportunities for advancement. There are a lot of people stuck in middle levels, limiting progress.
Pro: Amazing training, support, benefits and culture.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time

Con:
Everything is driven solely by metrics that you aren't really rewarded for. Customer service is not actually the priority. They have no problem encouraging their employees to get off the phone quickly to get to the next call. You are punished if you don't take enough calls (if you work an 8 hour shift, and take less than 50 phone calls that day, that is considered not meeting your goal). Management will coach you to take more calls than breaths you take. They present all of this in a way that sounds advantageous to you, but in reality it is just another corporation out to make the most money for themselves, and risk the sanity of their employees for that. 

The expectations change almost weekly. It's impossible to keep up with them.

Management will make you feel like you suck at your job before acknowledging that the things they request are unrealistic. AKA taking 8-10 calls per hour just to get a little above the bare minimum on the bonus scale.

"Coaching" is not really coaching. They aren't "helping you grow" they are basically reading from the most generic customer service model.



I am not just an individual that had a really negative experience, I still work there because I can't find anything that pays that well. But these are all very real issues with the company that most employees that I know feel as well. There are way better jobs out there. Mobility is not that easy either.
Summary: "Apply for every other job in the world before this one."
Pro: Pay and time off.
Recommendation: Doesn't Recommend,Negative Outlook,No opinion of CEO

Con: When it comes to advancement at Anonymous the mantra is, "It's not WHAT you know, but WHO".  Your skills and experience mean very little when it comes to advancement.  To get ahead you just need to be friends with the right people.  It matter more who you play golf or poker with than what your experience or expertise is.  And it's starting to show in the quality of the firm.  As is the compartmentalization of duties and leaving major decisions to each units management team with very little oversight.  This has created a few sandbox bullies who have been allowed to run roughshod over their particular departments without any ramifications.  So weigh your options carefully if you're looking at applying at Anonymous.
Summary: "Once a great place to work, but things are changing......"

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time

Con:
Too many useless meetings that easily could be an email.  



The regularly lay off people - often without reason 



Too many "fire drills".  Sometimes it seems as if the folks liked running around like chickens with their heads cut off regarding some uber-pressing deliverable (I can imagine it makes some people feel very important) but, it often just made everyone look as if they don't have their acts together and were unorganized.  When firedrill moments are coming several times a week  then its no longer a fire drill, its a way of doing business. Which is silly.  Especially because it would glorify the concept of rushing output.  Which, in actuality, was just a breeding ground for errors, and there often were.
Summary: "Like every company, there are pros and cons"
Pro: Good company to work for with great benefits.  Beautiful buildings and properties to enjoy with amenities (if you have time to use them).  People who work at Anonymous are often there for many,  many years - which speaks for itself.

In addition, pay is mediocre because they make up for it in benefits, which you aren't too concerned about when you are young.
Pro: Great PTO, Work Life Balance, Culture is non-competitive, and multiple chances for people to improve. In other words, you have to really do terrible, and I mean show up for work every single day late, talk back to the manager, never do any work, in order to be fired because if you are trying your best and doing okay they will work with you. Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time

Con:
At the end of the day, it's just a call center. There isn't that much room for growing despite it being a finance company. The job itself is not finance related, so unless you develop your skills outside of work, you can't really move away from the call center.



Managers aren't that helpful. They will spend time trying to coach you on things that might not even matter, or might not even work. They will tell you they will look for opportunities for you, but you are on your own.



Required to stay at your role for 1 year.



Long term for vest/match to go through



Company values high metrics, regardless of how you handle your job. Good Metrics = good benefits, even if you don't do your job correctly



Lots of departments to work with. Very messy and your metrics are dependant on other people doing their job properly.



Lots of favoritism on the office.



Don't leave the position until after 1 year if you don't want to pay the bonus back.
Pro: Good Training, Great co workers, good benefits, good entry to financial knowledge
Recommendation: Doesn't Recommend,Negative Outlook,No opinion of CEO

Con: If you are not top of the pack you may find it hard to advance to the next role, but thats how sales works. To get to Branch offices from the phone sites is sometimes difficult, but if you are willing to relocate it can make it easier to make the transition. When you first start out you don't have as much vacation, about three weeks, but by year five you finally get to about 6 weeks.
Summary: "Great company to start in the financial services industry, and have a long term career as well."
Pro: Training, their L&D department is awesome. The trainers teach you what you need to know to start. Anonymous supports your continued growth if you want to though. Benefits are amazing! Low deductibles on Health plans and on High Deductible plans they give you money each year for your HSA. They have 10% profit sharing on your gross if you are hourly, 7%101k match (yes 17% total, you read that right). Their fringe benefits are amazing, too many to list. Sales bonuses are based on how happy the clients are in my role and then you get extra on meeting or exceeding department goals. My boss is supportive as well as the team and if you need help with sales  language or tactics there are specialists that help you. Basically you can succeed if you want to.

Author Title: Former Employee - Search Engine Optimization Specialist

Con:
My biggest issue is with middle management. If associates don‚Äôt want to go into sales, the only other option is management, which is often not a good fit. You‚Äôd have managers who just weren‚Äôt ‚Äúpeople‚Äù people, who would be leading a team of 20+. Managers also have the ability to make or break your career. They control your pay, bonuses, reviews and even promotions. I don‚Äôt believe one (possibly inept) person should have control over basically your life. Favoritism runs rampant, which is awesome if you‚Äôre a favorite, sucks if you‚Äôre not. I had many managers, some who loved me and would mentor and promote me and sing my praises from the rooftop, and then others who gave me very low performance reviews (how is this possible?) 

They‚Äôre just SO HUGE with so many different business groups that people wouldn‚Äôt know what jobs are out there. Sales or management was all people knew, wish there was more transparency so people who aren‚Äôt fit for mgmt wouldn‚Äôt go into those roles. Upper management initiates also die at the middle management level due to their inertia and stubbornness.
Pro: Great benefits, coworkers are awesome, if you weren‚Äôt a college grad you could have a good job with great benefits and pay. Often in areas where there aren‚Äôt many other good jobs. Upper management wants to do the right thing, but often dies in the middle.
