Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time

Con: There are really great organizations within Anonymous, but there are also some organizations that are horrible.  Where I worked before I left they had no management skills.  EVPs would have a tantrum at meetings - yelling at the attendees.  They nitpicked everything, and never showed any appreciation when you completed a project.  Other cons include the fact that you have to have all your investments at Anonymous or jump through hoops for compliance.  You also cannot mention that you work for Anonymous on social media.  You have to have all your political contributions and volunteering activities preapproved.  I guess that's standard for financial services, but it's still a con as far as working environment.  It's hard to know where they are going with the Merrimack site.  They keep moving the technology jobs to North Carolina.
Pro: Great compensation, very good benefits.  The company is privately owned, so you are not constantly worried about the vicissitudes of the shareholders and whether it's an up or down quarter.  Don't get me wrong, they very much care about making money, but it's not the same grind as a public company.  Their eyes are focused on the customer as the one to please, not the shareholders.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments  for more than3 years

Con:
Not a good place for people who are implied leaders. It's a very top-down culture. You have no budget even as a VP, no freedom to push outside the "Anonymous way". Most people have been here for the last 20 years and it shows how out of touch these leaders are with how workforce of today looks at leadership and work in general. Long tenured middle managers and individual contributors also show a strange indentured servitude behavior. Many don't have the spine to say the truth, stand up for their beliefs and do the right thing. The culture is to sugar coat bad news and push all decision making as far up as possible. 



This might be fine if you come from a top-down, command and control culture. If you have worked in a culture of empowerment, this will be a stifling place. 



The company is headed towards uncharted territory but people up top lack the will to get rid of the "leadership" crud that only knows status-quo and actively tries to stonewall new ideas. A vast majority started their careers in phone sales - so they are not equipped for todays and tomorrows world. It will be an extremely hard task to correct the current heading of this ship. Drastic measures are needed to clean house but I doubt it will happen. I am waiting to see what happens in the next year.



Again, if you are a young, go-getter this might not be a place for you.  If you want to build a career that enables you to work in another company later, don't count on developing yourself as a leader here. If you want to be told what to do and just want to spend a few more years until retirement, this place is great and has excellent benefits.
Summary: "Depends where you are in your life"
Pro: Good benefits. Co-workers are nice. Work is super easy and doesn't take much time if you are smart. Great for coasting into retirement.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 10 years

Con:
Their Portfolio Advisory Service (PAS) is the key product along with annuities that you are pressed to sell. They train you really well on how to overcome the objections of Clients. You get paid 0.07% or 7 basis points for every dollar you put into these products - JUST ONE TIME - there is a tiny bonus based on Retention. The worst part is that every one in the Financial Consultant role knows the product is terrible and underperforms consistently by 1.5%-2.2% on a yearly basis. If you work here, prepare to exchange your conscious for your paycheck. 



Management will talk trash about you after you leave, there is no loyalty. You will work with 400 Clients, the best Financial Consultants don't develop deep relationships with Clients because you don't have the capacity to do that because you must sell about $36 million a year at a minimum in their garbage products.
Pro: As mentioned, great benefits. 7% match and 10% profit sharing. If you do 7% your going to be putting away14% of your total pay into retirement which is great.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Must move all funds from outside sources to fidelity managed accounts.

While legal, I feel it is immoral to have a lack of transparency wrt. published prospectuses

Can only apply for lateral moves within the company

Promotions are difficult to get, must be in job for 3yrs. before being considered for promo

No eye care insurance

Pay is less than average
Pro: It is just a job

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Anonymous chips away at your soul. By far the worst culture in any place I've worked, and sadly its improved from it was when I started.   Know multiple people that currently work and have worked there that don't like there job, but sometimes stay because handcuffed by the money they make, me being part of that group for awhile. 



-Expected to work lots of OT in sales jobs.

-Lower Pay than comparable jobs.

-Very tedious and repetitive for most phone sales positions.

-Manager half the time doesn't even know your role so that can't help or teach you other than to tell you to work harder, more OT, or give suggestions that have no tangible merit behind them. Part of that is because of the change that happens so often and never gives groups stability within the company.

-Worked there for six years and only ever knew the people directly around me.  Its ironic as you talk to people all day yet you don't get to know anyone at the job unless your in a higher up positions where you have more leeway to be off the phone for a few minutes.

-Entry job is into service group is awful, super strict on when you can go to lunch, break.  Basically no flexibility.

-Each move up the ladder did get slightly better but its not a good thing when you have to get 4 or 5 promotions before you say to yourself this job is alright.
Summary: "Look Elsewhere if you want to Enjoy Your Job"
Pro: Perks at Anonymous is 10% profit sharing, 7% match, lots of positions and places to go within the company so you think you would be able to find something that you like, best thing was learning about investments for my own personal use moving forward though...
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Almost all the jobs in Utah are call center jobs. By their nature, they're like having your soul sucked out of your nose on a daily basis. I love this company, but if this is the kind of jobs they're offering here I'll never go back.
Pro: Anonymous is a great company with good benefits and strong ethics. Compared to friends who worked at other financial services firms, I never felt pressured to do anything unethical or against the best interests of the customer.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time
Author Title: Former Employee - Financial Services Associate II

Con:
Anonymous caters to new hires. They are like comcast: Throw the world at you if you are a new employee, but the people that have worked here and put their time in, and actually contribute to the company are rewarded with the opportunity to do more work.

 Every benefit is designed to get people in the door.  New hires got a  12% bump in pay, plus a signing bonus of $2500.   I have worked here for almost 10 years and I get to do my job, the help desks job, and the new hires job, and don't get so much as a thank you. Too much middle management that has no idea what goes on on the phones.   Work is not challenging.  Roles are not defined. Who does what... No one knows.  

Meet your sales number? Here's a Snickers bar.

Pay is low.  

I'm sure that there are some people that enjoy their work, but in the Active Trader  group, the morale is low, attitudes are awful, and suggestions are ignored.

Work site is in a horrible location- every time you go outside, you are accosted by homeless people for money.  Building is not owned by company.
Pro: Vacation,101k match, insurance, Licensing

Pro: Good benefits, work hours and reputation.

Con: They have everyone at each others necks now for survival.  What use to be an environment of constant improvement and making things better for investors is now an every man for himself environment with everyone worried about saving their own skin.  It is tragic what has happened to the once premiere investment firm to work for in New England.
Summary: "This USE to be the Best Place to Work.  Now, not so much"

Con: If you choose to work in one of the call centers, as a phone-based representative, make no mistake your entire day will be spent on the phone, and that your metrics and performance will be very closely scrutinized. Be aware that, despite what you're told in training, you're there to get through as many calls as you can. Bonuses, which can be generous, and advancement, which can happen quickly and be very rewarding, will both be based on your metrics. Non-phone positions are non-existent in some locations, so be sure and investigate your location fully before committing, especially if you're worried about burnout.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than3 years

Con:
The best things about Anonymous are also the worst things about Anonymous. 



1 ~ If you end up in the wrong department with the wrong boss your life can be a living hell. Anonymous is very liberal in its HR policies which can be good but also means they let things fester for a long time before taking action. There is a percentage of people that will take advantage of this and especially if you are on a small team you may end up constantly covering for a weak link.



2 ~ It is an American dream to start in the mail room and work your way up to VP someday and that is totally possible at Anonymous. In fact, it may be a bit too easy. It is completely common to attend leadership meetings and hear from senior executives "I started on the phones just like you!"  Well, that is fine once in a while but at some point you do want people leading you to actually have some training and experience. Anonymous is full of hundreds maybe thousands of Directors, VP's and SVP's that started on the phone "just like you" and it shows.



3 ~ Anonymous has managed to stay out of the news but there are plenty of unsavory things they do behind the scenes. They are currently very worried about the Department of Labor proposed Fiduciary Rule. Their current employer benefits business model is already unethical but if the rule is enacted will be illegal as well. It has long been a major IRA rollover sales lead source to take advantage of relationships with employers to gain access to employees. Anonymous is the world's largest 401k record-keeper and should this lead source be taken away it will be a huge hit to their personal investing sales model in which two thirds of the new assets are from internal rollovers. The Anonymous brokerage business would be nowhere near what it is today without having taken advantage of these workplace business relationships.
Summary: "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly"
Pro:
1 ~ Many would tell you the best thing about Anonymous is the people you work with and I agree. I have made several life-long friends and look forward to seeing them every day. Asking around you will find many people also found their significant others at work as well.



1 ~ Upward mobility and job opportunities. I may be biased from working at the Westlake campus where there are over 6000 jobs but it is also relatively easy to move to other locations within the company. There was a time years ago when it might have felt like you had to go to Boston to move up in the company but those days are gone and there are many great leadership positions throughout the country.



3 ~ Brand recognition you can be proud of and sleep well at night. Anonymous is a discount broker so not ripping people off with high loads or fees. They did not get caught up in the mischief so many other firms did with the mutual fund scandals or financial crisis.

Con:
No loyalty 

In the 12 years i worked here i was NEVER once asked whether or not my manager was doing a good job.  There is really no tangible process for promotion, pay increases, bonuses.  If your manager likes you and you have a decent relationship then you get raises & bonuses.   I have never seen so many mgmt people afraid of conflict, afraid to tell employees they were not performing, etc.  The culture is one of fear to tell the truth, when people are asked they do not tell the truth because they fear retaliation.   I personally sat in a senior mgmt meeting and heard a Sr. VP, tell another manager to tell her minions to stop sending feedback to Sr. Mgmt, they may ask for it but dont really want to hear it.  When they downsized a few yrs back they laidoff some of the best most knowledgeable talent, i suspect bcuz they made the most money, but many left were clueless which meant that those remaining had to do twice as much and cover the clueless.   When employees are having heart attacks in their cubicles something is very wrong
Pro: Once a really great company, good benefits, some places have onsite Gym, cafeteria selections fit full range of food choices, if you are motivated you can take training classes

Con: The role just sucks, especially if you work nights because they never hire enough people to work late nights so people can wait up to 10 minutes just for a password reset! It's a call center so it's constantly taking call after call and people can be too needy or hostile because they can't treat their retirement account like an ATM. You have to be in the role for at least a year to even be considered for other roles though it will just be another job on the phone all day. Also your calls are graded all the time and depending on your manager... it's a miracle if you do anything right on a call. Some people call in to get a balance and just because you didn't get the persons life story doesn't mean the call was "inconsistent". Metrics are so whack.
Pro: I love my coworkers, they are truly nice people to work with. Anonymous has excellent benefits - medical, dental,101k with 7% percent match (though you have to be there a year to get match and work3 years to be vested), quarterly bonuses on performance and profit sharing. I truly love Anonymous and what they stand for. I just hate the role I'm in.

Con: While the salaries are competitive at the beginning the raises are almost none existent. And, to get a promotion is even more difficult. If your looking for somewhere to grow quickly then Anonymous isn't the place for you unless your lucky. Also, there is a lot of politics involved in this company. You will see coworkers move past you that are terrible at their jobs (borderline clueless as to what is going on), but network very well and talk to the right people. This can be very discouraging to those who actually try and work hard. Because, at the end of the day your picking up their slack and they're reaping the benefits.
Pro: Anonymous Investments is a great place to start your career. I started right out of college1 years ago and the starting salaries are competitive. Plus, you get amazing benefits such as dollar for dollar match on101K up to 7%. In addition they give you 10% of your salary for profit sharing at the end of the year. I have worked with a lot of very intelligent people that challenge me everyday to make me better. I enjoy the challenge because if we aren't helping each other improve and to learn new things a job can get stale very quickly.

Con: The usual large company drawback's apply.  If you're looking to work on the most cutting edge technology or explore ways to disrupt industries, maybe it isn't the best place to work.  Although Anonymous focuses on innovation strategies and new markets, it's size means that change does not come quickly, for the most part, as there are many processes and controls wrapped around existing models. There are also significant regulations to which all players in the financial services industry must adhere, which is fine, but learning and adhering to those regulations limits flexibility.
Pro: Anonymous Investments is one of the top company's in the financial industry.  The firm's focus on workplace atmosphere, collaboration, career growth, benefits, and work-life balance make one of the most rewarding and enjoyable employer's.  Anonymous also regularly hires third party company's to conduct employee surveys, and that feedback is taken very seriously.  I say this because I've seen senior management respond to areas of improvement with meaningful and relevant changes that enhance the working lives of Anonymous's associates.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 8 years

Con: If you're contract through Veritude you pretty much don't matter. No vacation time. Benefits suck. Your contact may get extended and often times you're left in the dark.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time

Con: On the surface the Financial Consultant position seems great. They give you a book of clients, there's no cold calling since they provide leads and you can make over 6 figures with average effort. But in reality it's a pure sales role with very little concern about what's right for the client. Definitely not a fiduciary advisor and the turnover is extremely high.  It's all about selling product and filling the buckets. Anonymous FCs are managed by the ever present spreadsheet. Everyone is stacked ranked and if you are below average on any category your branch manager or RPC ( who are usually inexperienced coaches that stink at sales) will come talk to you to see how to improve. The problem is there are like over 20 categories of things they measure you on. So you will always be below average in something! Another annoying thing is every click on the computer, every phone call, every email is tracked like big brother ! They also continually roll out some new method or spreadsheet and say this is the way things are going to be so get used to it. 4 months later you never hear about that spread sheet again. There is no adjustment if you are new, if you are in different markets or have a smaller or a more established book. There is a certain level of gamesmanship with the numbers too. Click here it counts, click here it doesn't even if you did the work. Talk to a client for like 30 seconds and tag their deposit and you get credit. Drop this client from your book without the client knowing and you won't get hit with an outflow.   The people who do well in the role game the system the best. All the managers are ok with this and all they care about is selling managed money, annuities and bringing in new assets. Who cares what's right for the clients. That's really the sad part the clients think you are helping but in reality you are just selling what pays you the most basis points and hope they never call you after the sale. My advice is if you get this position plan to work it for 2 years then find something else in Anonymous not in the branch network.
Pro: Excellent benefits.101k had 7% match and 10% profit sharing. Occasionally there is free breakfast and lunches. Room to grow in the company if you are willing to move
Recommendation: Doesn't Recommend,Neutral Outlook,No opinion of CEO

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Anonymous does not practice what it preaches.. You are told when you are hired and during training that customer service and advocating for the customer is the main goal.  That you should "own the call". However as soon as you are on the phones, you are told that once the customer is handed off to what ever dept ,  you should not be involved anymore, that you should not make too many outbound calls to the customers because we are an inbound call center , I do not consider this owning anything.  The procedures and resources are time consuming and cumbersome.  Your computer is prone to freezing when you are in the middle of a call because of all of the resources you have to have up,  and yet you can not say anything about your computer not working properly. 

  Anonymous has compassion as part of it's mission statement , yet most of the procedures could not possibly show less compassion for the customer if they tried.  In short I feel like I was lied to about the position I was hired for.   

   Management shows favoritism as well as cliquishness, and though everyone appears to be friendly it is surface only.  You never know what management expects or what they are in charge of  because it changes constantly.
Pro: The pay and benefits are great for the Albuquerque area, they also offer some amazing perks to inspire you to make choices.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 10 years

Con: A highly political company with unknown employee measurement and hidden scores. As a senior person in my position you get to know the skill set that is important for your job. When you do outstanding work you soon realize that advancement Is not based on merit but who you are aligned with. A company that is interested more in protecting management with an emphasis on the org chart and less about the work itself. Constant internal battles and intentional reorganizations. An internal employee goal program that ignores how you want to grow as an individual instead focusing on how a manager wants you positioned. If you get a good manager that focuses on the work it can be a wonderful place but soon there will be a reorg and and you will find yourself having to pay more attention to the political back channels and less on your passions and skill set. Politics is extended externally as well with profits spent on preventing governmental "regulation" but internally a love of regulating the employee. Highly protectionist from the top on down. This protectionism even extends to internal technology where systems in place are more about what management wants rather than what the employee needs.
Pro: Decent salary. Good benefits. Some coworkers that can share your values about doing big things. A company that prides itself in conservative investing contrasted with technology and first-to-market product and services.

Author Title: Current Employee - High Net Worth Representative

Con:
Customer service representative work and culture is truly toxic, mentally taxing, entirely sedentary, and unsettlingly monitored by management. You are physically chained to your desk by a phone set for nine hours a day, and provided with two 15-minute breaks and one 30-minute break, all of which are timed by the tracking system. 



There's a big sentiment of favoritism that guides promotions, bonuses, and on the flip side - verbal / written warnings. You don't need to be able to think in order to excel in this role, you just need to be able to follow chain of command and avoid questioning anything. Voicing your opinion will always work against you.



For anyone who studied finance / econ / business, be warned: this is NOT a finance job in any capacity. You will not learn anything about the financial service industry by being here - unless you move into a licensed role, in which you'll really only be able to learn about the industry to pitch the same handful of Anonymous products that benefit the company, so it's really just a glorified sales role. I work with many people who previously worked in grocery stores, coffee shops, or retail shops, who never went to college. It doesn't matter what you know - if anything, it'll benefit you to avoid all forms of thinking whatsoever, as Anonymous does not value ideas, only obedience. 



Your schedule is monitored by a system that quantifies every second you spend on / off the phone into performance metrics that determine your fate at the company. Do not drink too much water at your desk. If you take bathroom breaks, it'll harm your metrics and your manager will have to talk to you and possibly issue a warning. Management speaks like they "want to help you", but they really want to help themselves climb the Anonymous ladder, and couldn't care less about their expendable employee base. Pay is very low for a financial services industry job...customer service reps are barely making $38k. And this was after a much-raved about "pay increase" that we should've been so humbled and honored to receive, for the grueling work we struggle through. 



Coaching sessions are torturous. You'll be placed in a room with your manager and possibly two to three other colleagues, to listen to each others calls, and tear them apart to bits. You are expected to adhere to a call structure and parrot the same lines, check off a certain number of transfers to certain departments, pitch a certain number of "contribution increases" to bring more money to Anonymous at the customer's expense. Managers never tell you what you did well on calls, only what you did poorly. It's not that we don't want feedback and to improve - but sometimes, we did some really nice things on the calls and want to be recognized for our positives too.



Minor technicalities are a guaranteed pull down the rabbit hole of warnings. If you have a technical error, the quality team screens more of your calls, notifies your manager, and you get a "verbal warning". They'll screen exponentially more of your calls than they do for anyone else, so that they catch more mistakes you made that everyone else makes too - regardless of how minimal they may be, the repercussions escalate very quickly. Management gets excited to prosecute their employees and never looks at the full situation when quality provides feedback. Half the time, they don't even read their emails or listen to the call, just issue a warning because you "messed up," and they don't care about your side of the story. Sometimes if you try to explain, they'll ask you to stop talking.



If you start in a phone center, you will end in a phone center. Before you begin working, management will pitch to you that the "sky's the limit" with career growth in the company, but they don't tell you about the red tape that stands between you and the sky. Anonymous sucks people in for years and years, until they don't have any speakable skills to pitch anywhere outside the company because they've been on the phones for so long, and they're stuck there. It's a culture run by unfair management who talks down to you like you're an incompetent toddler. You will be overworked, underpaid, and undervalued for all the efforts at self-betterment in this job, as it all goes to waste. If they like you, they like you. If they don't, nothing will change that. Either way, get out of there sooner rather than later. The brand name that Anonymous provides isn't worth the mental and emotional suffering of their customer service work.
Pro: Training is pleasant. They hire right out of college. Work-sponsored outings are a delight. Great facilities, beautiful campus, on-site Starbucks is the greatest perk of all. Friendly coworkers. Pretty packaging for what proves to be quite an awful deal.
Recommendation: Doesn't Recommend,Negative Outlook,No opinion of CEO

You need to leave the company to pursue your next upward career move, get that next level of experience and then re-apply for a more senior position at Anonymous in order to move up in your career.  Sad to say but it is the reality at Anonymous.

Con: For my region, a huge amount of travel was required, which took much of my productive time. This was often not the case with my peers, whom I was ranked against. Certain employer events would also cause flows of assets beyond my control. They attempted to capture this in the goal setting, but that was done so far in advance that it was certainly not an exact science. The travel time made it very difficult to have much of a personal or social life as well. I often worked 12 hour days, and then spent the evenings doing all the paperwork and entering notes into our tracking system, so it wasn't unusual to have a 14-15 hour day, then have to catch a plane to another location and do it all again the next day.
Pro: I enjoyed autonomy, I created my own schedule, although certainly certain goals had to be met. I was paid a salary, plus a variable compensation, which was largely derived from my activities, so I had a better chance to drive my own success.

Con:
Work non-existent/not challenging
Office is located in the middle of nowhere (Texas)
Old fashioned attitudes
Not a lot of young people unless you work in the call center
Old technology
Too much bureaucracy

The downside to the training program is that the team that you get placed on is very hit or miss and very much or if your control. Some people were placed on awesome teams working with cool products and technologies while others were stuck working on software that was 20 years old. 

Also during the training there are a lot of B.S. corporate events/talks, which were super cheesy and unnecessary. Some of the topics during training were a waste of time too, like learning how to write an e-mail (yes, I'm serious).

The team I was placed on seemed to have no plan in place for me when I got there despite the fact that a manager has to request an associate from the aforementioned training program so it's not like I was placed on their team by surprise or without their knowledge.

The whole time I was there I wrote probably a total of 20 lines of code because the product was in maintenance and there was very little new development. There wasn't really any work for me to do, so I essentially got paid to read reddit all day.

There are tons of meetings to attend and most of them are just people from various teams/business units arguing over minute details about random aspects of a project. The amount of red tape that you have to go through to get things done is pretty high.
Summary: "It could be great or it could be terrible"
Pro:
Good benefits & pay
Not a lot of pressure to get things done
Nice office/campus
Free rent for3 months
Get paid to do pretty much nothing all day

This was my first job out of college as a software developer. They have a training program where they send you to North Carolina for five months to learn about various technologies and to work on a "real life" project.

About halfway through the program you get notified of the actual team that you'll be on when you return to your job site. You have some input with this, but the decision is ultimately made by management.

The program itself isn't too bad. I learned about a lot of technologies that I hadn't heard of and it gave me a little bit of real world experience.
Recommendation: Doesn't Recommend,Positive Outlook,No opinion of CEO

Con: My experience is all within Workplace Participant Services business unit., working with workplace retirement plans such as 401ks and 403bs, and the company that pay us to service those plans. In WPS, we are underpaid for what we do (median in New England for our job type would be closer to $70k), the expectations are always changing, applied inconsistently, and you are prodded and driven to do overtime because they choose to understaff for the busy seasons to save money. In the call center positions, you're on a clock, you get the legal minimum required breaktime, and there is a general lack of respect for work/life balance. Everywhere else in Anonymous, I hear the experiences are great, so I would say this is a reflecting on being within Workplace Participant Services, not Anonymous as a whole.
Summary: "Depends on where you are in the company"
Pro: Amazing benefits. 7%101k match, 10% profit sharing into your101k every year,3 year period for full vesting. That can get lucrative after a while. You also can have the Portfolio Advisory Service manage your101k free of charge as an employee, and you have access to beautiful grounds (the complex is thousands of acres large with a pond and hiking trails and two cafeterias and a couple gyms, tennis and basketball courts and softball field and volleyball court). The health insurance is a little pricey but the plan itself is the best I've ever seen in terms of what it will cover. And last but not least, if you do your years i the dumpster up front, there is excellent income potential within the company.

Con: They are old fashioned. They don't have a work environment that inspires creativity.They have call models and sales models that they want you to stick to "to make you successful"...they actually focus more on those models than educating about the products they want you to sell...it can sometimes make you feel like a robot and clients pick up on it. They measure performance a lot by things that don't really make business sense and have particular buckets they want you to fill. If you can get past that aspect of the job it can be a nice career.
Pro: Great benefits package and a large company so lots of opportunity to grow. You can advance quickly if you have ambition. The retirement benefits alone make it worth it. 10 percent profit sharing...Seven percent101k match. You can expect to make over 100k as a portfolio specialist which is decent and is truly under15 hour work week. Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than5 years

Con: Pay and bonus structure is significantly subpar - every time this is brought up you're reminded "how great" Anonymous's non-salary benefits are, which is somewhat true, however the fact that I have access to all kinds of benefits that don't apply to me ,or don't really have any personal benefit to me, personally, irrelevant.  I can't pay rent, buy food, or pay all the other bills I have will my "great benefits."  Money is the only thing that helps with that - and the salaries Anonymous pays, compared to the broader industry, are ridiculously low.  Moreover, there have been numerous changes that have occurred in the last 12 months that are ostensibly to "make things better" for the customer, as well as the associate, but the net effect has been the opposite ... for both.  They've basically significantly increased the scope of the role, while narrowing the performance metrics ... all while creating an increasing environment where it essentially makes it impossible for you to provide the positive experience the customer is expecting, and meet your goals.  How this has played out out to associate is ... you can kiss making more than the bare minimum for your quarterly bonuses (which also ... in not very much at all) goodbye.  Also, over the last 12 months or so, there seems to have been a dramatic concern with turnover, primarily among the associates who have been with the company less than 12 months.  The company has become ridiculously preoccupied with finding ways to keep this demographic with the company that they're basically throwing everything but the kitchen sink at them in the misguided hope it will keep them from leaving.  Basically ... they're focusing all their measures on increasing salary, compensation, and quality at work to the employees who have been there the least, and contribute the least to the company's overall functionality.  I've been with the company, and in this function for years, and even though I've been given yearly bonuses and increases I sit next to people who have been licensed less than 6 months, and are making the same amount in salary as me, or more.  It's really insulting, not to mention makes all the experienced, and seasoned employees feel extremely unappreciated.  Then there's also the issue that performance and ability really have no bearing whatsoever towards promotions or recognition for achievement - the current situation at the location where I work reminds me more of my senior year of high school, and everything boils down to a popularity contest.  The end result is you have people who weren't even competent to begin with and routinely failed to meet even the most basic of their performance metrics, being given increased levels of responsibility and management if they're "popular."  Granted this exists to some degree or another no matter where you work, however the level I've witnessed over the years is on the order of 20 times worse than anything I've experienced in nearly 15+ years in the workforce.
Pro: Lots of great resources, training is definitely better than average for the industry, lots and lots of great employer provided benefits, facilities are very up to date and modern, tons of resources at your disposal, and a great place to learn more without necessarily having to be in a pure sales or commission environment.
Recommendation: Doesn't Recommend,Neutral Outlook,No opinion of CEO

Confusing bonus structure that is constantly changing and bonus is dictated by manager entirely and not by production and stack rank so it can be very bias. It has become more of an efficiency role instead of quality even though the main point is sales and not service. Very unorganized part of the company. It's a little niche compared to the rest of the company so there is constant change and no one including directors know what's going on in the future. Also misrepresented growth opportunities. They say they are expanding and you can promote to the more prestigious phone role or into the field however when one of those spots is vacated they backfill it with two people in this role instead of replacing. So be prepared to be stuck.

Author Title: Former Employee - Vice President Human Resources

Con: Unfortunately, the training program is where my positive experience ended. Employees are reminded every day from the first time they peruse the careers website, to the job interview, to on-boarding, to training, to team meetings, that Anonymous isn't like Merrill Lynch, Schwab, JP Morgan, or any other player in the game; Anonymous is a family-owned company and doesn't have to play to it's shareholders, and thus they are one of the few in the business "for the customer". That sure sounds nice, but beyond being family-owned, it's just not true. This job is in a 24/7 call center, and just like every call center in the world, metrics are king. You'll never move up anywhere in the company for retaining a multi-million dollar account or preventing perilous actions through education of financial instruments or any other morally outstanding action... you'll move up for finishing your calls on an average of less than eight minutes. This "time = money" focus exacerbates an already-beaurocratic business structure by incentivizing representatives to transfer their calls or to be curt to the point of being entirely unhelpful. That's fine, and almost expected from most call center representatives with other companies, but in financial services, it's unacceptable; you're dealing with people's retirement accounts and livelihoods. On the sales side, recommendations are limited to proprietary target-date funds and bloated, high-fee "managed" accounts. Going above and beyond to solve problems that are repeatedly surfacing and are consistently unaddressed is a habit discouraged by management: "that's not your job". Other than their own propaganda, nothing differentiates this company from the other financial services firms--do not take a potential paycut to choose Anonymous over them with the idea that you'll be working for some sort of Red Cross organization, even though they will spin it that way. At the end of the day, this is a 24/7 call center (where your job is to verify customers, reset passwords, give website support, send checks, and enter trades at their direction...financial professional is thrown around very loosely around Anonymous, but I would not consider the FR to be one) that is ALWAYS hiring. If you weren't able to deduce, there is an unhealthy amount of turnover at Anonymous due to employees leaving for increased responsibilities and salaries (most Jax representatives went to Merrill, which was literally across the street!). On the other hand, if you have some sort of relevant degree or experience and are out of work, there is a ton of job security and experience to be gained here. It's a stepping stone at best.
Pro: Anonymous has an incredibly in-depth four month long training program that will not only bring pre-licensed financial representatives up to speed to pass their Series 7 and 63's (even for those completely new to the industry), but will also familiarize you with all of the software that would be used on a day-to-day basis. Generally speaking, upon completion of the program, financial representatives are capable of adequately performing the job duties in what is objectively a complicated job function without any sort of assistance. Also, barring a layoff climate or doing anything illegal, job security is very, very high; never hitting your numbers will still get you your weekly paycheck. If you play the game, opportunity is most certainly there to advance (and your manager will be first in line to assist you in achieving your goals), but you can only go so far in the call center, both in terms of job duties and salary.
Recommendation: Doesn't Recommend,Neutral Outlook,No opinion of CEO

Big push to move low level employees into the next step on the ladder. People at senior/principal levels just stay where they are whether they slack off just enough or put in some quality hard work

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Once you get licensed and "get on the floor" that is when the trouble begins.



The job is extremely boring. Dealing with people calling every second of the day from about 9-4pm is horrible. Most of the time you are resetting passwords, not actually doing anything finance related. And when you do get the chance to do finance related things, all you do is enter trade tickets and hit send.



In training, they sold to us that we are "financial professionals," however, I would beg to differ. The only difference between "service associates" and a regular CSR rep is that at Anonymous, you are licensed.



The job sucks. It sucks your soul. It is not a fun environment. IF you enjoy  answering calls all day for $16-20 dollars a hour, have at it.



**Also, it should be noted that promotion to the sales side is extremely hard. There are 200 apps a year for 25-50 sales jobs. You have to kiss major butt and kill your metrics to get ahead. It is just too many people applying for those jobs. Managers will say that there are so many positions you can work in, but in reality they are all the same job, with a x<5000 in pay differential in the service side.



AS OTHER REVIEWS HAVE SAID, ONCE YOU ARE HIRED IN A PHONE SITE, THE CHANCE OF LEAVING TO A BRANCH OR TO ANOTHER DIVISION OF FIDELITY (fund management, analysis, etc). IS EXTREMELY SLIM. PLEASE KNOW THIS.
Pro:
Good way to get licensed. Extremely focused on making sure you pass the 7/63. Free material, a retake if your scores are close to passing and an overall good atmosphere in training..



very boring, but very thorough.



Ok job for a fresh college graduate, but other than that I would advise one to stay away.



Good food on campus. They hire good cooks to feed us while work. Decent pricing too

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments  for more than a year

Con: Where to begin...The mantra being preached to new hires is that your contribution matters and you're helping our customers just by answering the call. In reality, training is now so utterly warped and schizophrenic that you likely will need a promotion above the entry level position to assist with anything more complicated than cutting a check or trading a mutual fund. Consequently, it is absolutely crushing that you can't help half the customers that wait hours in line to get to you and that's even worse when you first start to where you transfer 95% of your calls. Management is unhelpful and most of the call center managers you honestly scratch your head at what they actually do other than go to meetings and give you self-directed coaching assignments. As with any call center, metrics are King. I got promoted entirely because I got through calls fast and didn't ask questions only for the next role to be even worse. Certain departments (core/hnw services mainly) have forced overtime right now that is held against you if you don't meet the supposed goal or have other activities that prevent you from doing so. The new systems internally have also taken hold times and raised them exponentially because of the new/barely trained reps having to transfer everything and attrition causes old reps to leave for jobs outside of fidelity or internal promotions with the stress the new system has lumped on them from new hires being functionally useless. Volumes aren't even as bad as they were last year but it's still a high stress job that keeps you tied to a cubicle having to apologize to clients for management failing to see the problem in changing the entire service model at the busy time of year when clients are already in a hurry and coming in in droves. The money isn't enough to make this worthwhile.
Pro: The benefits (401, medical, etc) are above standard for most employers. They're also the most likely firm to get you to pass a series 7 if you have no finance experience or degree to fall back on. If you can handle call center work there is some job mobility in that function, just don't expect to get into the back office or anything beyond a phone unless you're a lucky duck destined for management.
Recommendation: Doesn't Recommend,Negative Outlook,No opinion of CEO

Con: I went through the entire hiring process and was made an offer, went for drug testing , fingerprinting and to have a badge made . On a Monday before class started I mentioned I was pregnant . On that Tuesday I recieved a call from hr asking question regarding my pregnancy , on Thursday I recieved a very rude call stating they were withdrawing my offer due to "unspecified concerns that came up during background check" even though the background portion had already been completed and passed long before... There's no doubt in my mind that they changed their mind due to my pregnancy , which Im pretty sure is illegal. I'm very disappointed , I was looking forward to this job and wasn't even expecting a maternity leave from them, I was back at my current job when my youngest was only 6 days old. There's nothing in my background that should've kept me from getting hired , per their rules that I looked over carefully. Whatever their reasons, I know that my merit and experience more than qualified me for this position , and my character has never been questioned, especially by an employer or associate. Their loss I guess.
Pro: I was offered a great salary and benefits.  The hours seems reasonable and not ever having to work weekends seemed great
Recommendation: Doesn't Recommend,Negative Outlook,No opinion of CEO

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than a year
Author Title: Current Employee - Brokerage Operations Representative III

Con:
If you want to go to a role involving financial analysis, or anything unrelated to the direct relationship with the clients, it is almost impossible to do starting from the phone roles, you will easily get a job at another firm with the training and certifications you gain, so you may have to jump around from firm to firm.



The advisory/guidance roles in Anonymous are less "sales" related in comparison to say Merrill Lynch, but they are still sales related. At the end of the month if you did not speak with a single customer that needed an annuity, you should not see any form of negative impact for not putting someone in one. Anonymous should be leading the industry in the charge towards a more "fiduciary" standard.



The compensation was recently increased to 42k for the entry level, which is okay, but honestly everyone across the board should receive about an extra ~10k. Anonymous can afford to do it, and the retention rates would drastically increase. Most of the employees are recent college graduates, so amazing healthcare and benefits are not as important as cash money to invest.
Pro:
This job is technically a "call center", but don't let that dissuade you, Anonymous an amazing place to work. The benefits, training, and exposure to the financial markets are invaluable. For those wanting to enter the industry that do not have degrees from overpriced private colleges, Anonymous is the place to be. You will work alongside some of the best and the brightest, ambitious individuals who come from a wide array of backgrounds, all sharing a common desire to help the uneducated investor find success.



I can only speak for the Jacksonville, FL location, but the training is phenomenal. The series 7 instructors, alongside the rest of the learning and development team will make sure you are successful. You will have to be self motivated though, every day during the initial training you will be coming home to take 1-3 hour tests, but if you ever need assistance with a concept the mentors are there for you - and are actually encouraged to help you by being paid overtime.



Whether you want to move up in Anonymous or leave and go to another firm, this is a great place to get your foot in the door in a normally very competitive industry.



Benefits are amazing. Make sure you take advantage of everything.



With the brand new systems in place, schedules are more flexible!

Pro: Great retirement benefits, a chance to learn about the Financial Services Industry from a pioneer in the industry.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Been here for 3 years. "promoted" 3 times. Anonymous Micro-manages its employees like McDonald's. 100% phone job. Want to go to the bathroom? Need to leave a note in regards to a customer issue? Need to talk to your manager for a moment? (you get the pattern) Too bad, it will eat into your phone statistics since they measure how many seconds of every minute you're actually on the phone and report it to you every morning. FORCED over time for 10 months out of the year (i.e kiss your weekends goodbye) even though on the interview they claim it's just for 1-2 months. All career development (which they don't stop talking about due to fear of the very high turn-over they have) is being concentrated around your ability to stay on the phone for the rest of your career (unless you want to be a manager of a phone team). I honestly don't know one employee that is not actively looking for a different job.
Summary: "Phone job with little to no apportunity off the phone"
Pro: Covered parking, great employees (and to some degree managers) , nice looking campus, does not publicly traded, thus, does not need to answer shareholders, fantastic class setting to help you get licensed (series 7/63)

(They force you to watch countless hours of internally-produced videos during new hire class on why Anonymous is the best company you'll ever work for...). They make you feel bad for hating your job while at the same time putting under unmanageable working conditions. I had to work 10 hour shifts with a 30 MINUTE lunch, and if I took 1 minute longer than that, I got a threatening email from my manger. SERIOUSLY? I could go on, but there's so much that I could say about this company. Do not work for Anonymous unless you are desperate and have nowhere else to go. Con: 24 / 7 coverage.  Anonymous Investments work you like a dog for lower than industry rate consulting rate.  That is why there are so much turn over at Anonymous.  All the good ones left for higher paying jobs.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Everything is communicated via 50+ page Powerpoint documents that no one reads beyond the 3rd slide during meetings. Annual increases are tiny or nonexistent, although the HR documentation indicates ranges for double-digit increases (dream on).  Some execs are reassigned to lead departments in which they have no experience and are clueless about strategies and issues.  Overall, they are very slow to take action on toxic performers, which causes turnover of  the solid performers who can get jobs elsewhere and not have to deal with the grief caused by the toxic colleagues.  Sr. leaders ask for feedback and suggestions, but rarely act on honest input - it's easier for them to manage the status quo.  Although the ongoing mantra is about ethical decisions and behaviors, I personally encountered an environment where confidentiality was breached and bullying was evident...the sr. exec chose to look the other way.
Pro: Base pay not so competitive, but generous bonus plans more than made up for that.  Good place for recent college grads to start their careers and get a solid foundation of experience.  Beautiful facilities, great design, and lots of art.  Lots of opportunities to participate in classes, seminars, information sessions, etc...both in person and online.

Lots of politicking and favoritism.  You learn which managers like who very quickly.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time

Con: Not so much Anonymous as it is the industry we work in but tax season (leading up to the tax deadline of April 15th) and distribution season (retirees requesting their minimum required distributions before the end of the year) can be incredibly draining.  Last year we were slammed and it made for a very long couple of months.
Pro: I honestly love my job.  I'm so grateful for the opportunity to work for a company that truly cares about their clients!  Providing excellent customer service is absolutely necessary and we take it very seriously. Anonymous strives to hire like minded individuals that create a positive work environment.  They review their salaries to make sure they are staying competitive and there's plenty of overtime opportunity. The benefits are great. Tuition reimbursement, 10% profit sharing, 7%101k match, health reimbursement (gym memberships), etc.  They are very lax compared to other companies when it comes to using sick time, last minute vacation, and changing your shift to accomplish a better work/life balance. Anonymous is very open about upcoming changes within the company with all levels of employees.

Pro: Great benefits and work life balance.  Work with high quality employees and work is interesting  and challenging.  Ability to move around and experience different areas of business.

Con: Call center is a "sweat shop" in my opinion. Make you eat lunch, 30 minutes, at your desk-they call it a "Working Lunch". The calls are non-stop and you are limited in a career due to this being a call center. Very political place, no room for advancement. You are coached and everything you do is recorded both on computer and phone. Adherence to your schedule is a big thing, also, if a customer give you a bad survey, and its not your fault, you still get in trouble. Blah!!!
Summary: "Do yourself a favor, Run Away from Anonymous"
Pro: Benefits were good, they match 7% after 1 year of service, but, not fully vested until3 years. Most people do not stay3 years.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time

Con: Not a performance based company.   While they claim to be,  monetary reward system tends to be socialistic with little distinction for a person's productivity. Much of compensation is tied to 401K as opposed to cash in pocket.  Will know more on this once I've gone through the bonus round.  Once you get hired in you are fairly well set since they tend to steer away from terminations, rather they look first to place people in another position.   This makes it challenging for managers who are dealing with performance issues.  But even with this, the vast majority of people are top notch.
Pro: People are professional and they care.  Leadership is excellent and C level executives are very in tune with what is happening in the business.  Open environment where ideas are encouraged.  Fairly conservative and cautious company which means quality triumphs over speed.  This means you actually have time to think and do things right with less pressure to simply deliver.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Base salaries can be very low, especially when you get promoted to the next level.

Some groups work in crowded arrangements because leadership will not support any official work from home arrangements.

Lack of oversight on Directors and Vice Presidents with direct reports. A bad apple can really tear a department apart. 

Review process is not individual. People are stack ranked and there are quotas on high ratings. Even if you have 2 star performers, only 1 can receive the most excellent rating. The process is truly not individualized.

People provide reviews for employees they have had very little interaction with. Can get very personal.

You will have to change departments to earn more money as annual merit increases are often nominal.

Your career is in your hands here. You can not depend on any management or HR group to help guide you in advancing your career.
Summary: "Great company with pockets of terrible management."
Pro:
Great benefits for employees. Salary+Bonus+Annual Profit Share+7% dollar-to-dollar101k match.

Contractors treated well in most groups. (I have been contracting the last few years)

Durham NC location is pretty casual. Business casual dress with jeans on Friday. Relationships with management have always been casual side.

Some groups work with offshore resources and get to travel to other countries.

Some groups are in flexible work arrangement situations. Some people work from home much of the time. Even in other groups, you generally can work from home if needed for personal reasons from time to time.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than3 years

Con:
Poor vision and lack of strategy by senior management. Heavy on politics...Lacks work/life balance for some key individuals.

Pro:

You can come here to stay...Overall great place to work.

As a result, those of us with families tend be left behind those who are single and can go out and drink with the V.P.s and get moved ahead.
Pro: Competitive salary and can provide great experience. I worked in several different groups including workplace investing, brokerage operations and technology and have been very happy working in my current role.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 10 years

Con: The culture is a bit straight-laced especially when compared to newer companies run by generation X or younger people.  Also, it's a mutual fund company first and foremost.  The company has a history of technical innovation but they aren't a tech company so it seems like technical teams are hit hard when the markets contract.
Pro: I loved the people with whom I worked, they are a smart and talented group.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 10 years

Con: Massive attempt to eliminate older employees in the branch system, will not promote (especially if you are a woman) unless you are young and are a member of the so called "boys club".  If you are a young male you will be supported and promoted by management.  Managers will lie to HR to support this movement.  Anonymous is on the wrong track, this has not always been true, however, seems to be the direction they are taking in 2015. It boggles ones mind that a company the size of Anonymous would not find the best talent in the industry, instead of promoting mediocre sales people to manage branches, most of whom do not know the first thing about how to treat employees. I was one of those employees that worked harder than anyone else and was still treated badly, and after all the years I devoted to this company you still pushed me out. Shame on you Anonymous.
Pro: Benefits are satisfactory, pay could be more inline with the industry, vacation policy is ok but has not been updated for over10 years.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Terrible disconnect between senior management and the people below them. Poltiical maneuvering among senior leaders is widespread, a result of C-level unwillingness to set direction clearly or resolve conflicts decisively. Company culture is consensus-driven - often from the bottom up in that individuals, groups and teams are left to work things out themselves - and when issues among teams arise that cannot be resolved below the SVP level, they remain unaddressed and left to fester until things get bad enough that someone senior HAS to step in, usually with more fallout than would have been necessary if the problem had been addressed earlier. There is a serious blind spot when it comes to recognizing the limits of consensus-building and the fact that leadership by directive is sometimes necessary.  Micro-managing is common, and far, far too much time is spent on producing presentations and reports.
Summary: "Good people hamstrung by micro-managing senior management who won't make tough decisons"
Pro: Solid pay, decent work-life balance, excellent benefits. The people at Anonymous are smart, friendly and uniformly desire to do the right thing.

The market manager told us to stop calling people in "our book" and only work with new clients.  Mandatory to have 18 appointments per week.  Leaves no time to respond to clients calls or put in any effort to plan for client appointments which is the most important part of Financial "PLANNING".

Con: Management has way to may priorities throwing you in a number of different directions. The fire drill method of management makes it hard to no what to focus on. The middle management is hit or miss, you either have someone to help you move up, or someone who is afraid you'll take their job.
Pro: Excellent benefits. Health Insurance for a family is reasonable, the 10% drop into your101K for profit share each year was always a plus in January. No vision insurance offered, but good dental,1 weeks of vacation after3 years, plus all market holidays. Seldom have to work weekends or past 6pm.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 8 years

Con:
Anonymous - who is a recordkeeper for who knows how many companies 401k plans, has a 5 year cliff vesting schedule, and you're not even 20% vested in company contributions until 2 years.



The systems provided need a MAJOR overhaul.  There are procedural specific systems and client specific systems to use when handling calls.  These systems are not updated, so 1/2 the time you are under a constant worry if you are handling something incorrectly.  When cross trained on multiple products, you are not trained completely, so customers can ask questions you are supposed to be able to answer, but you can't because you don't know.  The answer is supposed to be searchable while you put the customer on hold to get the answer.  But holds can only be for 3 minutes, and it can take a lot longer than 3 minutes to find the answer because 1/2 the time when you search something the system comes back with no results. 



If a customer escalates, they don't go to your immediate manager, you're to call your "solutions desk and escalate the call" and that rep is supposed to handle the call from that point.  However the solutions desk reps are extremely lazy and will do anything and everything to push the call back on the tier 1 rep because they don't want to handle the call, thus causing the customers to become completely frustrated, yelling and screaming at us over why we are not transferring them to a supervisor, and then give us a bad customer survey.



If you need to enter a work item, they are shipped off shore to some reps in India to handle who have no idea what they are doing.  So they resolve the work item incorrectly, and we need to enter multiple work items for the same exact thing over and over.  We promise customers a 5 day work around timeframe and something so simple can take over 1 mo to resolve because the India reps just don't care.   The customers become very upset over how long it takes to resolve a simple error. 



While the company offers great potential for advancement, it is all in who you know, not what you know.  I had an interview for an internal transfer once, and while I was nervous as I didn't have a lot of interview experience at the time, my interviewer was constantly yawning and looking at his phone even before the interview started.  I don't think I was that boring, but that was extremely unprofessional and I can't believe he got the job he did because while I didn't get it, once trained I'm sure I would've been way more suited for the position. 



When you do need your manager and not a "solutions desk rep" they are nowhere to be found because they are always "in a meeting".  



This job creates a lot of extremely stressful situations, but when you become frustrated and voice your opinion, you're in the wrong and put under review or fired.  You can offer suggestions on how you think things should be and how to correct it, and management will pat you on the back for it, but then nothing is ever done to fix anything.
Pro:
Competitive Pay

Some coworkers are great

Great benefits package offered

Great101k match



Great potential for advancement
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than a year

Con: Communication was lacking between staff and contract employees. Several times my emails were not answered and many times required extensive phone and messaging before a return call or communication was initiated.
Pro: All benefits were as expected and as promised. Salary also was as expected and as promised. It systems were updated regularly and completely.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for less than a year

Con:
1) Increased stress. Due to Anonymous's business model to constantly bring in new business we are focused on bringing in new business all the time. I never take full lunch breaks and leaving at 5 PM makes me feel guilty. 

2) Hampster wheel. There is no means to the end.  Managing a $1B book ensures you may get $50 - $60k a year in "residuals/trails" at Anonymous while at a wirehouse a $1B book may generate $1MM + in residuals/trails

3) Long hours. If you are looking for an 8-5 job, working at the branch sales level isn't for you. Work/life balance is tough.
Pro:
1) 10% year end profit sharing (added to101K account) and 7%101k match

1) Stability of company

3) "Always learning" mentality, constant weekly coaching meeting to ensure we are on top of the market

4) Good pay if you can perform well (only speaking for branch positions ie VP Financial Consultant / Financial Consultant)

5) If you are new to the field the Anonymous call centers is the perfect place to start. Anonymous will license you, train you, and help you find the right department/branch to work in. Anonymous is big in promoting internal candidates.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments  for more than a year

Con: This is where your dreams go to die. You answer phone calls all day long 24/7. You feel like a robot with going over the same questions over and over again. Even at the prestigious higher roles you are still only offering two cookie cutter solutions PAS (Portfolio Advisory Service) and Life Cycle Funds both of which have mediocre performance. As a Financial Solutions Rep we aren't even allowed to sell the product on performance. Why else would you hire someone to manage your money other than performance? The people that sell it don't even know what the performance is and its so hard to find you eventually give up. If you want to be paid a lot to be a robot selling mediocre products this a great place for you.
Pro: They pay for your licensing training and pay you a decent starting salary. 7%101k match after the first year and 10% profit sharing on your second year.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than a year

Con:
They continually ask you to do more and more while the pay stays the same (i.e., taking on other responsibilities, taking more phone calls due to lack of proper staffing, etc.) The work / life balance is not very good. 



Many managers also like to play favorites, so even if you hit all of your goals you are still screwed and will have a hard time moving up or receiving any bonuses/ raises.

Con:
Travelling can be extensive. Each implementation is at least 1 - 2 weeks (including the weekends) and it's not uncommon to go from one to another. Some implementations are scheduled and promised by upper management to the client, for 10 - 12 weeks. There were many instances where employees would travel from a 2 week conversion to a 4 week conversion to another 4-6 week conversion back to back. 



I don't know if the pay grades were appropriate for this sort of commitment to the employees.
Summary: "A lot of travel, low pay, but great experience."
Pro: You learn a ton about the clearing and custody business. You are one arm of the full implementation spectrum, but it allows you client facing opportunities as well as exposure to all levels of management and different departments. The experience, knowledge and exposure are the biggest advantages to this job

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time

Con:
Financial Advice was limited to mutual funds and a few select annuities.  

Quarterly bonuses were based on annuity production and accounts transferred to Anonymous's professional investment management services.  Professional Investment Management was limited to model portfolios comprised of  mutual funds and some ETFs.  As in any large corporation the goals continuously changed and became increasing more stressful.
Pro: As a Senior Account Executive, I was assigned an existing book of approximately300 clients,so  there is no need to recruit new clients, a definate plus.  Benefits were great , the salary was competitive and the working facility was beautiful.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 10 years

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for less than a year

Con:
This is financial services and it is highly regulated, what does it mean, there are rules. LOTS OF RULES. But that is only a bad thing if you are one of those people that can't follow rules or can't follow order.



The rules are very simple: Don't be late. EVER. Not a minute. Why? Because it affects the entire company. This company handles big clients with big expectations. It handles other peoples retirements, which means their futures. Yes, there is a high level of commitment, but there is also a high level of opportunity.
Pro:
This is a company that cares and provides opportunity to show it.

1. Benefits

1. The pay is very good especially considering the work/life balance: I declined a job that paid 10k more, but fidelity pays overtime, where as the other job was gonna work me35-65hours per week. NOT worth it. Anonymous provides a very good pay with the ability for those who want to work over-time to make more money.

3.Great opportunities for growth. They pay you to get your licenses, they have great tuition reimbursement benefits. If you are ambitious and want to grow, Anonymous is your place. I am already planning to get my licenses, an MBA, a masters in law, and move up in the next 6-7 years. 

4. A great culture with efficiency to its core.

5. Healthy lifestyle emphasis. They have the FIT food which means salads and healthy food is super cheap. How affordable? $1 for a salad vs $10 for hamburger. Yes, they want their employees to be healthy and thank goodness. They also have a recreation center and a health center.

6. Ability to get involved with community and company. They have great affinity groups for LGBT, AfricanAmerican/Hispanic, Women, and Veterans. They also have AnonymousCares so it is great for people who enjoy social groups.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for less than a year

Con:
-opportunities for further growth very limited if you do not make a lateral move into a different department.

-pay does not increase much, I knew many employees that had worked for Anonymous for 10+ years on my team and were pretty much going to retire i

Con:
*Poor compensation - below the industry average for all positions



*Mandatory overtime - poor work/life balance especially during tax season



*"Pseudo promotions" - change in role, no change in pay 



*Outdated and inefficient computer systems that increase errors 



*Incredibly large company - you are easy to replace 





Don't believe the reviews that you see below. They do not accurately reflect the life of a Anonymous employee or the "small guys" at the end of the totem pole ( 80% of the company). Mid to senior level management is a different story. They live a drastically different life than the average employee who works tirelessly and is underpaid. Wine and dine events for mid to senior level management  are constantly ongoing in our cafeterias. Such events are disrespectful when you are requiring your employees below you to work weekends during tax season.
Summary: "The American equivalent of a Chinese sweatshop/ Modern Day Slavery"
Pro:
*Fantastic training 



* It's easy to get the job, they hire everyone 



*Friendly environment, great coworkers

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than a year

Con: Its a machine and you get treated like a replaceable cog. Heavy micromanagement to control output of product (ie what you say to clients) They're like the mcdonalds of financial services - you know what you get, whether good or bad. Working there you're forced to adopt their processes and procedures with exact scripts, very robotic - often times reminds me they want you to be a parrot (ie repeat what they say with greater enthusiasm, then they feed you a cracker like Iago from Aladdin). Management recruits you by promising you a book of business and that its like you running your own business but with fidelity's resources and support. Further from the truth. Once you're in, you always have to continue to generate revenue for the firm. This doesn't lend a good hand towards servicing your existing customers. Good pay, but its a hamster wheel. The moment you stop running, you get slapped.
Summary: "Ok place to work, but not all its cracked up to be."
Pro: They recruit you with the promise of quick promotion and fast track to a 6 figure income. Its as they promise - atleast in my previous roles. Fantastic101k matching and PSP. Great benefits, great training. Overall pleasant company to start with if you're new in the industry or ready to retire
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than5 years

Con: there are no cons that i can think of
Pro: New facility, friendly people, amazing compensation and benefits
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than a year

Con: Projects move at a snail's pace.  A lot of politics three and four ticks down from the CEO.  If you like fast paced and challenging, this is not the place for you.  If you want to be more than just a small cog in a huge machine, this is not the place for you.  If you mind the ever-present feeling that Big Brother is watching everything you do (in and out of work), this is not the place for you.
Summary: "A great place to work if you can stand projects moving very slowly"
Pro: Great benefits, competitive salary, lots of diversions in the way of talks by high profile outside speakers, art tours in the building, classes at the gym, etc.. etc.  Very nice and intelligent people work at this company and the majority are very committed to the firm. Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: I was recruited strictly for my customer service skills.  I was concerned about metrics such as call times, call quota, and surveys and asked clear questions about these issues.  In the face to face interview, I was very mislead.  I was told the main focus was on customer satisfaction, and this was not true once I was on the floor.  Our training about the subject matter was excellent, but we received almost no training on the complex and multiple computer programs.  There was no hands on training of the system.  This lack of training on an absolutely vital part of the job is why I had to leave the company.  Also, many times we asked a manager or mentor a question, we were told something that was later disputed.  There was no consistency regarding information.
Pro: Good hours, great pay, no working weekends.
Recommendation: Doesn't Recommend,Neutral Outlook,No opinion of CEO
