Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
POLITICS.  I am aware this happens everywhere but the amount of sucking up and brown nosing at this place is absolutely unbelievable.  The best way I can describe it is as a shark tank.  



Certain people would stop at nothing to stab you in the back.  If you ever did anything that could remotely be a mistake you would get a email from whoever found it and they would copy every manager that they could possibly think of.  This was not just in my area, it happened in every area I had ever been in contact with during my time.



Managers did not care about their employees (except for their "favorites") and never provided any training that could help you to move up through the company.



Advancing your career is basically impossible.  If you are content making a very low salary for an extended period of time while being stuck in an entry level job into your 30's (yes I saw a lot of this) then Anonymous is for you.



Raises were an absolute joke.  I know the economy is not in the best shape but it is insulting to get a "raise" that might increase my paycheck by a quarter.  Not to mention all employees received the same "pay increase" regardless of talent.
Summary: "Seemed like a decent place at first but so glad I left"
Pro: Pretty solid benefits, SOME people I worked with were really fun to be with, great101k options especially with the matching and the ability for a Roth101k

Con: Pay is subpar to every other company in Finance. Promised promotions and advancement into investment roles however they only give those were only given to Ivy League graduates or through nepotism. Not worth your time after 2 years empty promises and no following through. Need ti be a Johnson or a graduate of Harvard or MIT to get anywhere waste of 5 years of my career.
Summary: "Good experience then a big political debacle."

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Anonymous has a lot of legacy software and hardware platforms, so it's not the place to be if you are interested in getting experienced with newer technologies or automation. Anonymous is addicted to faulty systems which require high levels of maintenance and manual effort, because they can get them "cheaply" through volume discounts and enterprise licensing. Approximately 15% of your time on the job will be required for mandatory "ethics" and "compliance" training, double-recording your time and work results in disconnected, deficient, and faulty systems. The ethics training is as much a joke as the company's stated values, which include honesty. As long as you aren't tossing midgets or taking kickbacks, honesty is not even valued (especially amongst management), much less promoted in ANY way. I personally know of managers who are told by upper management to lie to their employees. I'm not sure how "ethics" can even exist in such an inherently dishonest environment.

By the time you complete all of the "mandatory training" and administrative tasks required, you will be lucky to have 60% of your time left to do your job. They will schedule enough meetings to consume another 20% of your time, but management will still treat it as 100%.  Of course, while trying to complete your job tasks in this remaining 40% of your time, you will also be expected to train offshore staff how to do your job.  The offshore staff is culturally trained to say "yes" to everything and then delivering on 10-20% of what they promise.  But it's okay, because they are perceived as being "cheap labor", even though they can't seem to work independently and require that you do about 40% of the job for them.  A significant amount of time on the job is also wasted "shifting gears", as management is largely incompetent and doesn't understand the costs associated with changing your mind and focus constantly. Often, fake deadlines are created and things given an overblown sense of importance to pressure employees into working late. Many times I have arrived at work and started to work on an "important" task perhaps less than 1 hour in duration and still struggled to focus through the constant interruptions to complete this before the end of the work day, which is often late into the evening. My boss interrupts me 6 - 8 times a day for "emergencies", and then becomes upset because "he doesn't know what I am working on".

Penny-wise and pound foolish, Anonymous purchases systems based solely on the purchase price and doesn't seem to know the 1st thing about TCO (Total Cost of Ownership).  They build lavish and expensive bathrooms, while looking for ways to cut expense reimbursement, benefits, and bonuses, while they make billions shipping American jobs overseas. They have contributed significantly to the infrastructure and economy in India while they add to the unemployment lines domestically.

Talk about a hostile work environment! Making your boss look good here is the only thing that counts. The company's core values are an absolute joke, as is their dental plan, "ethics", and "compliance" training. Rather than focus on getting results, motivating employees and doing the right thing, managers spend their time sneaking up behind employees to see what's on their computer screen. If they see a similar screen that might have been there 2 hours before, the assumption is made that you have done nothing else within that 2 hour period, even though there are electronic records of all systems usage. Why check when it's easier for them to assume?

If you are technically incompetent and can lie like a politician, there is a comfy home for you in management at Anonymous. Once you're a member in this exclusive club, it's all about you and other than committing career-icide through political folly, there will be nothing you can do wrong. 

Also, if you ever want to invest on your own, Anonymous will make sure that whatever gains you might make will be more than offset by the paperwork, administrative hassles and threats to your employment status from their "compliance" department. And that's only IF they pre-approve every trade that you make.
Summary: "A lot of manual effort from disconnected systems and lack of information goes into completing daily work."
Pro: It's a good way to get a wide variety of experiences and assignments. There is always so much that's broken, so it's ripe with opportunities for improvement. There is a high frequency of change, which can also be challenging.  The environment at Anonymous is very friendly for those who work and play well with others regardless of how poorly you do your job. Overall, a pretty safe environment.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: During the economic slowdown, the culture became ruthless.  It's a fight to remain standing and a fight between people that should be on the same time.  I am happy to have left and don't know anyone who is happy to stay on.

Also, the HR function is practically non-existent for many of the lower levels (except for transactional support from a shared service area).
Pro: During bull markets Anonymous can offer many opportunities to grow, gain new experience, and receive decent monetary rewards.   Since the great recession like many large firms, the company continues to reduce management layers and discover that it can deliver quality service with less resources.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
I find there is a complete lack of respect for the regular employee.  Very low pay and bonus's for most employees. As you move up with in the company a culture of superiority is fostered and encouraged. You have royalty and the peasants. 



Most middle management  has been brainwashed and this is their only professional experience, thus they think and act a like.....very scary if you've worked anywhere else.  If you ever express an opinion or disagree with those folks.....you're permanently branded.  You can do that with the highest levels of management and it would be respected (they are far away and only get to visit a few times a year). 



Employee turnover is unbelievably high (this is good for creating opportunity), however, it's a reflection of how employees are treated.  Management encourages people to be given warnings  to increase job performance vs. rewarding them.   



e.g. You have 10 business goals. You could be doubling your results with nine of them, however, you're just below goal with one that's not up on the list of importantance.  Instead of averaging out your overall performance, they will focus on that one thing again and again. The person who just barely made the goal with all 10 is far better than you are.



The company will waste money and spend lavishly all for show but a great majority of employees don't benefit from this.
Pro:
Great company/reputation for your resume. Very nice101k match and profit sharing. Bonus's are great if you're in the top3-10% of the company.  I believe Senior management is very good. The Johnson family has been good.



Kathy Murphy was a great addition to the company.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: You won't get any significant raises unless you make it your priority to move departments when you can. This requires you to apply and search for internal jobs constantly, which I have seen work for some people. To sum it up, there is no autonomy in your job. From the start, they want you to buy into the "Anonymous Culture." However, they have the money to spend to be a successful company - at least for the short term. So if you want job security this is the place for you. If you're looking for autonomy in your job and play an active role in the company you work for, I suggest you look elsewhere.
Summary: "Anonymous sucks for me, will it for you?"
Pro: Job security. For the most part it takes a lot to be laid off or fired.  Benefits are good, which include profit sharing, access to HSA/Health Flex accounts, etc.

Con: There are countless opportunities for advancement, but Anonymous has done away with most opportunities for actual pay raises.  All job opportunities are positioned as "Stepping up and contributing to the needs of the business", with vague promises of "potential merit increases" which never come to fruition, or "increased bonus opportunity", which likewise never comes to fruition.  Raises are only given for major job promotions, such as from manager to director, and even then they are minimal.
Summary: "Big on Vision and Teamwork, Small on Compensation"
Pro: If you enjoy a team environment working with other highly motivated and intelligent individuals, Anonymous is a wonderful place to work.  The company survives on a high level of commitment from its employees, and has been incredibly successful as a result, even posting record profits during the worst recession of our time.  Particularly during the first couple of years out of college, Anonymous can be a rewarding and educational place to work.  Most people consider FIdelity a good training ground for better jobs in the industry that pay a decent salary.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: The culture can be highly stressful at the best of times but numerous Reductions in Force (RIF's) over the past several years have impacted morale and compounded the stress level.  Entire groups have been RIFed, regardless of the criticality of their function or their individual performance ratings.  I know of numerous high-quality, highly respected people who have been let go as part of the on-going re-org, so performance, dedication and a good review rating won't save you from a RIF if your group is a focus.  Reviews for bonuses and raises seem to be based less on performance than on the corporate review paradigm, which dictates that a manager must assign a specific number of satisfactory, sub-standard and outstanding ratings (example - a manager with 10 direct reports can be given the directive that of their 10 direct reports, they must have 1 employee rated sub-standard and only 1 rated outstanding.  The other 8 must be rated Proficient/Satisfactory, regardless of performance.  Due to Fido having such a high number of exceptionally bright and dedicated people, who step up when they see a problem, it is fairly common to find groups where the majority (if not all) of the team members deserve an Outstanding rating.  With the existing paradigm, only 1 can receive that rating and receive a fair bonus/raise.  Eight of the others will receive a Proficient/Satisfactory rating and receive very small bonus/raises.  And one of those 10 people will receive a rating of  N ('Needs Improvement'), which prohibits a raise/bonus and tags them as a probability for the next RIF - and you can't internally transfer if you received a rating of N).  Promotions are also tied to review ratings.  Before I left, the policy was that an employee had to receive 2 consecutive reviews of above Satisfactory/Proficient to qualify for a possible promotion.  That did not ensure they would receive the promotion, it just meant that they qualified for a possible promotion, if one was available.  There is little to no work/life balance and based on the review paradigm, there is no financial incentive for regularly sacrificing your personal life to protect their reputation and business interest.
Pro: Anonymous employs some of the brightest, most innovative and dedicated people in the industry.  The culture is high energy and fast-paced so you'll never be bored.  Most people are willing to step up and share their expertise while fighting fires (if you know which group/s and which person, within that group, to ask).  Most people in support/ops are required to work an excessive number of hours each week (usually 60+) but you can learn more at Anonymous in 1 year than you would learn at another investment firm.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Middle and upper management appears to have no idea where they are trying to steer the company, so the company swings from taking an idea to the extreme to a complete 180. Today they may be focusing on customer satisfaction and personalizing the interaction and in a few months decide to strip down customer interactions to scripted nonsense.



There are very few outlets for good ideas to arrive at implementation. Although there are feedback channels that may from time to time result in small changes, the bigger process issues or customer/client issues are completely controlled from the top by people who don't understand (and at times take pride in not knowing) what they manage so they don't know how to recognize or fix problems. So something may be a problem for years before somebody decides to do something about it, and even then the "solution" may aggravate the problem.



Anonymous is very political. Anonymous is obsessed today with it's brand image to the public, but one thing that is always constant at Anonymous is the constant obsession about your "brand". Gossip is taken as gospel and can ruin your brand in a second. What people have to say about you will override your performance in virtually all cases. Many managers would rather sink one of their employee's opportunity for advancement to be able to keep that person's performance in their numbers. A lot of backstabbing and stealing credit occurs.



There's not a lot of advancement opportunity. When the economy was great in 2007 it wasn't that hard. If you were great in your job, you could move on to a slightly better position, and when you did well there, you could move to another slightly improved position, until you were where you wanted to be. Once the economy crashed in 2008 that all stopped. I get it. That happened everywhere. However, it also stopped all discussions of professional development and no effort was made to give opportunities to develop skills for the current role or another. As a result, future promotion will be very difficult because internal candidates won't be as competitive against external candidates.



Recruiting/HR and their processes are absurd. It can take months after applying for a position before you get an interview. You can apply for a role, not hear anything for several months, and then get an email that you have an interview the next day. So you end up with no opportunity to prepare and made no efforts to prepare because you never heard anything back. Feedback from interviews rarely exists or is very generic. Hiring managers are lazy and don't follow through. 



For every great manager there are ten clueless unhelpful managers. It's obvious that middle and upper management have no idea how to manage their people because there's very little accountability or responsibility on the part of front-line managers. Directors believe yelling at people is the only way to manage, so they will yell at their managers when the numbers are bad, and that's pretty much the extent of direction or vision executed at the management level. I have heard several managers complain that they don't feel it's right that their performance is judged based on the performance of the people they manage. Well, that's what managers are there to do. If they aren't managing towards success, then they aren't doing a great job. I understand there are low performers, etc. but when I see managers playing ping pong for hours in the break room, there's not a lot of accountability in the system.



There's a lot of infighting between different business units. Everybody points fingers but nobody takes ownership over problems and fixes them. Customers and employees get stuck in the middle with no way to get out.



Anonymous no longer places a premium on its talent. Since 2008 the company has eliminated whole business groups with no effort to keep around people with tenure with tremendous transferrable skills. It does very little to help grow talent or keep it from leaving. Where a few years ago employees were loyal to the company and that loyalty was returned, the company has completely eliminated that loyalty. As a result, the company keeps losing great talent and keeps hiring new people who underperform and embarass those of us who strive to be great at our jobs. 



While all of the above things are common among businesses and I have, as most people, experienced similar trends at other jobs, what I will point out is that these problems were not institutionalized in a company that performs with mediocrity and accepts laziness in its overall perforamce. Anonymous is a top competitior in its markets and a lot of its strength historically came from the loyalty to and from its employees. Anonymous has worked very hard to treat its employees with indifference and management -- from the very top -- has set the company afloat with no real vision or guidance other than keep trying to make things that don't work struggle to work.
Summary: "Easy to get in, hard to move up"
Pro:
Anonymous does a lot of solid training, considerably more than a lot of competitors in the field. 



Benefits are very good. Pay is a little less at Anonymous but when you consider benefits in the compensation package it is competitive.



Workplace environment is reasonably professional and not stuffy.



For the most part front-line managers are willing to work with associates to find a favorable resolution to personal issues.



Managers don't throw you under the bus to customers just to make the customer feel better about a problem.



There are some great employees and managers who care about the customer and care about the employees.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Inconsistency between groups, as the company is quite large (~40,000 employees.) It sometimes felt like employees in a different group were experiencing an entirely different work environment, almost as if they were in a different company.
Pro: Within my group, there was an amazing sense of camaraderie and support. I felt like I was part of a high-performing team who liked to see results, but have fun at the same time. Even though I was an intern, my opinions were always respected and I never felt like a lesser member of the group.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Very poor salary, bonuses, and raises.  There isn't a lot of opportunity to move within the company.  Everything is driven by leads and acquiring new business whether you are in a sales function or not.  If you don't want to go into sales you won't ever be given the chance to even interview for the job within the company you would excel at.  Management does a poor job of using the talent they have within the company to fill the positions where it is needed.
Pro: Very good benefits, strong101K matching and profit sharing plans.  You get a pretty good amount of vaction after the first few years.  Anonymous seems like a pretty ethical place to work at with good people from good backgrounds.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: They do not support their employees in any way
Pro: benefits are good and they do train to pass the series 7 and 63 and get paid for it

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Corporate infighting, and some of the downsides of working at a large firm.  Adequate compensation just isn't there at the associate level.
Summary: "Company does not have a clear direction"
Pro: Benefits at Anonymous are great, but are more structured towards the long term.  Most of the management are long-termers, so while there is some political in-fighting, it's mostly limited and directed towards the "newcomers" in management.  Good and bad, depending which side of the coin you fall on.  Not a bank, but still nice to be privately owned in this environment.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Everything else, nepotism was king.  Meritocracy died a lonely death a long time ago.  Large meetings were sessions of the "blame game" with discussions about how things should be "moving forward".  X Y scatter plots are not to be used in presentations, even if they are the only sane way to display the information.  We love pie, and pie charts.
Summary: "Did a summer internship there.  Dilbert became less a joke and more of a documentary after."
Pro: Paid very well, silly but nice perks with things like a gym with personal trainers and pretty nice cafeteria.  Nicely maintained grounds.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Not many opportunities to move horizontally across the company.
Pro: Good work/life balance, average salary with great benefits (especially after3 years to fully vest).
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Your success at Anonymous will depend largely on the ability of your manager to steer you within the maze and to protect you from the political environment. Don't stay in any one area/unit/department for too long as you will become "type cast."  This is not a paternalistic environment; do not expect to be taken care of. This employer typifies the characterization of the "disposable employee." They have a reputation for re-organizing every six months. This is, if not literally, virtually true. You must be very flexible and not cling to the past. Upper management is currently (May 2010) in a state of upheaval that has been ongoing for perhaps 5 years. Continuity and vision is lacking.
Pro: Anonymous is a strong company with a streak of independence allowed by private ownership. Good product recognition. Solid and very conservative with respect to financial responsibility. Many opportunities for career growth, change and diversity if you are able to adopt the culture. Good availability of resources including career education. Better than average compensation and benefits.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Very reactive to market change, can't seem to get comp right for branch sales, poor communication from the top management
Summary: "Benefits are good, many management changes in the last few years."
Pro: Solid profit sharing and benefits, many opportunities in phone sites.  You can make a career out of it if you don't mind limited growth
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: The company can be slow moving sometimes, positive changes and feedback seem to be planned but take a long time to get acted on.  Career advancement past client focused or operations jobs will probably require you to relocate.
Summary: "Decent place to work, employees treated well"
Pro: Decent place to work, employees treated well and there are good opportunities within Salt Lake although these are some what stacked towards direct contact with clients.  During busy times there is a lot of flexibility with overtime.

Con: Layoffs have been going on for the past few years.  Moral is very low and many areas are overworked because of the past reductions.
Pro: The large company offers several levels of responsibility, this gives you an opportunity for advancement.  The salaries are alright but the benefits are great.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: In the call center, you can get stuck on a shift that you don't want.  Granted, because of the economy there isn't a lot of hiring, but there doesn't seem to be any opportunity for us to advance or even any concern by management to develop us for future roles.
Pro: Pay is decent, benefits are great
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: I dread every single day I have to go into work. All you do is take phone calls all day long you are literally tied to the phone like a leash. You are expected to ACHEIVE on every phone call like you are a robot with a script to read. This job is horrible. if you are thinking about working here run away!!!! I wish i was told what is was really like before I interviewed. Anonymous may be ok to work at if you are working off the phones, but on the phones is a living hell.
Pro: Good benefits and thats about it.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Whatever pay they promise will be total fiction. Layoffs happen monthly(for the last 2 years!). Most everyone is trying to get you fired, especially at bonus time. Bonuses, raises, and long term comp are often cut even when the company has record profits. Senior managers live in fear of the Family and will throw you under the bus if it helps them. We have a saying: the bullet that will kill you has already been fired, it is just a matter of when it will catch up to you. And I say this as someone who has been successful here and still am. Politics exist everywhere, but this place is a viper pit. Many, many successful execs have been hired and fired in under a year simply because the old guard decided to poison the well on them. Unless you started here twenty years ago or are part of The Family, you are dead. No manager will ever extend his personal political capital to save you.
Pro: If you are lazy and dim, you might be overpaid by a large amount long enough to accumulate real wealth. The name carries weight on your resume. Because of the very high turnover, you might get promoted into a vacancy, but will not have to worry about the pressure of higher pay.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Anonymous use to be the BEST place to work and the most respected company in the industry.  To have Anonymous on your resume gave you the advantage over the competition.  However, that all changed in 2007.  The company culture, benefits structure and management style changed suddenly and negatively impacted clients and employees.  The company has considerable market share and has been wobbling ever since, trying to determine a direction to steer, go public, sell businesses piece by piece, not succession plan, etc.  I blame Roger Lawson for the down turn, but perhaps that was his purpose.  In 2010, the company still  has no clear direction and their current employees are not high the mgmt's priority.  The constant state of layoffs and restructure proves a detriment to moral and productivity.  Where is Ned?
Pro: If you can keep at job at Anonymous, that woud be a "pro"
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
You're not going to get an FTE position, never mind keep one if you have it. They've pushed out almost all the competent managers, and have stuck individual contributors as "perma-temps" with horrible/no benefits. The "perma-temp" medical plans stop paying at $5000 even though advertised as $50,000, so don't plan on getting sick or injured.  FTE to "perma-temp" ratio is the worst I've seen in 15 years there.



Reorgs coming fast and furious. 4 Managers in 1 year. Raleigh was to be the new Tech HQ and now there are no managers left there, just bodyshop L1 Visa holders, perma-temps of their captive Veritude "temp" agency, and a few FTEs. Hundreds laid off again just this past week across the company, following last year's 10% 4000 person cut, and several "stealth layoffs" between then and now. Most of the very experienced people, especially if they are over 40, have been dumped. 



There is absolutely no sense to who they're dumping, if they were sincerely still trying to run and grow the company. They're just cleaning up the balance sheet to make the company's financials look good, in my opinion. 



The old-school Wall Streeters who came in to take over from the long-term Boston exec mgmt have now themselves started bailing out of the firm. There's nothing left of last year's 5-year plan except the souvenir mouse pads showing the cartoon of the transformation plan. On which we had to take mandatory training!
Pro: Very few left. If you're an FTE "regular employee" they still have a great benefit package: excellent health plan,101k with match, profit-sharing.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: difficult to move up in the company quickly, very large company with lots of expected bureaucracy, high turnover in executive management
Pro: Intelligent people, access to all the resources I need to do my job, fast paced work environment, pay for performance

Con: Bonus has never been what I was promised at the beginning, it is controlled by upper management who do not know and work with the lower level employees. They are more concerned with controlling their budgets, rather than rewarding and developing talented people. Difficult to get interesting and challenging projects, management is guarding their turf and does not delegate. Which is understandable, considering the constant threat of layoffs. If you are eager to advance, have varying assignments, get exposure to high visibility projects and rise quickly on the career ladder, this is NOT the place for you...unless you have really good connections and/or a senior exec family member. If you are, however, content with 9 to 5, easy, mindless work, go for it.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Management has nothing but contempt for employees.  This is across the board.  Management practices are abusive.  I have personally heard a VP refer to his department as a "factory" and his staff as "work horses", and he has been promoted 3 times since then.  Hard work is expected and pay for performance is not a reality at Anonymous.  You work crazy hours to succeed and don'd get paid for it, recognized, and when the bonus cycle comes they wont pay out.  Dont fall for the bonus mumbo jumbo, Anonymous has not paid out its bonuses in the past 2 years.  Youll be lucky if you get 1/6 of the amount they promise you at your interview.  Get your money in your base on your way in the door.  No exit interviews as a corporate policy: they know they are everything I have said and they dont want to hear about it or learn from it.  In my department 4 people have resigned in the past 4 months, some without jobs to go to, others for better opportunities.
Pro: If you are fresh out of college, spend a year here at most then move on quickly.  As the company declines further even this recommendation is only valid until1011.  However, you can learn a lot here.  The Profit Sharing is a good benefit and tuition reimbursement is good, but all in all the rest of the bennies are pretty comparable to everyone else.  Long term at Anonymous is career suicide.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: It required a lot of effort to catch up with the hours and it was too crowded to be able to show yourself to managers to go up.
Pro: it gave a great opportunity to improve Analytical and communicative skills, especially for someone who just started a professional career.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: This company is horribly inefficient. Senior management changes frequently and with those changes is always a reorganization and change of strategy. Anonymous chose RTP in NC as the home for their $100  million dollar new facility and planned to add 2000 + jobs. They started off strong - bought the land, moved hundreds of folks down from Boston and then pulled the plug and decided they would rather operate in TX and other parts of MA. With hundreds of families making a committment to relocate for the company, leaving family, selling their homes in a bad housing market and taking losses on the moves and home sales - most that relocated were laid off before their 1st year finished in the 'new' location. Folks that relocated without a relocation package paid thousands of dollars to get to NC for the company - and the company decided to change strategy and then laid these same 'committed' employees off. Many folks made personal sacrafices for Anonymous - and the company just hung their employees out to dry. Very deceitful company - provides little information to the employees - and what is communicated is mostly not accurate/honest. The culture is highly politicized and very back-stabbing as the company has so many layoffs everyone is always trying to make the other guy look bad in hopes of saving their own position.
Summary: "Deceitful Management; Reckless Decision Making; Terribly Inefficient"
Pro: Pays is fair and when bonus and profit sharing is funded - compensation is fair.

Summary: "Large privately held corporation with talented hard working people."

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con:
If you decide to work at Anonymous, make sure you like change -- there lots of it here (or Kaisan as the chairman calls it) especially within leadership.  Often times a new manager is brought in with a new "strategic vision" and you basically discard all the work you've done over the past 9 months and start over...this can happen again and again and can be frustrating...



I worked in several different business units during my 9 years with the company, and because the company is simply so huge, I found that if you have a good manager, you'll have a pleasant experience and receive appropriate performance and financial reviews and feedback, etc. BUT if your manager is one of many who are not good at being managers or for whatever reason don't "click" with you, it can become a miserable experience. HR tends to side with management, and it's extremely difficult to remove an incompetent or toxic boss from Anonymous.  Normally, you can weed these individuals out during your interview, but as I mentioned previously, Anonymous re-orgs so frequently, 90% of individuals hired end up working for different managers and doing different work than they signed on to do.  



You need to be prepared to roll with the punches and have a very flexible nature if you choose to work at Anonymous.



As far as promotional opportunity, there's no set rule such as after 2 years, you get promoted - i've seen individuals be promoted after 6 months or never promoted after many, many years.  Because your individual manager basically exclusively drives the promotion process, making sure he/she likes you is key.  When it comes to advancement, doing good work is often secondary to building a good relationship with your direct manager.
Summary: "Your Experience at Anonymous Varies Depending on Your Manager; CONSTANT reorganization"
Pro: Benefits, including tuition reimbursement,101K match, and annual bonuses are excellent; for the most part, it is a stable place to work, earn a good salary and interact with nice, smart people.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: You need to be able to network to uncover career opportunities. If you produce results then it is a great company but if you are not a consistent producer- start packing your bags.

Con:

You can literally perform with absolute excellence all year and still be rated average...after all the managers are all under pressure to meet the numbers and submit ratings within the allotted quotas. So...it the whole department had a banner year don't think the whole department is rewarded...this would never happen and it's grossly unfair. You're expected to suck it up and move on...until the next layoff then you're gone. Who needs that!!!

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: I am in customer service so I've been getting burned out by the demanding customer expectations and Anonymous's policy that the "customer is always right".  I notice the sales roles have experienced greater pressure to fulfill goals due to the economy.  We have been short staffed for a long time, and they are slow to fill the roles (either internally or externally, and competition is FIERCE) puting added pressure and stress on the remaining employees.
Pro: Salary is lower than industry standard, but made up for by benefit packages and little perks (fitness reimbursement, computer assistance, etc.) Great place to learn the ropes of the industry, sales techniques, etc.  Stable company, constantly changing internally to evolve with economy or client investment demand.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Since the first day I've been there, it's felt like we're in elementary school or some nice form of a concentration camp.  You are almost told verbatim what to say.  The call model is a decent model, but management needs to understand that not every call is worth the whole effort.  Not client needs our guidance services, not everyone is an active trader.  



Also, there is a large amount of knowledge that is needed.  Not that it is necessarily a bad thing, but the environment is horrible.  There are several different computer programs we use for various things.  One for trading, one for problem resolution, one for money movement.  A small mistake or overlook is looked heavily down upon.  If, God forbid, you make a "trade error," you are reprimanded even if it had little to no impact on the company (I've also had trade errors that made the company money).  



Even if the mistake was question that 99 out of 100 people don't know about how our internal systems work, there is supposedly always an answer in OLR.  It stands for OnLine Reference.  It's basically the Anonymous bible for trading and service.  Problem is that OLR must have been written by either a mad robot or Ned Johnson himself.  It's not written well at all and even sometimes contain mistakes that we still "should have known."  



We are given several metrics that we must meet that grade us on various call aspects; these include: average call time, scheduling efficiency (how closely you fit into a minute by minute schedule daily), and % of time either in available to talk to on a call.  



As reps we are expected to "put the customer first" at all times.  They should really rephrase that to "put the customer first only on that phone call."  After the call ends, so does any contact that we have with that person.  Why is this a problem?  About 25% of the calls you take are problems that may take awhile to fix.  There is no researching or following up on problems after the call.  Managers criticize calling back customers.  



Also, about 92% of managers are really horrible people.
Pro: Pay is decent for young college grads; also good benefits.101k - they potentially match up to 17% after some tenure,  Most of the people you work with are decent people.  Almost everyone realizes it's not the most exciting or fulfilling job; it's like everyone's in the same boat.  We can always connect with each other based upon bad calls we've had or some worthless reprimand from management.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: The company is very particular about expenditure in recent years and is ready to move employees to other locations to cut costs.
Pro: The company is proud to follow bleeding-edge technologies for its products. There's good learning learning in new technologies. The company is also proud to share and educate about its systems architecture design as part of employee training.

People are wonderful to work with...and for....for the most part.

Advancement is possible when YOU WORK for it

Educational opportunities abound!  

Will hire without a college degree

Great benefits!
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: In recent years the company has created an atmosphere that seems to breed hostility and a need to put others down in order to keep a manager happy. No knowledge sharing because the general feeling is, if I don't tell anyone else, they cannot take my job away. Does not work, your job is probably going overseas anyway. Overseas not held to the standards stateside employees are. So it's not perfect, no problem. Not a way I ever thought Anonymous would behave.
Summary: "Anonymous has changed, but not for the better."
Pro: Benefits were very good. In the early years there were people to share knowledge and people cared about one another. Back then it was possible to move ahead based on your work ethic and accomplishments.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Sometimes you have a hard time catching your breath.
Summary: "They are very nice to deal with, but they overwork people.  Every single minute has to be accounted for."
Pro: They pay well and if you are smart, punctual, worker bee type and do not like to take time off this is the place to make money.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: They are cutting back the benefits.  No raise this year, cutting profit sharing, no bonus, changed the way they rank the employees for reviews.
Pro: Food pay and benefits when I was hired.  Good location.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: You don't own clients, captive environment, very political, don't think just sell
Pro: As good a place as any to work in retail financial sales
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Pay is not great seems like they should pay better for a professional position.  Yearly raises are small and moving between positions is about 5% bump if anything.
Summary: "My thoughts on working at Anonymous for 5 years"
Pro: Bennefits the101k match and profit sharing are great.  Good place to get some experience in the financial services industry when you are first getting started.  They also pay for your training and licensing.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: with the phones are schedules are dictated by a console...so a 15 min break can't be more or less. Unpaid lunch without the option of not taking a lunch. Not enough money!
Summary: "Anonymous needs to show me the money!"
Pro: 401k match of 7%, profit sharing, medical/dental/vision benefits, even know we offered Roth101k to our clients for the past year or more just last week we now get to participate...why so long?...voluntary time off unpaid but useful when you need time off for appointments/vacation. I've liked my managers! People are cool for the most part!
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: A lot of turmoil and politics, management has good talks, but don't really follow up on their words and policies.
Pro: Even though it is not the same company as it was 10 year ago it is still a good place to work if you have a drive and can work in fast paced and volatile environment
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Poor communication between groups due to organizational silos.  Upper management focus is on short-term success, not long-term growth. When times get bad it's every man for himself!
Summary: "Company only looking at immediate bottom line ... no long-term view."
Pro: Working with talented individuals.  Salaries and benefits are above average.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: too many politiics and hard to get recognition for hard work, limited opportunity for advancement and the office conditions were cubicle hell
Pro: large technology investment so they were moving in every direction at once, recognizable brand so it looks good on your resume

Pro: A place with strong work ethics and values.  I know that the work that I do matters for our customers.  I have learned much during the eleven years I have been working there.

Con: Not a place to be looking for promotions right now but where is?  Consensus environment and many silo's make forward progress slow.

Pro: do not appreciate how luckty they are to owrk here and how high the quality of work life is.  People are top notch.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Poor work/life balance.

Management treated me like a piece of disposable waste from day one!

I think given the size and complexities of this organization, it would take a total restructuring to accomplish and as I said previously, old management can't cut it.
Pro:

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: your tied to your cubicle on the phone..not much freedom during the work hours, everything is scheduled...micromanaged
Pro: Pay for the liscencing and training, a good way to get a quick introduction into the financial services world...they pay and train you while you get real life experience...good benefit package
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Very paranoid atmosphere and constant reorganizations make for too much time spent on sucking up and positioning for the next reorg.  Most of the bosses I worked for were not very dynamic or interesting people you can learn from.   More interested in using their employees to shield their shortcomings.
Pro: Up until recently the pay, bonus and shares program were very good.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: The culture is very political.  Your manager may have been hired becuase of a realtionship he/she had with a director or VP not becuase they were great at their job.  Anonymous is not a place for great managers or leaders of people.  Since the introduction of Six Sigma Anonymous has become an assembly line, you have your job to do and I have my job to do and I will not help you becuase I may be held responsibel if something goes wrong.
Pro: The people I have worked with for the past 10 years have been great and have made it easy to come to work.  In the beginning there were many perks and management really made you feel good about working at Anonymous.  The campus is beautiful.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Promotions based on who you know.

Get time off when you need it,

Decent pay raises.

Con: With the overhaul at the executive levels from 2007 onwards, and the revolving door of external hires at the highest levels, the frequency of organizational and strategic changes became intense.  Major layoffs took place in 2008 and early 2009, due in part (but not entirely) to the market turmoil.  The whole financial services field has been downsizing, so think carefully before you apply for a job at Anonymous if the stock market is still very rocky.  Be prepared to manage your career and build a good network.  Have a "Plan B" ready in case you get laid off.
Summary: "New leaders across firm changing the culture"
Pro: I loved the people I worked with at Anonymous - smart, creative, hardworking, fun.  Most people care about the customer and work hard to provide great service.  Operations and Technology groups had many talented individuals and middle managers, but lacked a cohesive strategy and strong SVP management.  I had excellent training opportunities and career progression.  Anonymous was a great company for the 15 years I worked there.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: If you are not one of the director's or VP's favorites, don't expect a good raise or bonus. It helps to rent a vacation house near the VP's vacation residence.
Pro: The 7%101k match is great, as long as it lasts. Anonymous is cutting everthing else, so I don't anticipate this to last.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Full of processes.  It's hard to get things done with so much gatekeepers who need to approve anything that you do.
Pro: Comprehensive benefits which include101k matching, profit sharing, year end bonus, health care, etc.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Tough industry during down economy. Sometimes a thankless job.
Pro: Benefits, communication with internal employees about important events. Challenge of the job.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: It's a rat race. You always have impossible goals, and are reminded daily when you are not where you should be.
Pro: THey pay is nice, hours aren't to bad..
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Sometimes you have to wonder how some colleagues in senior level positions ever got to where they are in the company.
Pro:
- Anonymous's downtown location can not be beat.  

- It's a great stepping stone for college graduates who want to work in the financial industry as there are (were) many job opportunities within the company.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
What the heck happened since Roger Lawson came on board two years ago???!?!??!? Deteriorating from the inside.. and fast. Hack job management and direction setting at highest level(s) of management. Right hand doesn't know what the left is doing.... whack 20% of best people based on "secret sauce magic formula" in recent layoffs -- meanwhile setting new strategic direction in the areas which they just cut the top performers.

Ridiculous.

Firm has a stranglehold on employees financial life - and by extension the rest of employee's family also. Red tape upon red tape to make trades in personal ROTH or investment accounts - and onerous disclosure requirements (4 times a year) to meet a standard intended for Fund managers - not Sysadmins.

Morale in the tank. Lowest I've ever seen it in 11+ years. Excellent environment if you want to ensure you retain the poor talent and ensure the best talent leaves the company.

For example: Keep putting out ungodly levels of production.. and oh, by the way - no merit raises regardless of your rating or value to the firm -- and year end bonus (a significant incentive to reach stated goals) is a big question mark. Therefore highest performers treated exactly the same as poorest performers.

Attitude of "Where else are you going to go? There are no jobs right now." ... Ha! Just watch.
Pro: Well known brand and respected reputation in the industry (Financial Services). My personal manager and other low- to mid-range managers of highest caliber and integrity.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Terrible work environment in their call center. Treated like a machine and little tolerance for mistakes.
Pro: Good benefits and paid time off. There are opportunities to advance but in order to do so you basically have to be a perfect employee in the the eyes of management. Not worth the time trying to be a customer service rep when managers are constantly looking over your shoulder.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Low morale, little room for advancement, poor work/life balance, little regard for employees.  Poor lower and middle management that's insecure and willing to burn out their direct reports in order to keep their own jobs.
Summary: "Perpetual reorganizations & layoffs caused them to shed their best talent & left behind mgmt. that disdains employees."
Pro: 401(k) match - There's not much else.  The thing I hear most from my coworkers is that this used to be a great place to work, and now it's just a job... just a paycheck.  I keep hearing people say that they can't wait for the economy to recover so they can find a job elsewhere.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Senior management is totally out of touch with the fact that morale is at an all time low and they are the reason.  We are a ship adrift at sea with no direction.  When Ned was fully in charge it was a much better place to work.
Summary: "A shame what has happened to this once great company."
Pro: I have none to offer.5 years ago I would have said a good place to work.  10 years ago a great place to work.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Beware of office politics.



The system they have in place for measuring productivity is hugely flawed.



Branch Managers enjoy a great deal of power.

BM's don't really do much besides interview candidates.
Pro:
If you're in sales, there's a very clear path to follow.



You can have your eyes on a promotion starting on day one.



The pay is about on par with the rest of the industry but the101k match and profit sharing at Anonymous are pretty hard to beat.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Management is not honest with employees about current situation of the company and compensation outlook; there has been significant turnover in Anonymous C-suite, and it is unclear what direction the company is heading; limited real time feedback on how well you are doing your job.
Summary: "Good place to work when they want it to be"
Pro: Anonymous is one of the only equity research jobs where an undergrad can immediately become a lead analyst on10+ companies with good access to top management of the companies they are researching.  There is also a strong history of talent that you will be surrounded by.  Pay is fair to good for the job.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: It had become a bloated company with too many senior level people (a number without staff to manage). Additionally, I believe the review process could use overhauling (mixed signals on ratings/ranking) coming from HR and the department management.
Summary: "Despite the recent events, all in all a good place to be"
Pro: With respect to the changes being made due to the economic downturn, through1008 the benefits package was outstanding in my opinion.  Health care was well covered. Salary, bonus and profit sharing was a nice combo.  Additionally,  the work/family balance was very nice and there was a high level of flexibility.  I also liked the number of community volunteer activities that you could choose from.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Office politics.  Unfocused idea of where the company is going.  Upper mgmnt to quick to use layoffs to change bottom line.
Pro: Excellent benefits (medical,101k, vacation, education).  Overall good corporate culture.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Tend to focus on strategy and business plans and not on execution and getting things done.
Pro: Typically take a long term approach to business. Not worried about hitting quarterly numbers like public firms.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: It is still a cubical farm. There is a lot of corporate non-sense that you have to put up with. There are still some unqualified, and not-so-great managers who sneak in to their positions from other companies. Hard to move up right now of course w/ the hiring freeze and the economy in general. We just went through a reorg so it was very unfun to work here for the last few months, but things are getting back on track now that the panic has subsided a bit.
Summary: "Great company, good opportunities when the economy permits"
Pro: This is a great company to work for. Smart, caring people (for the most part), great benefits, lots of extras, beautiful facilities and great managers (for the most part). This, at least my department, is pretty laid back and it runs very smoothly. Low stress job.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Too much red tape and constant micro-managing can be suffocating.
Summary: "Good and bad things but that is everywhere..."
Pro: Great benefits and the ability to move and grow within the company are the best reasons to work for Anonymous.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Compensation is at the low end for the financial industry in service, sales and management. There is no exposure to outside sales, no cold calling. This is a con because it makes moving to another company a bit of a shock.
Summary: "Anonymous is a great place to start a career in the financial industry and can be a great place to make a career."
Pro: Great management, employees and customers. Plenty of opportunity to learn the industry. Career opportunities in management and sales. Benefits are excellent. Privately held company which makes for a great environment.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: This is not a place where they let people sit all day long doing nothing. 8+ hours a day is normal and often work over time.
Pro: cutting edge technologies to work with, lot of room to learn and grow if you are a starter.  People are professional and talented, great team work among the groups to get the work done.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: The use of call flows is like being a robot. You can't really help the customers on the call's because of the liability Anonymous feels comes back on them, in my opinion. However, I don't think Anonymous really encourages there employee's in CSS to be better at helping customers with Investment Education calls.
Summary: "Anonymous is a Great Place to Launch a Career"
Pro: Anonymous (CSS ) is a great place to launch your career. There is alot of support and systems that are in place to ensure you are successful. Anonymous is a great place for wholesome people who want to work and a friendly, family-oriented environement. Its not the place for a gunslinger who wants some action. Wrong culture.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Ownership has let too many outsiders come in and has not protected internal employees. Many top leaders have been allowed to leave. This is completely opposite their prior approach. People have to work very hard to succeed with little reward or recognition. 55-60 hour weeks are not uncommon and are expected. Management does not prioritize and simply jump from one focus to the next with no continuity. They do not allow an idea or effort to develop and show results. Refuse to ask the hard question and demand results. They are drowning under the weight of their own size and becoming more bureacratic by the day.
Pro: Privately owned, provides flexibility. Great benefits but getting weaker. Good individual technology, blackberry, laptop, etc. Lots of smart, hardworking people there. Well known name, brand recognition. Morally responsible people for the most part with minimal backstabbing.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con:
uncertainty of management

impersonal

dysfunctional leaders 

bad culture

failure to stay ahead of compentition

unprofitable business ventures are hurting prospects

Money and benefits

benefits such as health care and shares

strong legacy business model
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
It seems that compensation tends to be less competitive (at least in the non-supervisory roles).  I think Anonymous recognizes that their name cache on your resume is "value enough" in their eyes for future opportunities outside of the the company.



Because Anonymous has so many seperately managed business units under the "Anonymous Investments" umbrella, the cultures can vary widely.  I've interacted with some employees in other business units (outside of FMR) who seem to have a very relaxed work environment ("think I'll leave at 3 today...it's Friday, and it's so nice outside!") or generally seem to be less impressive on a talent level-- some business units' Directors or even VPs are less qualified/knowledgable than many of the non-managers in FMR.



That being said, there does seem to be either a little bit of arrogance from, or a little bit of jealousy toward, FMR in interactions between business units.
Summary: "Can be a great company (depending on what business unit you work for)."
Pro:
It's a company with one of the best reputations in the industry, and it's especially good working for a privately held in the current market environment.  The constant internal message from senior management is that rule #1 is "what's right for the client"....no matter what your role is.  



I'm constantly impressed at the depth of knowledge at FMR (can't speak for other business units, but reference my "Cons").  I've worked at other firms and constantly feel that I work with some of the best and smartest people in the industry.  



Working for FMR (as opposed to other business units within Anonymous) is a real plus too.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: The downside is that the company is very large and it is hard to get promoted
Pro: It was a great place to learn and grow.  Senior Management are very professional and look to promote younger ambitious people.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: I was really surprised to see the cost of benefits. They pay is below the market average. If they would lower the cost of benefits, I would be working there again in a heartbeat!
Pro: As a representative, the job is low stress. People at the Albuquerque site are great! It has a friendly atmosphere.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: There is no clear actionable vision from senior management.  Many outsiders have come into very senior level positions and haven't lasted too long.  There have also been some very high profile departures from the firm.  This has caused a general sense of uncertainty about the vision and direction the company is heading towards in the future.
Summary: "Great place to work if confusion at the top doesn't bother you."
Pro: Large company with may different opportunities.  Anonymous has its hand in so many areas of business that you could do pretty much anything.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Depending on your position, there can be an expectation of working well beyond 40 hr work weeks, though that is not a consistent occurence.  Occasionally Executive Management may have plans in the works that are driving changes organizationally, but which not all employees are privvy to at the time, and which can then make some of the organizational changes seem inappropriate (at that time).
Summary: "Anonymous Investments is a good place to work for someone who expects as much out of the company as they put in."
Pro: Anonymous offers extensive growth opportunities to those individuals who display talent and a drive to succeed.  In most cases the managers are very understanding of family and personal time needs, coupled with an expectation that everyone is a professional and will make their hours up as necessary. Anonymous also offers excellent benefits packages.

Con: Performance is not always valued.  Mediocre resources can flourish and even excel if they are liked by senior management.  Pay for Performance is not managed well.  New Senior Leadership is cutting staff based on money not performance.
Summary: "Once #1 mutual fund industry leader now slowly decenting to the middle of the pack"
Pro: The money and benefits are excellent.  Salary, Bonus, Profit Sharing, Shares, Life Insurance, company match in101(k), etc.

Con: You are chained to the phone.  You have a ton of measures you have to hit and very little independence.  They micromanage you to death and beat the Anonymous way into you.  The growth opportunities seem to be confined to the phone site.
Pro: They have great health and101k benefits as well as vacation.  There are a lot of great people and they really promote a team atmosphere.  A lot of continuing education and reimbursement opportunities for education.

Con: Priorities and management is always changing.  Too many senior people working to protect their careers versus taking chances to grow the business.  Most recent changes handled poorly, way too many people kept in constant fear of loosing their job...tough to focus on the work to be done.
Pro: Privately held allows for long-term investment.  Great pay for people willing to put in the effort, however, that might all be changing.  Great benefit, even with recent reductions.

Con: no commissions, we should get better recognition.
Summary: "Anonymous investments, a great place to start out in the financial industry."
Pro: Heath benefits and other benifits

Con: Call center environment is not a Team oriented place. Management changes happen every week. Communication from management needs lot of work.

Pro: The benefits are good. Opportunity for advancement is Depends on the department you work for.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Highly matrxed - difficult to take tasks to completion.
Summary: "People made the company great - why let them go?"
Pro: Benefits - was also once a powerhouse with great momentum.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Call center is extremely micromanaged. The managers can make a difference. In the end they just want you to do your job but they have so many people who do the bare minimum that it makes it necessary to micromanage, which ruins the job for those of us who take pride in what we do.
Pro: Good entry level financial experience. They like to promote from within. Decent pay for the work that you have to do.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
They are quick to let employees go. There are a lot of people willing to work for less so they have a revolving door of employees. 



The branches push contests quite frequently. You may be urged to sell something in order to meet some sort of goal, even though it might not be right for the customer.
Pro: They take care of the employees. Great training. Laid back environment at branches. There is a lot of training. I traveled to california and texas to get the right training i needed for my job. It was far better than just having someone teach me in the branch.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: I thought that Anonymous got a little too big and struggled to find out how to structure itself to succeed.  It seemed like we would go through 3-4 organizational alignments each year.  It's not that it's bad, but they never seem to be able to stay the course with their decisions.  It really depended upon who was leading the charge.  Current senior management is more about the bottom line as oppose to prior leadership.  Prior leadership still looked at growth opportunities and current leadership wants to maintain and not necessary grow the business unless it is an EXACT fit or match.
Pro: Overall, very solid company with great benefits, opportunities for promotion.  Anonymous has multiple locations so there is potential to move around.  You can get in contact with the top easier than you'd think for a large corporation.  The old saying was you never get rich while at Anonymous, but because you worked there you will be rich.  I think this is true because of the incentive programs between annual bonus opportunities which can be a substantial amount of your income, phantom share program that pay out every two years and their profit sharing that was their year in and out.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Anonymous is a large, lumbering organization that is going through significant change.  This can make for a challenging work environment.  Processes to get day to day work completed are often cumbersome and inefficient.  Decision making is often decentralized and requires buy-in from many different organizations.  Strategic decisions seem to take excessively long and sometimes waffle back and forth.  This makes execution of the strategy much harder than it needs to be and sometimes nearly impossible to meet required time frames.
Summary: "Anonymous used to be great but is now just good and hopefully stops there."
Pro: Anonymous supports work-life balance and has excellent benefits.  The work is challenging and mostly interesting.  Anonymous has a high degree of integrity and is a place you can generally be proud to be associated.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
What you hear is...white collar sweatshop...accurate!

Suffering from ethics problems at top (cutting most old timers who helped build the place)

Works on the basis of sponsorship
Summary: "Magical place to a place of misery"
Pro:
Money

Benefits

Colleagues are the best
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Can be very political and you need to spend a considerable amount of time promoting your accomplishments up the organization. Need to stay close to your boss and whoever he/she reports to to receive deserved recognition. If you want to move up you will need to an inordinate amount of time managing up. There can be a sense of entitlement amongst the longer term employees, but that is changing.  Anonymous makes money despite itself and spends money foolishly at times.
Summary: "Good Company - needs to show more organizational maturity"
Pro: Anonymous is good company for early and mid career opportunities.Excellent use of technolgy for building their business and getting your job done. The benefits are excellent, but you will need to work hard and sometimes work/life balance get be difficult to maintain.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: With the market being slow right now there are limited promotional opportunities.  Any personal trading activity must be cleared before the transaction depending on which department you work in.
Summary: "Great company with limited growth in current environment."
Pro: Excellent benefits and large job diversification across the firm.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Change, change, change.  Anonymous has historically been a place where people expect change.  Lately, they have taken it to a level that is unusual even here.

I have been with firm for 10+ years.  I can't remember a time with more internal discontent..
Pro: Great reputation.  You can quickly learn the business, and gain experience because of the high volumes.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Like any large company, there are good places to work and bad ones; strong managers and weak ones; good teams and dysfunctional ones. If you are in the wrong place or under a poor manager, life can be ugly. In IT, morale has been pretty low over the past few years for a number of reasons and I wouldn't recommend that part of the business to a friend right now. IT got hit pretty hard in the last couple rounds of layoffs and frankly many were happier to be let go than to be among those left behind. In many areas the pressure and hours can be brutal.
Summary: "Good and bad areas to work; weak economy has adversely affected opportunities and satisfaction."
Pro: The benefit package has historically been very good, although financial pressures are causing cutbacks in that area. When times are good, there can be good opportunities for development and advancement - especially if you work in a business or site that is growing or you are willing to move around. There are a lot of dedicated and intelligent employees at all levels of the company in my experience there were generally opportunities to spread your involvement and contribution beyond your job description. It was a good first job, but if you get stuck in one place for very long consider bailing.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con:
- Company has lost its direction, doesn't seem to be able to be the market leader

- Focus on technological innovation has become second to financial accounting

- Organization impedes risk tasking and innovation

- Difficult to navigate the complexities
Summary: "Anonymous's an excellent ship but it navigation systems may be flawed"
Pro:
- Willing to take risks on emerging technologies

- Excellent benefits and pay,101k and profit sharing are industry leaders

- Excellent work life balance, vacation time and personal time is encouraged

- Respected industry leader, with major market shar

Con: Chained to the phone like a workhorse. Not much opportunity for upward movement in company. You are micromanaged big time and have to follow a strict schedule. The constant beeping in your ear from phone calls will drive you crazy after a while.
Pro: Good health benefits. 7%101k match. Profit sharing of usually 10% of your salary at end of year. You have to stay3 years to be vested. Good people to work with. Anonymous has a great training program the 1st5 months you are there to get you licensed and ready for the phones.

Con: Too much politics, red tape, and committee-based decision making. Little opportunity for lateral training and transition. More internal promotion and assignments based upon who you know rather than what you know.
Summary: "You Can Be a Star Today, Gone Tomorrow"
Pro: Total compensation and benefits package. Good place to get some experience. Work for a few years, then think about moving on.
