Con: Anonymous is increasingly feeling its size and is not as nimble as it once was.  Investments in technology are there but so are attendant bureaucratic obstacles.  If Anonymous endeavors to retain the core cadre of good people it has recruited in the past and bring their insights to bear, they could well maintain their standing and, potentially, go on to new heights.
Pro: Anonymous is a large, multifaceted umbrella of companies affording a range of opportunities.  Benefits are good -- especially the101k since Anonymous is the premier provider of mutual fund services.  The entrepreneurial spirit of its Chairman still there but needs a boost.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Management keeps information close to cuff and does not share. Individuals can be very possessive of their department and valuable information.  Hard to get promoted out of the director level.
Summary: "Do the benefits out way the cost of career advancement?"
Pro: Great Benefits. You will not find better in the financial services industry. Low benefits costs allow for more take home pay. Lots of young people and a business casual work environment
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: New management and layoffs every year or two
Summary: "Great place to work, excellent benefits but be prepared to be laid off every 1 - 3 years in a new management re-shuffle"
Pro: Opportunities for advancement and various different career paths.  Training is also very generous.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: I've worked at Dot-Com's, Start-ups and a few Fortune 500's and Anonymous has the worst management I've ever seen. The work is off the charts boring and the Business cares more about their bonus than the customer.
Pro: I like it here because the people are friendly and smart. The managers are understanding of your family needs. It is within walking distance from home and it is very laid-back.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Lack of meaningful management development; favored/high performing individual contributors are 'rewarded' with management positions.  Managers are expected to manage people AND continue to perform as individual contributors.
Summary: "FI Isn't Blessed with People Management Strengths."
Pro: Overall compensation/benefits are above average.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con:
As an employee, you are forced to use Anonymous's products, e.g., you can't have a brokerage account anywhere else or a financial advisor if he or she places trades and if you buy other company's mutual funds, you have to report it.  

The culture is almost like a fuedal manor with a benevolent lord.  The employees are expected to show tremendous loyalty to the firm.  To hear some talk, there is no other place they could ever work.  This used to be okay when Mr. J was more involved and the managment reciprocated some of that loyalty.  But it just isn't the case anymore.  At any given time you could have your job moved to a cheaper state, India, or just plain eliminated.  Sr. managment communication is full of sports metaphores and lofty vision statements, but surprisingly silent about long term plans related to employees such as site closures or changes to business lines.  Increasingly we have stealth layoffs.  The only way you hear about whole areas being eliminated is if you happen to have a friend that works there.  People just disappear off the company directory.  At least in 2001 and 2002 they bothered to tell everyone what was going on.  Lastly, it has become almost impossible to move internally.  They recently added another HR layer between a candidate and a hiring manager, so now if you want to post you have to go through your manager, an "internal staffing rep" who will decide whether you should even be thinking about moving, a staffing rep who will decide if you should be considered for the position, and then finally the hiring manager.  Most of the time the hiring manager never even sees your resume.  If you do happen to get that far, the hiring manager is prohibited from making an offer until he or she has gotten a reference from your current manager.  If you do apply for a position and you aren't being considered, no one ever bothers to tell you.
Summary: "Anonymous used to be a great place to work"
Pro: As an employee, you get cheap access to Anonymous's products, such as brokerage account, mutual funds, etc.  If the assets are under Anonymous management, you get it cheaper.  For example, a person with an HSA account at another firm pays annual fees, because Anonymous runs your HSA, you don't get hit with fees.  Also, Anonymous spends a ton of money on technology, so you will have nice desktop hardware and software.  The facilities are generally nice and well stocked with coffee and tea.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Limited opportunities unless you are into sales.  Like the others said, there are a lot of politics involved.  In the regional centers, most job functions and advancements is to go into sales.  However, that may not be everyone's cup of tea.  Also, it seems that service is really second to sales regardless of your function.  The better the salesman you are the better you will do in the call centers.
Summary: "Great place to gain experience.  May need to look elsewhere for growth."
Pro: Great pay & benefits compared to the same position at other gigs.  Good for college students and recent grads.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Management may not support their own direct reports
Pro: Opportunity for creative thinking exists.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Last couple of years have been a continual circle of re-organizations and changing priorities, projects are not finished before they are cancelled and the next one begins.  As a result morale is pretty low, and most associates are just going through the motions.  Many of the Sr. mgt team are from "the outside" so many of the strategies are new.
Summary: "Anonymous - changing for the better or out of business in 5 years?"
Pro: Comp and benefits are solid.  Company is less "risky" than other financial institutions.  Even with the rough times over the last few months...some areas of the company are doing quite well.  Anonymous is also very large, so there are many internal opportunities.  Being private is also sometimes a positive since hitting quarterly earning targets is not a requirement and they can spend $$ if needed.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Lack of strategic oversight.  New plans every five years with no accountability for success.  Can't feel like we are "moving the needle".
Pro: The benefits are excellent.  You have the ability to identify problems and develop solutions regardless of role or level in institution.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Work/Life balance...  There is none.
Summary: "Don't expect to make a lot of money or advance at Anonymous Investments"
Pro: The benefits are very good
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Work Life Balance- there is none
Pro: Your co workers are very good at what they do so you never have to deal with someone who is inept.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Executive Management is a revolving door. Anonymous is the place where 'executives' like to end their days getting highly paid to put their 'stamp' on the company. Almost like clockwork, every 5 years or so, executive management changes. Then the newest group of executives start their own slash & burn program to make the company more 'productive'. Once they've finished this wonderful task and decimated the various groups they declare victory, collect their huge bonuses, and turn things over to the next group of bean counters. Anonymous is coming apart at the seams because there are so many chiefs and so few indians left to any real work.
Summary: "Anonymous Investments: Retirement playground for washed up executives."
Pro: Challenges. If you like to be challenged, there's many opportunities. Start a project, then half way through it 'poof' the people you were working with are gone, typically replaced by inexperienced Indian speaking low paid H1B candidates. Salary is ok, but don't expect too much in the way of a raise.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: As of the date of this submission, there are jobs being transfered to new locations.  Relocation is not necessarilly a bad thing, but does cause anxiety.
Pro: A strong sense of right and wrong and a very strong brand name.  The past year or so has seen a lot of transition withing the company.  Relocations and job eliminations are very nerve racking.  However, my impression to date based on personal experience and talking with other colleagues, Anonymous tries to ensure a seamless transition.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Average pay is below market for many positions. Although billed as a meritocracy, promotions often go to those with tenure first. Very tall structural heirarchy, built around 'good old boys' network in Boston. Employees not given incentive, freedom, or resources to take ownership or creative stake in company.
Pro: Good training program. Large company with room for advancement, and areas for growth. Because Anonymous is privately held, the company is able to avoid the large scale layoffs common to its competitors during down markets. Strong benefits package: 10% annual profit share, and 7%101k match.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Too many glass ceilings, too many changes on high level in the last 2 years
Pro: Private company, somewhat protected from the market swings
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Very political and bureaucratic.  Titles are very inconsistent across business units, meaning a VP in one unit is a director in another.  Accountability at the senior levels is weak.  Due to frequent re-orgs a senior business leader is often moved to a new area and therefore is not in a position to own the impact of the changes they make.
Summary: "A company in a major transition, experiencing the pain of change; future is unclear."
Pro: Large company with option of moving to a different group to gain career.  Different groups are often like different companies; therefore, having the ability to move between groups is a good way to boost your career.  Good compensation structure - historically anyway.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Communication from the top down is terrible. We never know where we stand with the company, it is privately owned so there is little information available about how well we are doing.

Decisions made by senior management seem cavalier, and they leave it to middle level managers to deliver bad news to the rank and file.
Pro:
The pay can be very good.

It can be  a very exciting place. You never know what they might throw at you as a challenge
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Pay is sometimes on the lower side.  Also since things are departmentalized so much, sometimes you don‚Äôt feel as connected to the overall picture.  Sometimes you get locked in your own world and it‚Äôs hard to see how you relate to everything else or to other companies within Anonymous Investments.
Pro: The people are good.  I really enjoy the overall culture of the corporation.   I have also found that some internal departments go out of there way to support their employees.  Though this tends to be ‚Äòdepartment‚Äô specific, I love the fact that Anonymous allows this.  Overall Anonymous is a great place to work!
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Complex technical environment, poor work/life balance, senior management lack compassion for employees
Summary: "Great place to network - poor work/life balance"
Pro: A lot of learning literature, opportunity to network, best compensation, great retirement benefits
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: The company has institutionalized the acceptance of failure at worst and mediocrity at best when it comes to IT Projects.  As a software professional, it becomes frustrating to work furiously at solving every type of issue besides the technical.  Front line managers are ill equipped to manager software professionals, they are either bad developers promoted to the point of incompetence, or just do nothing know nothing MS Project jockeys.
Summary: "It is better than a punch in the face."
Pro: The money, especially bonuses in my experience exceed the market.  The base salaries are about on par.  There are a lot of good benefits beyond101k and health care.  There is supposed to be a work / life balance at Anonymous, but like so many other things, it is very inconsistent from manager to manager and business unit to business unit.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Corporate politics.  Depending on the type of information you would be exposed to on a daily basis your own personal stock trading will be affected in the following ways: You'll need approval before every trade (buy or sell), You must hold any purchase for at least 90 days, If you do sell within 90 days you must surrender the profit.
Summary: "Anonymous is a great place to work."
Pro: Great working environment.  Friendly atmosphere.  Micro-managing is NOT the style there, big plus for the day to day.  Great reimbursement programs for things like tuition (90%), computer purchase (10%), exercise equipment ($150/yr).  Flexible work environment. Fitness center.  Great cafeteria options.  Kitchenettes with sink, coffee pot, microwave and fridge in every area make it easier.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Even though Anonymous says career advancement is about the people management, managers are still promoted for technical ability, no people management skills.  Also, while Anonymous talks about work life balance, my experience is 'face time' (late nights, early morning, vacations on email, giving up most of your vacation days) is how you are taken seriously.  I've heard managers say that even though the work week is 37.5 or 40 hours (depends on site) that if you don't work at least 55-60 hours/week then you are not doing your job and contributing to the firm.  Employee recognition (at the individual department and manager level) is virtually non-existent, most often employees get back handed compliments, 'you did a great job but here is how you could have improved...'.  Kaizen (continuous improvement) is great, but my experience has been strengths are minimized and areas of improvement are the primary focus.  This approach can be very disheartening to a business team or group as well as to individuals.
Summary: "Great place to work, but here's what you need to know"
Pro: Anonymous is a large company with many different business and product lines - this means there is a great deal of opportunity.  It also invests a great deal in new technology (almost too much without thinking through the on-going production and operations costs).  Anonymous also has a fantastic benefits package which makes up over50% of total compensation - excellent healthcare options, dental,101(k), etc.  Anonymous also has some of the smartest people I have ever met or had the pleasure to work with, they are creative, driven, articulate, and for the most part have a good sense of humor.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: It's a challenge  for people who have experienced other work environments.  Don't plan on working a regular week.
Summary: "Start a career here, but don't plan on staying forever."
Pro: Great place to work for people who want to break into the financial industry.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: This is a hard place to start a career out of college.  The structure of the compnay is very top heavy and chances to wok on exciting projects are not always available.
Summary: "Good place to work, however hard place to start a career"
Pro: Benefits are generally very good and competitive in the industry
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Arbitrary performance review and bonus review ratings.  As a regular worker you are very unlikely to see the E (exceptional) or O (outstanding) performance review ratings, those seemed to be reserved for managers and connected people.  While many get promoted, they are usually "in-line" promotions worked out with existing managers.  If you post for a higher level position on the internal job board you are unlikely to get it.
Summary: "Anonymous is a great place to work, but could be limiting in career growth"
Pro: Outstanding benfits package, beautiful campus, professional atmosphere, good work/life balance, challenging projects, and Anonymous gives back to the community.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Working for a private company has both its ups and downs, sometimes you have no idea what top management will do.  If the owner has a strange dream we might be starting a new business.  Sometimes the pay at Anonymous can be less then at other companies.
Pro: Anonymous has a great retirement plan, great health insurance choices, and can change jobs internally with little difficulty.   As a salary person you start off with three weeks of vacation and after five years you get four.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Its an old, tired company that is way too top heavy.  Particularly with senior managers who have been around for 10+ year and seem to be in "coast mode" and are out of touch.  In my specific group there are twice as many managers as there are actual employees (developers, analysts, QA, etc.).  This makes for a politically charged  environment.  Promotions are based on who you know and how long you've been around instead of how good you are.  



The opportunity to move up in the company by moving on to other groups within the company has recently been removed.  You can still transfer, but it must be a lateral movement (ie: they won't pay you more for doing more, and any type of promotion is out of the question even though they'll expect you to do the work of people with a higher job title).
Summary: "An Old, Tired Company that Needs Improvement"
Pro: Good benefits (profit sharing, 7% match for101k)
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Projects are often delayed.  Performance evaluations and reproting structures are sometime convoluted.
Pro: Anonymous has a solid reputation.  It's a safe and stable place to work and there's an excellent commitment to work-life balance.  The office culture is great: everyone is friendly and willing to help.  Furthermore, there's a strong commitment to employee education.  Eevryone seems very accessible.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: lack of strong planning and business discipline; fundamental changes at the top of the house have not yet trickled down to the next level of leadership, can get very political and turf-oriented at times
Summary: "Anonymous has its challenges just like any other place, but the strong upside remains..."
Pro: Smart people, strong culture of accomplishment, diverse lines of business, good environment to learn and grow as a leader
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Contractors are treated with different standards, and there are a whole lot of them.

Anonymous's online workplace management tools can be overwhelming.
Summary: "Great place to work if you're ready to roll up your sleeves and apply yourself!"
Pro: Great variety and opportunity for learning. Good people stick around. If you're intelligent and know how to apply your talents, you'll excel. Anonymous has great online tools to help you get your job done.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: lower pay, expected to be available 24x7, poor recognition, only the managers get the credit, slow to promote. There are a lot of job positions but the qualifications are such you do not have the background necessary to be considered.  Definately more of a who you know than what you know.  In order to advance, it seems important to network instead of working more on an actual skill set.
Pro: Great brand name.  Able to work with newer technologies. A sense of empowerment is given but some managers are micro managers.  Others are so hands off you do not get any feed back at all.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Disorganized, no empowerment of employees, belittling and controlling managers, don't trust skilled people they bring in to do their jobs, micro management, sweat shop.
Pro: They do give healthy bonuses and good benefits but all that will go away across the next few years.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Different demographic of the community is a big determinant of your compensation.
Summary: "Best company to work for in America."
Pro: Great compensation structure, even for unlicensed Representatives starting out in the industry.  Company spends considerable amount of time and resources on professional development of employees.  There is a really strong sense of healthy competition amongst the associates.  The company does everything it can to recognize and compensate those who perform above their benchmarks.  As a matter of fact, I've seen approximately 10 associates get promoted in the less than3 years I have spent here.  There is a lot of room to grow as well, even for those who have plenty of industry experience.  The support structure is amazing, the company really goes out of its way to make sure every associate is successful.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Company has no vision, no respect for employees, it is a heavy, bloated, top heavy organization that is not capable of strategic thinking.  Be prepared for reorg after reorg, management having no idea what is going on. The slow drip drip of the real talent has now become a roar and the good people are leaving in droves.
Summary: "The company that was formerly the great Anonymous Investments is on a path to mediocrity, well on its way to obscurity"
Pro: Learn the business, earn a paycheck, get some experience then leave and go to somewhere who will give you more respect and pay you more
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Lack of opportunity for career advancement in IT. Locations (non-Boston). There is an unspoken expectation in some departments that you will work above your normal hours and not complain or expect any compensation for the time.
Pro: Location (for Boston Employees), multiple fringe benefits. Some good middle managers. It really depends which part of Anonymous you work for though - FMR is the way to go with less likelihood of being outsourced or down sized.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: If you cherish the ability to get things done, and to grow yourself from an overall career perspective, I would highly recommend you look elsewhere
Summary: "Decent place to work if you have a family, but if you are just starting your career, my advice: run away screaming."
Pro: Salary and benefits are the only key reasons that I would recommend anyone to work at Anonymous
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: It is currently undergoing a lot of turbulence and restructuring so it is hard to get work done.
Summary: "Good place to work - but  needs some more time to work out the kinks of its restructuring."
Pro: Opportunities to move around and grow in new positions.  Work life balance. Benefits
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Constant distraction of reorganizations and reductions in force. No clear direction in the Human Resources Services Company. While this Anonymous Company is over 10 years old they are still trying to figure out who they want to be when they grow up. Opportunities, career advancement, salary increases and bonus are based on who you know not job performance. No consistency in roles, employees in team leaders and managers positions play the same roles with the same and in some cases more responsibility as the Directors and VP's but without the same salaries, title and bonuses potential.  Employees continue to pay for the sins of poor decisions made by Senior Management team by way of continued reduction in the merit increase and bonus pool to make up for financial losses incurred  by poor decisions.
Summary: "Enough fooling around - time to start focusing on the business at hand and your employees."
Pro: Benefits and the employees in the Human Resources services company are great to work with.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: long hours and no time for family
Summary: "A place to get started not a place for a long career"
Pro: benefits and pay.  Anonymous pays well if you are willing to work.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: career advancement is difficult to come by...there is no clear direction as to how to get to the next level
Summary: "Anonymous is a good place to work for work-life balance but not for career advancement"
Pro: compensation packages are fair and benefits are good in terms of tuition reimbursement
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Constant change of priorities. Tremendous lack of support.
Pro: Anonymous's very conservative nature has paid off with an impecable reputation. It is a privately held firm that has been around for sixty years. One of the best reasons to work there are the great co-workers. Many smart, talented, and loyal employees. Anonymous boasts excellent benefits. Very generous match/profit sharing. The pension program has been replaced with retirement health account. I also value the great education on the industry that I have learned over the years.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: A lot of silo work results in re-runs and overlaps in effort and technology.  Poor communication between different business units.  Still plenty of Chinese Walls between Retail and Institutional services.
Summary: "Wide range of career options if your are flexible and willing to work hard."
Pro: Great people, The company makes getting in the door a really hard process.  A sense of team exists once you start working here.  Good balance between work and life.  Most phone site campuses are loaded with activities such as baseball, basketball & soccer courts.  Also onsite gyms and food services as well as laundry services
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Employees are just cogs in the wheel at Anonymous.  Two examples reinforcing this opinion are: entire business units are relocated on a whim and development programs are non-existent.



Raises and bonuses are ‚Äúcapped‚Äù minimizing the importance of excellent performance. In the end, the really great performers leave seeking appropriate compensation. Many end up returning shortly after for a matching (or higher) salary indicative of their true worth (dictated by the market for their services).
Pro:
There is significant opportunity to change jobs within the firm due to the diversified businesses within the company (employer services, fund accounting, capital markets, operations, technology).  



The benefits programs are strong.  Employees can receive tuition reimbursement, gym membership reimbursement, computer assistance and even back-up day care.  Some sites offer on-site health clubs and/or walking trails.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: There's very little job stability...layoffs have been happening every year in certain areas.  Not sure why, we're swamped with work and the company continues to make a ton of money.  That is a good thing, but they need to cut in certain 'other' areas instead of the same area every year.  Some of the old leadership must go.  The new leadership I believe is strong.   Maybe they will help breakdown the walls between the groups so we can get a lot of work accomplished.  They also need to get rid of the 'good old boy network'...there's a lot of talent in the organization, but they can't get passed the 'clicks'.  This is very unfortunate.
Summary: "It will just be another large corporation when Mr Johnson retires...not a good thing.  He's the backbone of the company."
Pro: The benefits and pay are equal and/or above it's competitors.  Everyone takes pride in their work and they want to do the right thing.  The tenure is high.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: It can be tough to see people promoted or hired for choice jobs because of who they know or where they went to school.  This problem though seems to be endemic to the entire business world.  You have to manage your time appropriately to allow you to keep up with your current tasks as well as learning more skills and making the right connections to be properly positioned to advance your career.  If you are not a Type A personality you can get stuck in a role performing the same tasks over and over without much growth potential.  You have to take initiative and make it known that you want to move ahead.  Some management will not support your career goals as it causes them to have to backfill which can be a challenge.
Summary: "Bring Your ' A ' Game to Anonymous and Your Opportunities are Endless!"
Pro: The collegial atmosphere allows employees at Anonymous to work together towards solutions by bringing diverse knowledge through cross-business teams.  Instead of working in Silos we communicate with business partners having experience in multiple industries.  This allows quicker responses to client needs as well as the most efficient process to bring the most relevant new products to market within budget and original timeframe.  The benefits packages include health insurance, life insurance, short and long term disability, corporate perks, share ownership in a private company, and101k.  Management is very flexible when time is needed for personal needs.  The properties are taken care of and kept current and the food at Sebastians(internally owned caterer) isn't half bad!
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Very little opportunity for career advancement in a lot of groups, and unclear criteria for promotion. Top-heavy management bloat and low turnover prevents upward movement. There's a good chance your role & responsibilities will get narrower over time, rather than broader and more challenging/exciting. Expect many of your colleagues to be frustrated that they're not being used to their potential.
Summary: "Come for the salary but don't stay for career advancement."
Pro: High salary.  Many offices subscribe to a 9-5 day and don't expect much overtime so it can be a family-friendly atmosphere. A lot of smart, talented people. Generally thorough review process means you'll get regular feedback (even though it might not turn into any recognition for a job well done).
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Very little opportunity for career advancement in a lot of groups, and unclear criteria for promotion. Top-heavy management bloat and low turnover prevents upward movement. There's a good chance your role & responsibilities will get narrower over time, rather than broader and more challenging/exciting. Expect many of your colleagues to be frustrated that they're not being used to their potential.
Summary: "Come for the salary but don't stay for career advancement."
Pro: High salary.  Many offices subscribe to a 9-5 day and don't expect much overtime so it can be a family-friendly atmosphere. A lot of smart, talented people. Generally thorough review process means you'll get regular feedback (even though it might not turn into any recognition for a job well done).
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Significant and frequent change in senior leadership introduces challenges and is somewhat disconcerting.
Summary: "If you can handle change and are a self-starter, Anonymous provides significant growth opportunities"
Pro: Continued investment in the business and ability to maintain a long term perspective allows growth and opportunity for the organization and the indivdual.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Currently undergoing a transformation that may commoditize the company and make top performers leave.  Reluctant to eliminate low-margin business from its portfolio.



Much of the company is territorial and rather than working well as a team, things can be quite difficult to accomplish.
Pro:
Overall compensation at Anonymous is very good - however you are expected to contribute a lot to earn it.  Advancement is available for top talent.



Anonymous is very flexible with its work options - telecommuting, flex time, etc.  Management is very well versed in leadership and helping people to provide resources to bring out the best in their work.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: politics, not enough autonomy to make decisions, low pay
Pro: Perks like Profit Sharing, bonus, being privately held, training opportunities
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: The environment is difficult and the hours often long.  There can be significant red-tape in making decisions or moving projects along.  Certain areas are very political.
Summary: "Great Comp/benefits but not a good workplace for some..."
Pro: The best reasons include terrific pay and benefits along with the ability to work with some very accomplished professionals.  There are a wide variety of opportunties across the corporation both domestic and international.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Being a huge company can make getting noticed not so easy here. The corporate culture discourages risk-taking but I think that is something upper management is starting to realize. Anonymous used to be a place that encouraged and developed risk-taking, entrepreneurialism and bold ideas. Office politics are rampant here. The pay is good but much more can be made elsewhere if you take the initiative to look and to relocate outside New Hampshire.
Pro: Anonymous has some of the highest paying jobs out there in New Hampshire, but unfortunately that doesn't say much (see below). Anonymous is a very easy place to start a career in financial services and learn the business from the ground up.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Sometimes you may not get the exact shift that you want. You might be required to work the evenings, though you are able to submit your preference.   you might have long hours on the phone, but the calls are very diverse.  One call might be from a multi millionare, the next, from a student investing his first $200 in the stockmarket.
Summary: "Anonymous: great place to break into the business"
Pro: Great way to break into the financial market and obtain your series 7.  Options for overtime are amazing.  You can work many hours more than the usual10, in order to make additional time.  I knew people that worked 80 hours a week and more than doubled their salary.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: It's a call center position so it‚Äôs very heavily regulated and monitored.  Daily schedules are planned to the minute.
Pro: So far, it seems to be a very fast paced environment which appears to offer significant opportunity to advance, at least within my business unit.  I've learned an immense amount already, if anything, it has been a great opportunity to learn some of the business and a great entry point.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Anonymous is absolutely out of control.  Anonymous promotes firefighters and not strategic thinkers.  I've worked at other highly political companies and Anonymous is absolutely the worse.  This is because how one should succeed is not clear.  Since success is difficult to measure and no career path has been mapped out, the schoozers win the day due to an ambiguous environment .  I see that many cutthroat, but ineffective managers are continually promoted. There are a handful of good managers out there however.  



In general, I find Anonymous a very difficult place to accomplish anything since the focus of mid-management changes and priorities change.  



Merit review and the fact that its called that is a joke, and we all know it.  If an employee wants to find his/her true market value, find a new job.  Don't wait around for Anonymous to make an adjustment for you.  

Things are not clear when are recruited as far as the benefits package, profit sharing, and the 401K match.
Summary: "Out of Control, but could turn it around in 5 to 10 years"
Pro:
I generally like most of the people I work with.  Recently, I've been given multiple opportunities to learn new things and management was willing to clear the day to day work so that I could do that.  As of late, management has been good at trying to strike a work/life balance (only recently however).  Management has improved as of late to get a handle on workflow and communicate.  



Anonymous has good reimbursement programs for health equipment, gym membership, and computer equipment.  You do receive some financial serivces at a discount like $8 trades, inexpensive portfolio management and the like.  



Anonymous does have the potential and resources to become an outstanding company.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: The red tape is a killer! Unless you have been in the organization for a while (4 years at least), it is extremely hard to get things accomplished without running around all over the place, being bumped from person to person. Certain "standards" in place also merely serve to place a checkbox on a form rather than serve a real and vital purpose. Again, this adds to the red tape without necessarily improving quality or process. Career growth is strictly by time worked rather than skill. There is no "fast-track" for star employees. Even for those that consistently outperform, they still get the same promotion time line as the not-so-stellar employees.
Summary: "Great for business and finance folks, bad for technology people."
Pro: Very good in terms of flexible work hours, ability to work remotely and geographic diversity. A big plus is the international exchange program where employees from Ireland or India come over to the U.S and vice versa. Of course, this is usually only available to senior positions, but a great bonus none-the-less. They also offer free financial courses; even for those of us who are not finance majors. They make great emphasis on retirement savings and their profit sharing plan puts funds directly into your101k, tax free! This alone help me reach my retirement goals in a very short span of time.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: With the so called Global economy salaries and benefits are not what they once were. Also, with the recent layoffs and consolidation of jobs, this creates more work and hours for those of us who are left and for less pay.
Summary: "Lately it is not the "Great Company" to work for that it once was!!"
Pro: Benefits, education, and the ability to work with some of the best people in the industry.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Health benefits could be better. Employee contribution amount for medical is too high, no vision benefits, dental is basic. They force you to take all your vaca and sick days or you lose at at the end of the year.
Summary: "Anonymous is a good company to work for."
Pro: Fair salary. Otherwise, no particular reason as the people makes the company a good place to work for. If you have a bad mgr or coworker, then it makes it tough to like your job no matter how match you make. I'm lucky as I get along with my mgr. Company culture is fine.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: limited career development opportunities post-graduate school.
Summary: "Working at one of Anonymous's phone sites is a great place to get your financial career started"
Pro: Their series 7 study course has one of the highest pass rates in the industry.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Business platform is too large and departments are outsourced; created as phone sites versus subject matter support staff to advisors. Financial advisors are too reliant on software and not enough technical (financial) development is promoted by the company in certain areas.
Summary: "Very conservative and respected, reputable firm can improve in compensation department as an I-Management leader."
Pro: Reputable firm. Leader in the MF industry. Very conservative business platform and compliance/HR department that constantly modifies policies and procedures in order to avoid heavy risks and excessive business expenses.  The company has very driven and intelligent individuals that strongly believe in a team oriented work environment. The branch work environment is much different than the phone sites where customer service is provided to branch representatives and clients.  Business processes are heavily outsourced by department functions and organized according to a customer service phone tree.  Overall, the only improvement to be made is in the compensation area and the technical development available to the representatives working at the branches.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Worst job of my life. Long hard days that are incredibly boring taking call after call and answering the same four or five questions over and over. They micro manage you to the minute (literally) and tell you when to eat or take a break. That might appeal to some but for me that was the first time I had been in such a repressive position. I felt like a slave. And the compensation is terrible. I made more in my first year out of school ten years ago than I made at Anonymous and I am fully licensed (Series 6 and 63). I mainly took the job out of curiosity. I was new to the area (NC) and had never worked for a huge company before so I wanted to see what it was like. Thanks to Anonymous I will never again work for a company with more than 100 employees. To recent college grads......trust me....there is much better opportunities out there and I would run, not walk, from any offer that Anonymous makes you. I had never been miserable in my life until I worked with Anonymous and am so happy that I left.
Summary: "Please read if considering working at Anonymous"
Pro: There really are none. If you are a glutton for punishment go for it. It was by far the worst working experience of my life and I am so glad I left. I had always worked for smaller, entreprenurial type companies where there was real opportunity if you worked hard and could produce. This culture does not exist at Anonymous, at least not in the role I was in. They do have decent benefits so that would be a reason to work there and if you are looking for P/T you only have to work50 hours per week to be eligible for the benefits (80% paid by Anonymous). They also do have the option of working1 ten hour days or even5 ten hour days if you are so inclined so that is something that may be appealing.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: The culture is terrible. Yes-men and women with no substance are the ones who get promotions while the employees who are actually knowledgeable get shown the door. It's extremely difficult to be promoted or get the raise you actually deserve.
Summary: "Don't drink the kool-aid, Fido is still a corporation."
Pro: The benefits were good at the time I left. 7%101k match and 10% profit sharing.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Management is out of touch with market direction and needs, and technology personnel are viewed as "overhead" or an "expense" and not really an investment in the future.  There is a tremendous amount of bureacracy and layers of removal between the customer and the people actually doing the work.  Having "fun" at work isn't really a priority, eveyrone walks around with their head down hardly cracking a smile most of the time.  It's all business, all the time, but a lot of efforts being duplicated and /or wasted.
Summary: "Not a bad place to work, and so much potential to get better in the future!"
Pro: Anonymous has a very competitive benefits package, and good opportunities for training and extending your knowlege of financial services.  There are lots of opportunities for working in different departments during your career.  The average tenure of Anonymous employees is quite long - something like 10+ years, so you could build a long career here if you want to.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: While most private companies are somewhat protected from the pressures of the market, Anonymous is not due to the nature of it's business. There is a very strong focus on cost cutting right now. The company has more office politics going on than other companies I have worked at. Constant reorganizations.
Summary: "Great company, but in a tough situation due to the market"
Pro: Anonymous is a blue chip company which looks great on your resume. It's also large enough to provide plenty of opportunities for growth internally. If you are a self starter and deliver results, you can advance quickly.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Anonymous is a lifestyle not just work. You work 24X7.  No room for family.  Way too much paperwork to do your job.  Boston rules, Raleigh is treated like India outsourced.  Where I worked, I only got to know the 5 people that I worked with. Also, if you work in Raleigh, be wary of the Boston people.  They  are not friendly and are  not interested in helping anyone new.  The NH office resent the Raliegh office with a passion.
Summary: "Firefighting every day is the norm at Anonymous."
Pro: Pay and benefits are very good.  They spend money like it is going out of style.  The compensation is good but you have to be cautious what the HR reps promise you. They will promise you anyting just so you will accept.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Recent, sweeping management changes have been tough on the rank-and-file, and the outcome isn't entirely clear, yet.  Technical innovation is often dampened by "big systems" thinking and, recently, tight budgets and timelines.  The downside of lots of talented / smart people is that one occasionally encounters staggering levels of arrogance.
Summary: "Challenging place to work, in every sense of the word"
Pro: Privately owned company historically not afraid of investing in up and down markets.  No quarterly Wall Street pressure means management can take a long view.  Historically, very good compensation packages at all levels.  Intellectually challenging environment with lots of talented people.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: You get ahead based more on who you know than what you know and/or how you apply the knowledge; management doesn't lead, they 'boss'.  People are disposal resources, valued only until a cheaper solution comes along.
Summary: "So much potential, too much management greed."
Pro: Worker bee's are typically very bright and work quite hard.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Anonymous Investment Institutional Services handles employer retirement plans.  They have the potential to affect the lives of so many customers whether they are just starting their first 401K plan or retiring from the work force.  Today when the financial lives of so many individuals are so uncertain, the work of the retirement specialist is immensely important.  What they say or don't say can have profound consequences. This is a great opportunity for individuals with great fiduciary responsibility.  However, it is unfortunate that the advancement egos of so many managers suppress this responsibility of the retirement specialist.  If you are fortunate to find a manager that truly buys into the fiduciary responsibility of their role, then you will gain satisfactory of doing a great job.  Unfortunately, these are few among Anonymous's management team.
Pro: Anonymous Investment Institutional Services offers an opportunity to grow in a variety of financial positions.  Their are tremendous opportunities to advance if your willing to be part of the traditional "boys club".  Yes, this club is still alive and well at Anonymous.  If you are fortunate, to click with the right group they will ensure your advancement.  However the opposite is also true.  If you're willing to play the game, then  you can gain much success at Anonymous.  This is truly one place where who you know is truly important.  Hard work is relative to knowing the right people.   They will take care of you.  But if you speak up, beware.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Lower end of the salary scale.  Management is more supervisory leaving it up to you so search out ways to grow and learn.  Expect to spend your own time searching for ways to improve.  Prepare for a heavy workload which will only grow with the more experience you gain.
Summary: "Great place to work for self motivated people."
Pro: Knowledgeable staff, top notch technology, excellent benefits.  Hands down the leader in the industry in just about everything they do.  If you want to be surrounded by the smartest people and the best systems - Anonymous is the place to be.101k and other benefits will not be beat by any other institution.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Tied to a phone with headset over 90% of the time.  Working in cubicle city.   After a couple of years you are rarely challenged mentally and continuously repeat the same menial task and conversations with customers.  You do not generally work with the same customers so you are constantly talking to new people and the customers get different answers and advise from rep to rep.  Very political management team.
Summary: "Great place to start to get licensed and trained."
Pro: Retirement benefits with an automatic 10% profit sharing and $ for $ match on101k up to 7%.  Ability to work overtime for time and a half pay.  After3 years you have1 weeks paid vacation plus 10 holidays paid.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: There are also a lot of very lazy people working here who have adopted a "cover my butt" attitude.  Taking risks and initiative is actively discouraged by multiple layers of middle management who are afraid to be on the "wrong side" of a senior manager, so the safe-but-inadequate decision is preferred over a better solution which entails some risk.  Too much paper-pushing and red tape in getting things done.  HR & Management like to crow about paying "industry average" salaries, which to me seems like a way to guarantee you'll only retain "industry average" talent.
Summary: "IT is treated as an expense, not as an investment."
Pro: There are a lot of very smart people working in the IT area here, and it's been a pleasure working with them.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Transitioning businesses to alternative locations has provided some job instability in recent years.
Pro: Anonymous is a company that rewards hard work and dedication. They provide an extremely competitive benefits package which compliments decent salary packages.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: The company at times does not seem to have everything together. They have gotten so big that communication between departments is difficult and sometimes non-existent. The work at times can seem boring but Anonymous does attempt to try to improve your skills so you are able to move up.
Pro: Great Opportunity for advancement. Huge company so plenty of opportunity to move to other groups depending on your interest. The company encourages individuals to pursue their interests at the company and also outside of work.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Ned Johnson used to run the company in a way that treated most people fairly, but executive management changes constantly. Every time there is a new executive, the domino effect is seen and productivity is severely impacted. Roger Lawson is currently doing his best to decimate the company of the best and brightest employees.
Summary: "An once great company that is going downhill."
Pro: Anonymous is a large company with locations around the world. Compensation can be good, but the level of political game-playing is very high, making it hard to get ahead unless you are really friendly with someone at a higher level.

Con: squeezing more productivity out of you..
Summary: "Anonymous - the good and not so good"
Pro: Fast paced, sales environment with spunk

Con: Somewhat political in promotion processes.  Probably could make more money elsewhere though the position would be less secure.
Summary: "Great place to work if you are not out all for yourself"
Pro:
Privately held, they "Do the right thing" for customers.  Though changes take a lot of time to happen, they are on the right path.  They are very innovative and have been very successful over the last few years at using technology to build scale and profitability.

The benefits are fabulous, especially the profit sharing and match for101k contributions.

Great to work for a private company that is not totally concerned about profitability and earnings from one quarter to the next.  Company is conservatively managed so they have not gotten tripped up by the credit debacles.  Growing company which has a great future.

Great to work for a private company that is not totally concerned about profitability and earnings from one quarter to the next.  Company is conservatively managed so they have not gotten tripped up by the credit debacles.  Growing company which has a great future.

Con: It is a very large  corporation, so it is difficult to make a name for yourself.  Additionally, the job is very independent, so you must be comfortable initiating conversation with other members of the firm.  In isolated instances, there is a lack of interaction among team members.
Pro: At FMR, you are given a lot of freedom to do your job.  FMR also provides tremendous access to resources.  Since it is such a large institution, FMR has superior access to management.  Job performance is quantifiable.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: A lot of uncertainty from the top down, and most rank-and-file employees feel very out of the loop and not very empowered. Restructurings and management changes seem to be arbitrary and tend not to improve things; it almost feels like someone's tinkering with things because they believe they need to do something but they're not sure what. The people at the top are absurdly over-compensated and they don't spread it out as much as they could and should -- more employee ownership would be a great step. The people on the "inside" of the fund management shop, the core business, seem insulated and out of touch, kind of like a bunch of Roman senators.
Pro: Industry leader in many ways with one of the best brand-names in the business. Anonymous at the top of your resume or anywhere on your resume gets you noticed in the marketplace. It's a private company instead of public company so it's not pressured by the Wall Street quarterly earmings mentality, and that's a HUGE difference-maker in a great way. It's a well-capitalized company and they spend a lot on technology; I've honestly never seen anything like it. Some very smart people there, too, and some of them were even nice. Anonymous has a variety of businesses within the organization and people do move around.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Company lacks loyalty to its employees while demanding loyalty from them.  I have seen numerous 20+ year employees let go in down times in the market.  I have been very suprised at this lack of company loyalty and it has certainly been an eye opener for me.
Pro: Great company to start your career.  Opportunity is available to those who show desire to achieve.  Be prepared to be flexable with your career and change directions as the company changes.  As the internal saying goes "If you don't like something at Anonymous, wait a year and it will change."  Change is constant and those who adapt are rewarded.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Political, and short sighted lower to middle management.
Summary: "Good company to work for overall, but lower to middle management in certain divisions lack foresight."
Pro: Competetive benefits, Great training, decent work life balance.

Con: risk averse management that does not know how to grow a business

Con: Heavy Micro-Managing, Bad Work Schedules, High Turnover Rate, and Bad Compensation.  Do not plan on working for Anonymous more than one to two years, because you will become burned and stressed out.  The work environment is high stress with little reward or compensation.  Plus, you will have to follow strict hourly work schedule which includes only two 15 minute breaks and a 30 minute lunch (This is monitored to the minute...literally)!!!  The work environment does not allow for one to build relationships with your fellow coworkers, because you will be on the phone non-stop dealing with customers, and plan on taking between 85-115 phone calls in an 8 hour period.
Summary: "Anonymous is a great place to begin a career in finance, however you'll be burned out in a year!!!"
Pro: Anonymous has excellent industry training, will pay for the necessary security licenses such as the FINRA Series 7 and Series 63, and provide on going training through out your tenure.  I learned more in a year and half working at Anonymous, then I have at any other employer!!

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time

Con: If you get offered as a Java/Fullstack developer role and the hiring BU is Asset Management, and you decide to get onboard, congratulations, you will ruin your career. After you join, they will ask you to do testing also. According to them a fullstack developer is the one who does backend development+automation testing+manual testing. And that too, the tools used are a decade old. No scope outside, no use of anything as whatever you learn will not help you in the future for other companies. Very toxic work environment, no work life balance. Often you will end up staying till late night. Very short and strict deadlines. They will also make you work in L2 support, in the weekends, you have to attend to bug fixes. Yes think many times before you join this BU.
Pro: The Indian arm of Anonymous Investments gets huge support from the US, hence you have greater transparency with the organization. Very good compensation scales and equal pay according to your grade, which is very rarely seen. A variety of benefits like insurance cover, meal card worth 1150 every month, flexible timing, free transport, work from home option, good leave policy.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than a year

Con:
Where to begin...



- Management is just appalling at all levels. One of the managers said "depression isn't an illness", which just sums up their entire attitude

- People are placed in roles that may not suit them (or may not be what they applied for), and are just told to suck it up

- Office politics are a joke

- Bullying is ignored

- Employees are left to stagnate if they annoy the wrong person

- Really old tech, complicated systems, way too slow to upgrade

- Use a lot of obscure tech so it's hard to find solutions online

- WFH policy isn't clear, and some managers only allow seniors to WFH, while others allow anyone who's passed probation.

- People in senior positions just because they've been working there a long time, who have no business being that level at all

- All the interesting work is taken from Ireland and given to US teams

- Dublin offices are way out in Citywest, so not an ideal location

- Bad quality laptops with virtual desktops that keep crashing, meaning it can be impossible to get work done

- Everything is slowed down by pointless bureaucracy

- Terrible canteen with unhealthy food that's listed as healthy





Overall, your experience depends entirely on who your manager is. If you get stuck with a bad one (of which there are many), it's nearly impossible to escape from them without handing in your notice.
Pro: They have decent benefits and pay

* Time flies as there is a lot of work

* Great department to work with as it improves your investigation skills

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than a year

Con:
It's a call center not engineering company. It's top heavy company. More management than who are useful people. Pace over perfection is Mantra which is nonsense. They just do for the sake of doing and saving their you know, and not for the sake of work. Recently they wasted 27 million dollars during adoption of third party vendor product. They could not identify until later stages it was not the product for their need. Such is the expertise of folks here. Clearing interview is easy here so no expertise at all. People who work here get stuck for long time not able to get out, since they do work here on developed legacy systems, which are like 10 years backward in the industry.

Central infrastructure team provides infra which are just wrappers over APIs like spring APIs or so which just make u useless upon using it. Since u won't know the actual technology since u just use the wrapper APIs . If you are very nice at pleasing management, then u get promotions and not based on the ability or work done. Lot more to say, but enough for now.

Too much of unwanted meetings and you have to spend nearly two-three hours in telephone calls.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time

Con:
Too rigid, too formal and too many restrictions. Even the cab facility provided is not very flexible in terms of timings.

Not very friendly work environment.

No work from home option for people at junior level (people who do not get a laptop).

Even for people at mid senior level, taking a work from home is not very easy.

The entire Business Analytics and Research (BA&R) team works to provide data driven solutions to optimize Anonymous's Call Center to help demand planning. As it is the work is not challenging at all; after a point in time it becomes redundant and uninteresting.

Pathetic food quality in the cafeteria (You can always go to Pyramid food court to have food).

Summary: "How is it to work at Anonymous, Gurgaon location !"
Pro:
So, to start with, Anonymous has a great working culture.  There is a lot of inter team and intra team interaction within the organization. I was working in the operations department and it was fun to work there. 



Firstly, you become eligible for a promotion / IJP after spending 18 months in the current role. Good thing is a lot of IJPs (Internal Job Process) keep coming out. So you can plan to switch your role.

Secondly, there are a lot of fun activities, events and stuff that keep taking place

Thirdly, cab facility and complementary dinner and lunch facility available.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time

Con:
Common judgement process for employees is a pain. You need to be Rockstar to climb the ladder. 
Culture of meeting too often, no proper focus while working on complex code 
Mid level management is bit incompetent and arrogant 
Sometimes goals are written in blood. They aren't flexible. Innovation is must no matter complexity of your project. 
People are insecure because of this. They try to take credit for others work. It's about survival among fittest.
Pro:
Good work life balance 
Connecting from home option. You can connect from your personal computer if there is no office machine. 
Free, AC transport which will cut down lot of travel time and risk to your life 
Higher management which always tries to make our life better. 
Freedom to change our teams internally, manager won't be having any power to stop by it. This makes manager to be in top of his game. 
Very humble President in India. 
Matured captive unit in India, which gets lot of ownership in india
Employees have the freedom to use their leave quota provided it is planned. 
Good learning environment, company invests a lot in learning materials. They want to keep employees very relevant in the market.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: There are very few cons to be mentioned. However, one would be the need to cope with current technology trends as it takes a considerable amount of time for the financial domain company to bring an upgrade considering the risk factor to their data.
Pro: Anonymous Investments has an excellent work atmosphere. This is coupled with a good learning curve and career growth for inexperienced individuals who would be interested in the financial services domain.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments  for more than5 years

Con:
As a technologist, the office is still very male-dominated - though this is a problem everywhere for software engineers. 



A lot of the salary/bonus structure is very clearly tied up in the overall company performance. During a recession  or market downturn, the salary/bonus experience may be very different. 



There seems to be a lot of politicking in the upper-management. My team felt this through frequent group re-orgs, initiative changes, sudden U-turns on key priorities etc.
Pro:
LEAP' - Their technologist graduate program is exceptional. 6 months of training,1 of which are classroom based. Professional external trainers teaching everything form agile to public speaking to Spring MVC. They invest heavily in their young talent, and it pays. 



Salary was competitive as a grad (in my location at least), as are annual salary increases (I averaged 8-10% per year entering as a grad - in several smaller bumps - enough even to stay on par with peers who job-hopped!) though I don't know how that scales for higher-ups. The performance/review process is formalized and well run. 



The work environment is very good - flexible work hours, good work/life balance, very little tolerance for toxic behaviour, good people, I usually work10 hours and leave the office at3 most days.

Pro: Good work culture, friendly employees

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than a year

Con: A con to Anonymous is that there are a limited number of investment roles. Their investment team might hire one top student a year. There are roles available in Sales, Finance, Products and Accounting but no investment roles. As far as I could tell you would have a better chance getting a job with McKinsey than investing money for Anonymous. This isn't really a con to co-op students as much as it is to grads who want to actually do investing.
Pro: Anonymous invests in their co-op students. They had between10-40 co-op students each semester (most in Toronto Office). Every week HR organized walkthroughs of different departments and seminars to help co-op students better understand their business. Co-op students get many benefits including presentations from Portfolio Managers and guides on interviewing and recruiting to professional etiquette. Of all of my co-op terms I was treated best at fidelity and that was a common experience. Anonymous is also a very highly respected employer to have on your CV.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments  for less than a year

Con: There's a very strong individualistic culture and a strong tendency for the most visible and vocal people to be rewarded with promotions.  The staff is obsessed with getting promoted and it's more important to be seen and getting involved with extra-curricular activities that doing your own job well.  Self-promotion is more important than ability.  Kissing-up and pushing down is rewarded.  Far too much of a subservient attitude to the Americans.
Summary: "Don't work there if you have ethics"
Pro: Anonymous provides good benefits, although they have declined.  Reasonable salaries and a good bonus are offered.  Modern technologies are employed so good for software developers.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: In a lot of cases, progression up the hierarchy seemed to be the result of time served or by stroking the right ego. If you are the sort of person who thinks differently and enjoys a dynamic environment, this is probably not the place for you. Being told what to do by Boston, as in other US multinationals, can make for an easy, but un-challenging routine. The organisation in Ireland is also completely at the whim of management in Boston and things can turn from positive to negative (and back again, to be fair) with consequent insecurity at times.
Pro: The benefits package at the time was very good. The pension plan, in particular, was one of the best around, especially once you had built up some service time. The working atmosphere was, for the most part, friendly and relaxed.

Top Performers are not valued - appraisal rates vary drastically across verticals for the same performance rating.

India office is full of management politicking with little opportunities that aren't gimmicks. 



Anonymous in US might be a great place to work, not so in India.



No synergy across Bangalore and Chennai India sites.



Anonymous India lies to Anonymous US (fact).

Company with great management and pedigree, but only in the USA.



Significant on-site opportunities for a valued employee in India.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than3 years

Con: Where to start?  Ridiculous amount of people working on small projects that in any normal software house would take 3 weeks but take 3 months in fmr.  The Ireland offices are pretty much treated as an off-shore group, work is allocated from the US, but Ireland is not seen as an equal partner. You are expected to fill the time with coming up with "innovation" ideas, which basically means trying to convince the US partners to let you have more people ... exacerbating the first issue which is there's too many people and not enough work.  Also they have no clue what the function of a QA group in a SDLC is, and as far as career growth they expect testers to transition into "real" careers, i.e. management or automation developers.
Pro: Benefits (pension, bonus) are really excellent.  Training opportunities are good, advice would be to join the company, skill up on as much as you can (and you will have time to do it) then leave after a year.
Recommendation: Doesn't Recommend,Neutral Outlook,No opinion of CEO
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than a year

Con:
Hi Folks,



This is an honest review from someone who is been working for 4 Years in this company Anonymous Gurgaon Unitech cyber park office.

Total experience is of 8 Years now.

I have seen this company on all its sections functioning in gurgaon. So i will comment on each dept individually. Myself been part of I.T Technology department, i have worked in development/maintenace and support roles in this company so knows in and out. This review is completely transparent and genuine.





I.T Technology Dept Review: 



1) Only if you join above "Tech spec/Project Lead" level i.e 10 plus years this company might be for you otherwise please go to any service based firm even if you are paid little less. The life below the 10 Years guy is a hazardous journey. The people at higher level are sitting for more than a decade,  they do not have any kind of skills ..be it technical/managerial. Pure office politics and not giving credits and demotivation from senior management. Knowledge sharing is not a concept here, only self learning and politics is the mantra.



2) The Support profiles in company L1/L2/L3 ,People in these roles are highly frustrated, There is no learning there are no knowledge sharing sessions between development and support team.The heads of two departments are often on rivalry which leads to suffering of employees only. They do not have work life balance, the shift allowance and oncall support allowance are worst than any other firm. Working in night shift entitles you to a mere 200 rs a day and being oncall for 24 hrs even on weekend from home entitles you to only 350 rs a day. 

The project once developed is made live and the support team is not made aware till the release day what they are going to support in production :):).



2) Zero onsite opportunity, and by chance if there is any(1 week/1 month) they make you travel on sunday night ..reach UK on monday morning directly to join office then dey make you fly back on friday evening after office...as they dont believe on spending even for 1 xtra day to employee....and per diem they give is 28 pounds. Which is lowest.



3) High disparity in salaries within peers. A mid level employee salary difference could be in 1-8 lacs, so you can imagine the disparity level as you go up.



4) Their promotion cycle is July? But the clever HR has declared minimum difference for next role change is 18 months. So that automatically comes to 2 years. And mgmt will obviously take 2 cycles as a concept to promote you so minimum 4 years of waiting for a promotion after "senior analyst programmer" which is for 5 plus years itself and ranges to 10 years.



5) Bonus potential. It is part of pkg only and based on rating it is reduced as well . So how they can call it bonus. Next is you have to wait for year end to get it, if you leave between, it is completely surrendered.



6) No HR in the company. There is high shortage of HR. There is no concept of HR meeting of whatsoever. The HR is not available in the company for anything you dont have any HR to discuss any grieviance you have. There is just payroll department. All the HR are contractual ppl passed from colleges..they are kids just for recruitng people, even talking to them feels ashamed of urself.



7) Company itself finding difficult to cut off the extremely highly paid people working in the company since beginning. These people are stuck to company like termites they have packages equivalent to what their team is getting and are not a value to company. So company is slowly trying to get rid of them and past 5 years there has been sacking of people at higher levels quietly.





Operations-Back Office Department Overview:



1) It is worst for Operations / back-office department people.  Long hours.Strict breaks of 60 mins, which are being checked via software which checks the login hours of employee on computer.If the time out is more than 1 hr then he is to be scolded.



2) Worst paid, over worked. Highly uneducated an unprofessional culture in Operations team. So 1 rating for that. Just for sake of getting a job and so called brand name ..you can join Anonymous in operations. It is worst then call centers.
Pro: Major Pros: Free Cab and free food. Thats it!  Might be lenient towards female employees. Used to be a good firm3 years back

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con:
After I quit the company, I realized how come there are so many good reviews about this company. Then I realised probably they're the ones who never had any work in the company during work-hrs



- no work-life balance, Managers will tell u upfront to work till 16 hrs a day and shout at you in front of everyone ( ask u to do development during day time and Prod support at night)

- improper performance review, biased and politically influenced

- Ethics helpline is just a gimmick, there is blatant favoritism etc

- HR is a puppet who are mere slaves of managers/directors

- BAD BAD COMPENSATION: Bonus is HEAVILY included in the CTC and they'll eat away all you own money

- They'll give a huge chunk like 50K as transportation which U wont get upto even a penny if u dont opt for (good for far flung commuters)

- NO TAX saving options in salary and U get MEAGRE take-home (the company earns keeping all ur money in their own FDs)

- Medical Benefits/Hospitalization is only upto 1 lac/a where in a part of premium is deducted from ur salary too (My current org gives upto 3 lacs covering even in laws paying complete premium)
Pro:
I joined this company reading the same reviews like most of them do in here but probably the biggest mistake of my career to have done except a few. And those few are the pros:



- Gurukool sessions

- Good quality work

- Good transport facilities

- Great marketing of own brand

- Good leave policy

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than5 years
Author Title: Current Employee - Senior Quality Assurance Engineer

Con:
No work life balance. Almost all weekends are working. They say that you can take comp-off. But when you ask leave, they talk about the work load and deadlines. 

Long working hours. Though you leave home on time, you have to carry lot of work with you to complete from home.

Managers openly threaten you for sacking.

Very high iteration ratio. Almost every MONTH, good %  of staff are said to leave (including contractors) which is way beyond our imagination. Here when I say contractors, it does not mean that their contract is over & then said to leave. They are forcefully said to leave. 

Higher management are very rude towards employees. 

Employee has more work pressure than contractors. Managers blame employees if something is not going good even though contractors are working on that subject.

Few departments are even worse like TIS(infrastructure), retail, web etc.
Pro: Anonymous, Gurgaon is a step sister of Anonymous USA (FMR). Being a multinational company, you can see big name. Anonymous has many names, but if it comes to Anonymous Gurgaon, Cyber park office, than think it‚Äôs the one we are taking about.
