Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than a year

Con:
I think the pay-scale and bonus. It's very low for the people who work consistently and who do not work will earn a higher bonus.

There is favoritism if you belong to the same community.

Even if you don't like gossiping, you have to be present with the team when they are doing so.

Team leaders have to improve on their process knowledge. Leadership skills are important but it does not mean it is unnecessary to learn the process.

Working on Saturday's and Sunday during peak seasons.

Never buy food in Cafeteria. It's tasty but your stomach will start bloating after an hour. Every food item is prepared with Baking Soda. Chapatis are fine to have but get your gravy/subji.
Pro:
As a fresher you have to join this company. It will help you to understand the meaning of pressure at work.

It will help you in Multitasking. It will help you in planning your leaves, a day's schedule. Freshers can work here for 1 years. If you really like the Company and want your career to grow then start preparing for your IJP.

Bonus will be good but there will be minimum change in your CTC. You'll find good friends in your Cab but not in team. If you feel there is no growth in your job or not interested to do the record keeping job then please move on. Yes fun factor will be there only if you are in a fun team. Competition is High so Beware of your Co-Workers.

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than3 years

Con: It is not easy - but nothing good ever is.
Summary: "Great place to work - you're expected to work hard but are rewarded in return!"
Pro: Opportunities abound.  It really is what you make of it.  You have the opportunity to grow - tuition and training are supported by the organization - allowing you to grow and create your own opportunities.  Benefit programs are the best in the industry.  Innovation is encouraged and rewarded.  Organizational success is celebrated.  Client focused culture that respects the employee contribution.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 10 years

Con:
No longer employee friendly company.  Lot of high level (senior management) politics played in a dirty manner. Senior management's insecurity drives tenured and talent people to move out in search of better opportunities.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than a year

Con:
Today Anonymous is a place you should look to only as a last resort.  You will live in constant fear of having your job off-shored, eliminated, or moved halfway across the country.  Some choice anecdotes from the last few years:

- Sold your house to follow your job to another state two years ago?  Good for you, you can move again this year, right?  

- Involuntary transfer from the East Coast to the Midwest last year?  So sorry, you make too much money, here's a 20% pay cut; you can take the pay cut, or take a severance package at your *new* pay rate.

- Great news!  We eliminated our on-shore development team to save money, so you'll need to work with the new offshore development team to complete your projects.  PS - they're twelve hours ahead, and they aren't allowed to work remotely, so you'll have to work with them during their business hours (9 PM - 5 AM EST).  Make sure you're in the office 8 AM to 6 PM though, wouldn't want to people to think you're slacking.

- Due to the economic climate, there will be no merit or cost-of-living increases this year, and bonuses and incentive programs are being cut for individual contributors.  The good news is, we did manage to scrape up 300 million dollars for off-cycle bonuses for our top 270 executives.

- It's the first Tuesday of the month.  The good new is, it will be way easier to find a parking spot tomorrow.  The bad news is, you'll have no idea whether that key contributor on your project has been laid-off, or if they're on vacation for a week (unless you're the key contributor, of course).
Pro:
Ten years ago Anonymous was a great company to work for.  Five years ago, before Lawson's reign of error chased out much of the core of long-term senior executives, Anonymous was a good company to work for.



Benefits are still good (though much reduced from earlier days).  Compensation has been been flat for years, while the workload and responsibilities have increased as headcount has dropped.
Recommendation: Doesn't Recommend,Neutral Outlook,No opinion of CEO

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time for more than 10 years

Con: Working in a call center is so, so, sooo very monotonous. The job very quickly becomes, not only uninteresting, but also completely unchallenging. The immediate supervisors (excellent performers and leaders) were laid off a couple of times, and then replaced by lower paid, inexperienced, entry level supervisors. Also, reassignment and relocation is common. I had 4 different managers and constantly rearranged teams over the course of 2 & 1/2 years. Entire departments were suddenly and unceremoniously laid off, as well. Working on the phones gives you a certain amount of security, because they need people to answer the calls... but, there's not very much opportunity for advancement. When you are on the phones you are pretty much tethered to your phone and your desk until your designated breaks, so you need to have a strong bladder or lay off of the fluids for hours at a time. You don't really get a chance to interact or get to know your co-workers. Meetings were cut down, which cut down on goal monitoring, teambuilding and learning opportunities. The part-timers had very little opportunity to become full-time workers. If you are on an evening shift it is practically a Herculean feat to get moved to the day shift, even if you've worked there for years. However, despite this fact, the company will consistently bring on completely new hires and place THEM on the day shift... meanwhile, they'll tell the tenured evening shift-ers that there are "no daytime slots" available at this time, and ask them to please be patient (years into waiting).
Pro: Good Benefits, easy call metrics, easy to learn procedures, ability to learn about investments or benefits side of the business, slightly better pay compared to other call centers in the NC area, pleasant modern decor, very ergonomic desks & chairs, clean facilities, competent co-workers. If you can somehow manage to either get your series 6&7 licenses (which they'll pa for... but only very rarely, to reign in costs), or transfer to HR or IT... the company could be a good place to be in the long run. Whatever you do. Do not stay on the phones. It is seriously a slow, mind-numbing and monumentally uneventful death.

Pro: Helps to keep a balance between worklife and personal life.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Because of the size of Anonymous there are numerous levels management. Each level needs to prove their importance and thus creates and changes various policies, programs and guidelines. Anonymous is constantly changing  how they do business along with moving upper management in and out of various roles. The message to our clients is we are consistently changing how we do business. Due to so many various groups, any change in one effects the other. There is constant fixing of issues and solving shortcomings in the system. Our current issue relates to rolling out the "pod" as it was made to be a success  even before it was rolled out. It was over staffed, over funded, few clients and support both from internal as well as external OSG groups. Once it was declared a major success the remaining tiers of service were rolled out. This time all support was cut off from the out side groups, causing all internal groups to design a path in how to facilitate various "how toos". These new PODS where to handle the same amount of work with 3-4 times the number of clients. Where the average rep took- 10-15 calls  a day the new expectation is 35-50 calls. The service groups are now required to work overtime and find a way to get it done. Just as any change takes time to work out all the kinks we will find a way to make it work.  However in the near future upper management will change again and we will be following a new model. Management will need to prove their worth and will create all types of policies, programs and we will be jumping through a whole new set of hoops. Our focus needs to be on the clients and listen to them and listen to the employees who are on the front lines and understand what they dealing with. There is a huge gap between the reality of what we do and what upper management believes we do.
Pro: Anonymous has hired some excellent and very qualified people.  They created a very strong brand name through a focus on technology and

Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Used to be great in that you were paid according to effort (small bps for products), there was no arguing your performance and you had greater control. Higher salaries seemed great at first, but ultimately muddied the waters on your value. 

Introduction of higher salaries vs. basis point commission for production made the retail channel thick with bureaucracy for the sales force, muddled value interpretation (having to prove you are worthy of your salary), and ultimately allows for back stabbing by direct management, who generally go unchecked while often adding little to nothing by way of support, help, and development.

Focus on numbers solely over development (Sell tons of PAS and FILI or else)

Management now uses fear of losing one's job as motivating tool, rather than true development while masking it with a smile and telling you it is not the case. Managers and sales force seem at odds; kind of like the shipmaster with a whip and the rowers of the boat (it doesn't feel as though you have anyone trying to help you develop, rather just trying to whip your performance for their own bottom line)

Morale has deteriorated dramatically-ask anyone on the sales force

Your career is in the hands of your manager who solely interprets your worth, especially now that sales force is primarily salary.

It started out as a job I woke up and was happy to go to, but ended up a job I dreaded because the focus became random numbers (some that made little sense or seemed arbitrary like the customer satisfaction numbers and contacts) Important, but nonsensical, unclear, and clearly more important to your manager's bottom line. (Customer satisfaction is important to the sales force, the numbers are important to management) Even though no one can make heads or tails of them, sales force gets beaten up over them.

Managers seem to go unchecked, and while they may face pressure from their managers, can easily shift the accountability to the employees sales performance rather than their own lack of support and development. 

I was actually told by a Regional Manager my past performance is irrelevant, it's a "what have you done for me lately environment."
Summary: "Great name, but only used to be a great place to work. Now it's "what have you done for me lately.""
Pro:
Brand Recognition (Anonymous is almost like Coke in the investment world)

Great products (though managed product too cookie cutter for high net worth customers)

Pay is pretty good for premium discount brokerage compared with similar brokerage firms

Great Colleagues on the sales force, including regional specialists and consultants
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con:
One thing is consistant and that is change.

Politics run extreamely thick and drive management to manage up and out vs. down.

There is a push to reduce the overall cost of the workforce so work is being offshored.
Pro: The technology can be interesting.  There is always something happening with the business to keep you interested with the marketplace.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Definitely lower base pay than other companies

Bonus potential is a scam ... e.g. I am in the 30% pool, by the end of the year, my bonus will be my salary x 30% (my pool) x ~80% (base on my group's performance) x ~75% (base on my own performance).  So, technically, my bonus is only 50-60% of my potential.  In the old days, there is only 1 haircut (only my performance).
Summary: "Good place to learn how to do fundamental research."
Pro:
Benefits (401k match and profit sharing adds up to 17% of base and bonus)

Free bottled water, sodas, juice, milk for people in the invesstment company (FMR Co)

Huge travel budget for investment professionals

Access to a lot of research tools 

Access to senior management of outside companies ... on any given day, we have50-50 company meetnig inhouse.

Con: Leadership is very poor, managers gossip about their employees.  I had great reviews all through my tenure, and then all of a suden I got a terrible review and was then laid off.  Many others I spoke to had the same experience.  A sudden bad review and then kicked out the door.  Its just a very lame way to treat employees who have put so much effort into the company.  Its one thing to be honest but that is horrible mistreatment, really brings down morale.  There are no training programs, you are basically thrown into your role.  You are expected to work at least 50 hours a week.    once it was  great place with positive feedback and growth potential, now everyone backstabs and is bitter and rude.
Pro: Benefits and salary are good.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: While I mentioned the coaching sessions as a good thing, this is only true if you have a great manager. For most of the managers I worked with at Anonymous, it seemed they tried to fill the coaching time with criticisms, rather than using positive reinforcement and education. Phone center environment in general is rough on most.  For the last 2 years or so, they haven't been hiring within the company much for different departments.
Pro: Great benefits (7%101k match, fantastic health insurance, education, fitness, and technology reimbursement, etc). They'll train you and walk you through getting the licenses you'll need, of which they cover the costs. They schedule weekly coaching sessions with your team manager to try and remain involved in your individual success. Easy metrics to follow, in general.

A lot of politics in management.  It's more about which managers you are 'buddies'  with over merit.  

Very easy to get stuck in a group and focus on a select few technologies and be very good at it, but moving to other groups is not quite as easy.

Get to work with a lot of high-end technology with firewalls and network devices.

Very detail oriented approach to certifying solutions are fit for the environment before production deployment.   Promotes operational stabilty.

A lot of resources available like their FCAT technology library where you can get books and also the Safari online books anytime.  

I've had great managers and horrible managers during my time at Anonymous.  It really depends on who you work for sometimes.

Con: Poor pay.  Management constantly changes the strategic direction - every 6 months the investment team is presented with a new plan.  Get the impression they are constantly in fear of losing their job as performance is pretty bad, so get out of jail card is a new 'plan'.  Building fiefdoms is a key activity of middle-management, especially on the DOR team.  HR just seems to follow management around to see what they are required to do next - no strategic direction at all, 'yes-man' mentality.  Anonymous pays so badly that it really is not a long-term career option - benefits to your Resume after 1 year are more or less the same as after 5 years and even 10 - so makes sense to leave after 3-4 years.  However, the most disappointing thing about this company, is that there is no concern for employees, you are just a cog in the wheel.
Summary: "Good benefits, poor pay, constant management change, little respect for employees"
Pro: Used to be a good company to work for, still a good brand on Resume, colleagues at the Analyst & Fund Manager level were smart.

Pay is mediocre in comparison to other firms, but you job security is huge in our industry and you can be a bump on a log for the next 40 years if you want.
Pro: Incredible job security, profit sharing and matching at 7%, full dental medical and vision. Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
This privately held company is only focused on delivering profit to the Johnson family and other shareholders.  Our management here in the UK is here simply to act on instruction, and HR are a joke.  Having worked for other Tier 1 public competitors it is amazing to see the poor quality of HR employees (big titles, low pay and below-average qualifications for such a large investment house)

 - who just implement instructions, with no focus on a happy and contented workforce.  I am getting more and more discouraged at the treatment of us as employees.  The morale is so bad that it is a key talking point- most fellow analysts that I speak are just waiting for an upturn in market conditions, to make a speedy exit to a better-paying, and more employee-friendly environment.
Summary: "Management and HR just do what the private shareholders tell them to do"
Pro: My fellow financial analysts are among the smartest in the industry.  A good place to have on your CV for a couple of years because of the formerly good reputation of this company.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: I can only think of one consistent negative--I've had a few managers who pretty much ignored me or gave me bogus answers when I needed help, but even so it still happens much less of the time than any other job I've held.
Pro: It really helps that I love what I do, but Anonymous is the best place I've ever worked.  Sure, I wish I was paid more, could advance faster, etc. (who wouldn't??), but on a day-to-day basis, I couldn't ask for more.  Anonymous has a wonderful company culture.  I work in an environment full of professionals, very competent at what they do, and everyone is extremely supportive.  Positive feedback is offered much more frequently than any other job I've had.  Management is incredible at communicating to employees what is expected of them, helping them when they're struggling, and letting them know how the company is doing.  The benefits are pretty good, and the flexibility available to help employees with their work-life balance is nothing short of amazing.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Find many "warm bodies" showing-up every day just looking to receive the outstanding benefits package presented to all employees.

Con: Pay could be improved, transport links to office were not good, if you missed the private coach slot due to a late train then you had to pay √Ç¬£20 for a taxi to the office.

Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: A very aggressive managment style that has no regard for their employees.....msg is clearly given that we can be easily replaced because of what they regard as the 'strength of the brand'.   Annual reviews are conducted by mgmt in the manner of how little they can get away with paying, rather than rewarding performance.  They string you along that next time it will be better, but most people realise after being through the process 3-4 times, that this is a continued practice, promoted by the owners who demand an 18% or so margin from the business.  We've even had it explained to us that our bonuses are down because this margin of profit to the Johnson Family must be preserved!!  I find it hard to believe that the company can continue this mgmt strategy towards employees, as morale is so low.  Once they've destroyed the goodwill among employees....as I've seen happen over and over again, when people realise that the promise of reward for hard work and exceptional performance is only a carrot they dangle with no intention of delivering....it is almost impossible to rebuild.
Summary: "Anonymous has very little regard for its employees"
Pro:
The experience is good, and my fellow colleagues are among the brightest in the field.  

However, management in London is very aggressive about getting as much as possible from employees, while paying as little as possible.  For example, in1007 they gave such bad annual salary increases, that they had to reverse their decision because they suddenly realised they would have huge numbers leaving the investment team because everybody was so disgruntled...we were all called in individually1 weeks after the 1st annual salary review mtg and told 'good news, we've decided to increase your remuneration'.  Literally, every year the company decides how little they can get away with paying..they push their employees to complete disillusionment.  I have never worked in such a negative environment...most people I talk to are waiting for the market to pick up so that we can jump ship.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: The unique history of this (non-public) enterprise provided a most credible corporate foundation to build loyalty between the Johnson family and their employees.  However, executive arrivals in the last two years were voluminous... accompanied by even more voluminous reports of executive departures... some of the brightest  long-term Anonymous executives plotted their own exits to Putnam Investments and Morgan Stanley.  Other long term Anonymous executives quietly and abruptly found themselves outside the evershrinking "circle of trust" atop the Anonymous pyramid, creating the largest leadership vacuum since the JFK tragedy in Dallas.   The Anonymous workforce planners look outside the company to hire leaders, so it's unlikely that anyone with mid-level or senior-level leadership abilities and aspirations will reach their full potential through long-term employment and loyalty to the company.
Summary: "For the moment, advancement comes fastest for "teams" of one.  Blue chip employees need to be patient."
Pro: One of the best places to gain basic training.  This is a company struggling to find an identity for the11st century... which gives it tremendous potential (for either success or decline).  Individual experience is dependent primarily on the quality of your immediate manager and their immediate superiors, as would be expected in any large (35,000+ employee) multinational firm trying to redefine itself.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Understaffed.

Lack of direction & focus w/ recent org changes.

Merit / bonus review process promotes mediocrity.
Pro:
Majority of managers respects work-life balance. 

Great training opportunities.

Con: Most of the fund managers and other analysts have their own agenda and so it can be quite fragmented in terms of communication, and accordingly recognition, unless you really make an effort.
Pro: Extremely well recognised in the City and a lot of sway with companies and brokers; great opportunities to learn. A lot of freedom to run your own diary and pursue ways that you think will add value to the research process.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con:
Certain sections' job responsibilities are highly stress-prone - management sometimes take decisions based on budget planning rather than people development.

Most of upper level leadership is not technology aware, which makes them poor project planners, which in turn affects people development.

HR is too busy managing technical workforce coming in and going out, hence cannot do much to solve the management issues.
Summary: "Good, better  than most perhaps - but could be the best."
Pro:
Excellent facilities and infrastructure (may not last long due to recession).

Highly encourages innovation and employee development even though scope is minimal due to restricted financial domain.

Competitive pay structures (may not last long due to recession).

Management ensures proper communication to all employees in major decisions.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Company recently completed mass layoffs that clearly targeted the older, longer-tenured, more experienced employees.  Anonymous has made the decision that clients will be satisfied getting their retirement planning and investment advice from younger, cheaper, recent college grads rather than from loyal and experienced professionals.  Morale is at rock bottom across the country.  Benefits have been slashed.  All benefits that were once the pride of the industry have been drastically cut or eliminated - no more pension, no more company match to 401K, drastically higher health insurance costs.  With most recent layoffs, there can be no comfort in your job security.  Dozens of 20+ year employees were lay off simply because their pay was higher.  Many who were liad off were top performers with exceptional management reviews or were sales achievers.  Decisions of who would be laid off was made far above any local, regional or area manager level.  Management had not control of who and who would not be let go.  Products are low cost but they are becoming more and more low performance.  Anonymous was once the best in the field of equity mutual fund managment.  This is no longer the case.  Most of their funds are medocre at best.  With over 300 funds, they will have a few towards the top of some lists but most are below average.  The financial media has covered this extensively.
Pro: Great co-workers and life long friends met there.  Nice facilities.  Broad array of low cost products providing a good value.  Good web site that is easy to use in general.
Author Years: I worked at Anonymous Investments

Con: Changes, specifically to compensation and goals, are not communicated effectivly and in a timely manner. There are too many funds on the advisor side and while there are some good funds there is a lot of overlap and some of them are not managed well which can make sales very challenging. The daily job of an investment consultant is not correlated to compensation or to performance measurements. The stress level is high in my opinion especially when compared to the compensation. Competition with the direct side of Anonymous can also present a unique challenge compared to other firms.
Summary: "The Good and Not so Good  when considering working for Anonymous Investments"
Pro: Name Brand Recognition - Everyone knows Anonymous. Private Company. They Have great101k platform and strong mutual Funds that are recognized for their management. The benefits are great and it is a family oriented company. The company is quick to adapt to a changing market environment and are committed to providing the BEST customer service to clients.
Author Years: I have been working at Anonymous Investments

Con: Lack of planning from management, crazy implementation schedules, outsourcing, lack of training and opportunities.  No overtime pay for IT, aggressive cost cutting measures, redundant meetings and projects, lots of politics.
Pro: Good benefits, challenging environment, many good people.

Con: There are 4 layers of middle management, and they are all worthless. Your "rewards" and bonuses will be downright insulting-  I once had a senior manager tell me to pat myself on the back (and literally made me pat myself on the back) for doing such a great job.
